revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-28 22:00:27.000000000', 'message': "Fix faked-out account GET for JSON and XML.

If account autocreation is on and the proxy receives a GET request for
a nonexistent account, it'll fake up a response that makes it look as
if the account exists, but without reifying that account into sqlite
DB files.

That faked-out response was just fine as long as you wanted a
text/plain response, but it didn't handle the case of format=json or
format=xml; in those cases, the response would still be
text/plain. This can break clients, and certainly causes crashes in
swift3. Now, those responses match as closely as possible.

The code for generating an account-listing response has been pulled
into (the new) swift.account.utils module, and both the fake response
and the real response use it, thus ensuring that they can't
accidentally diverge. There's also a new probe test for that
non-divergence.

Also, cleaned up a redundant matching of the Accept header in the code
for generating the account listing.

Note that some of the added tests here pass with or without this code
change; they were added because the code I was changing (parts of the
real account GET) wasn't covered by tests.

Bug 1183169

Change-Id: I2a3b8e5d9053e4d0280a320f31efa7c90c94bb06

commit_message:
Fix faked-out account GET for JSON and XML.

If account autocreation is on and the proxy receives a GET request for
a nonexistent account, it'll fake up a response that makes it look as
if the account exists, but without reifying that account into sqlite
DB files.

That faked-out response was just fine as long as you wanted a
text/plain response, but it didn't handle the case of format=json or
format=xml; in those cases, the response would still be
text/plain. This can break clients, and certainly causes crashes in
swift3. Now, those responses match as closely as possible.

The code for generating an account-listing response has been pulled
into (the new) swift.account.utils module, and both the fake response
and the real response use it, thus ensuring that they can't
accidentally diverge. There's also a new probe test for that
non-divergence.

Also, cleaned up a redundant matching of the Accept header in the code
for generating the account listing.

Note that some of the added tests here pass with or without this code
change; they were added because the code I was changing (parts of the
real account GET) wasn't covered by tests.

Bug 1183169

Change-Id: I2a3b8e5d9053e4d0280a320f31efa7c90c94bb06

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-12 07:48:57.000000000', 'message': 'Add nova configuration reference tables

This is the first attempt at automatically generated configuration
tables being added to documentation.
blueprint autogenerate-config-tables
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Blueprint-autogenerate-config-tables

Work is being conducted out-of-repo at :

https://github.com/fifieldt/autogenerate-config-docs

Nova has existing tables, which are out of date for Grizzly.
These new tables will need to be linked in, but first submitting these for
review without linking them in to a book yet, because feedback is needed.

Please provide feedback on:
* completeness (is every option and its description present)
* groupings (is every option in the right group)
* potential integrations (can you see where one or more of these
tables could be combined under a nice descriptive paragraph)
* relationships to config files (are these useful as is, or how to
best integrate them with examples)
* anything else you can think of

Change-Id: I2c400fa511df5c878c5b640085a6e5286b1dd318

commit_message:
Add nova configuration reference tables

This is the first attempt at automatically generated configuration
tables being added to documentation.
blueprint autogenerate-config-tables
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Blueprint-autogenerate-config-tables

Work is being conducted out-of-repo at :

https://github.com/fifieldt/autogenerate-config-docs

Nova has existing tables, which are out of date for Grizzly.

Patchset 2:

Based on positive feedback, patchset 2 links in the tables to the
Compute Administration Guide, expanding its configuration reference,
adding config option sections to areas that lacked them and
removing old tables.

Patchset 3/4 just updates the author's email address.

Change-Id: I2c400fa511df5c878c5b640085a6e5286b1dd318

commit_message:
Ports consoles API to v3 API

Ports the core consoles API functionality to the V3 API as a
plugin along with the corresponding tests

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-core-as-extensions

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-14 20:09:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Set -2 because I want to make sure I get a chance to review this, and we still need to figure out an acceptable solution to the problem'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-22 21:09:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Ok, so after looking at this more, I really can't think of any better way to fix this.  Also, when I first read this, I read the json usage backwards.  What it's doing now is effectively the same thing that kombu does internally.  So, really, we're making the qpid code act exactly like the kombu code, except we're doing the additional json step in our qpid driver, while in the other case it happens in the kombu library.

The extremely unfortunate thing here is that it's not backwards compatible.  As it stands, grizzly won't understand the messages we send.  However, I think we could add a bug fix patch to grizzly to make it understand this change.  As long as you upgraded to have this bug fix before upgrading to havana, then I think we would be in good shape.

How does that sound?"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-24 17:44:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

Just for my clarification, your previous concern was the trusted-messaging bp, right?  Just want to make sure there isn't something else I'm unaware of.

One other possibility for Grizzly compatibility would be to not JSON encode if the content is small enough.  The receiving side already handles that, so it would just take some logic on the sending side to decide which format to send.  It's still not perfect, but it would make Grizzly work for 99.9% of the messages without any changes.  And we could still provide a patch to make it work for the other .1% if we wanted."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-24 22:30:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-24 22:33:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-09 19:23:53.000000000', 'message': 'Fix problem with long messages in Qpid

Qpid has a limitation where it cannot serialize a dict containing
a string greater than 65535 characters.  This change alters the
Qpid implementation to JSON encode the dict before sending it
to get around this limitation.  Qpid is able to handle long
standalone strings better than long strings in dicts.

The new code can handle old-style messages, but the old code will
not handle the new message format, so the RPC envelope minor
version was bumped.  Otherwise, this change should not affect
any other RPC code.

Fixes bug 1175808

Change-Id: I5d104e099f523508dae2b657f7d06d96984b10f0
'}, {'created': '2013-05-14 15:58:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix problem with long messages in Qpid

Qpid has a limitation where it cannot serialize a dict containing
a string greater than 65535 characters.  This change alters the
Qpid implementation to JSON encode the dict before sending it
to get around this limitation.  Qpid is able to handle long
standalone strings better than long strings in dicts.

The new code can handle old-style messages, but the old code will
not handle the new message format, so the RPC envelope minor
version was bumped.  Otherwise, this change should not affect
any other RPC code.

Fixes bug 1175808

Change-Id: I5d104e099f523508dae2b657f7d06d96984b10f0
'}, {'created': '2013-05-24 22:30:49.000000000', 'message': 'Fix problem with long messages in Qpid

Qpid has a limitation where it cannot serialize a dict containing
a string greater than 65535 characters.  This change alters the
Qpid implementation to JSON encode the dict before sending it, but
only if Qpid would fail to serialize it.  This maintains as much
backward compatibility as possible, though long messages will
still fail if they are sent to an older receiver.

Fixes bug 1175808

Change-Id: I5d104e099f523508dae2b657f7d06d96984b10f0
'}, {'created': '2013-05-24 22:42:57.000000000', 'message': 'Fix problem with long messages in Qpid

commit_message:
Fix problem with long messages in Qpid

Qpid has a limitation where it cannot serialize a dict containing
a string greater than 65535 characters.  This change alters the
Qpid implementation to JSON encode the dict before sending it, but
only if Qpid would fail to serialize it.  This maintains as much
backward compatibility as possible, though long messages will
still fail if they are sent to an older receiver.

Fixes bug 1175808

Change-Id: I5d104e099f523508dae2b657f7d06d96984b10f0

commit_message:
Tests should be using require_relative

The #require_relative statement is relative to the file
containing the the statement. Also, updated spec_helper
constants to follow existing spacing format.

Change-Id: I33c5c158ea34c30baf63bd72819b9d44b8516ca4

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-23 19:56:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

so, instead of solving it this way, can we have tests that do invalid UUID, which should return the same on both nova-network and quantum?

Then have a separate test that that is basically the existing tests, but skip on quantum with a registration against the bug? Because I do think that because this is through a servers call we should normalize the errors to the user (even if that means changes in V3 api)."}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2013-05-24 09:13:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I am not sure this is the right think to do. My patch set 'fixes' 4 Tempest tests do make them work with Quantum. If we split these 4 tests, there would be 4 additional tests that would be very similar to each other.

>can we have tests that do invalid UUID, which should return the same on both nova-network and quantum?
The thing is, if you send an invalid UUID (invalid UUID here means non-existent uuid) to nova-network it won't reply with the expected exceptions.NotFound but with a u'badRequest': {u'message': u'Security group id should be integer', u'code': 400}

So I am bit confused on what to do. Maybe it will be clearer after the Nova team comments bug #1182384."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-01 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-01 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2013-06-04 13:17:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Unless we get this changed in nova/quantum, I agree with Jordan that this is the right approach to test a non-existent SG. 
If we want to test the case of invalid SG id, we would also need to differentiate between nova-net and quantum. Not an integer for nova-net, not an uuid for quantum.'}]

commit_message:
Avoiding multiple code loops in filter scheduler

The code snippet can not provide the original target. In the
filters module, there is one line code will never be invoked
because of the code logic, so I modified it.

Fixes: bug 1186945
Change-Id: I3f2a662c28ab466b178268cae3502c40a1d22657

commit_message:
Cluster security and node placement control

Adding user key to the cluster

Each cluster will have a it own private key for passwordless login

It is possible to schedule a data nodes on diffirent hosts

implements: blueprint node-placement-control and blueprint cluster-security

fixed: bug #1179815 and bug  #1179821

Change-Id: I27183b9fcf1652b8f65a7018fe9cb880d5bed3b3

[{'created': '2013-06-04 02:48:32.000000000', 'message': 'Relax lxml version requirements.

This was preventing devstack from starting on Fedora 18 due to the
package python-lxml-3.2.1-1.fc18.x86_64 being too new.

This change is aligns the lxml rule with the requirements project.

Change-Id: Idd3697596dcefb830d60f8e44171b8c50e78178a
'}]
commit_message:
Relax lxml version requirements.

This was preventing devstack from starting on Fedora 18 due to the
package python-lxml-3.2.1-1.fc18.x86_64 being too new.

This change is aligns the lxml rule with the requirements project.

Change-Id: Idd3697596dcefb830d60f8e44171b8c50e78178a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 08:14:11.000000000', 'message': 'Suppress or re-raise as NovaException for failed libvirt domain lookups

Libvirt exceptions should be handled locally by either suppressing or
re-raising them as NovaExceptions. This fix does:

- Fix unhandled exceptions in list_instance_uuids and get_memory_mb_used.
- Centralize libvirt exception handling in new method _lookup_by_id.
- Improve test coverage for list_instances and list_instance_uuids.

Resolves bug 1182184.

Change-Id: If946f9d05388c93c0630d454e5ca3b6625bb14f9
'}, {'created': '2013-05-30 10:56:21.000000000', 'message': 'Improve error handling in libvirt driver

Libvirt defaults to outputting errors on stderr in addition to being
raised. Furthermore some libvirt exceptions for failed lookups can
safely be ignored while others should be re-raised and then as a
NovaException.

Included in this fix:

- Replace default error handler to defer outputting on strerr.
- Fix unhandled exceptions in list_instance_uuids and
  get_memory_mb_used.
- While fixing list_instance_uuids, this change also removes an
  unnecessary extra lookup for every instance.
- Centralize libvirt exception handling in new method _lookup_by_id.
- Improve test coverage for list_instances and list_instance_uuids.

Resolves bug 1182184.

Change-Id: If946f9d05388c93c0630d454e5ca3b6625bb14f9
'}, {'created': '2013-06-03 18:34:05.000000000', 'message': 'Stop libvirt errors from outputting to strerr

When a libvirt error happens, the default is to output to stderr. This
behavior can be omitted by registering a new error that simply passes
without doing anything.

Resolves bug 1182184.

Change-Id: If946f9d05388c93c0630d454e5ca3b6625bb14f9
'}, {'created': '2013-06-03 19:13:48.000000000', 'message': 'Stop libvirt errors from outputting to strerr

When a libvirt error happens, the default is to output to stderr. This
behavior can be omitted by registering a new error that simply passes
without doing anything.

Resolves bug 1182184.

Change-Id: If946f9d05388c93c0630d454e5ca3b6625bb14f9
'}]
commit_message:
Stop libvirt errors from outputting to strerr

When a libvirt error happens, the default is to output to stderr. This
behavior can be omitted by registering a new error that simply passes
without doing anything.

Resolves bug 1182184.

Change-Id: If946f9d05388c93c0630d454e5ca3b6625bb14f9

stop sharing a single session for everything. use common.db.sqlalchemy code
to handle session management

re-enable use of CEILOMETER_TEST_SQL_URL

Fixes: bug 1183996

commit_message:
Change memcache config entry name in Keystone to be consistent with Oslo

Currently, Keystone-Client is using "memcache_servers" config option to store
the memcache server info, while in OSLO project, it is using "memcached_servers"
to config the same option. It is better to change keystone-client's
"memcache_servers" to "memcached_servers" to keep consistent between these two
projects.

The changes mainly include:
1. Change the codes in keystoneclient/middleware/auth_token.py to use name "memcached_servers"
2. Due to the changes made in #1, need to change the corresponding testing codes
in keystoneclient/tests/test_auth_token_middleware.py
3. Change the relevant document in keystoneclient/doc/source/middlewarearchitecture.rst

Fixes: Bug 1172793
Change-Id:Ifa4eca2011053f4c97b60ef9702fadbd8ce7ad41

commit_message:
Remove tools/openstack_ubuntu script.

Taking into account the script does not work, and according to
heat's 2013/05/22 team meeting [1], the team decided to remove the
openstack_ubuntu script. This commit just performs this action.

This commit also removes the documentation that mention this script.

Fixes: bug 1175817

[1] http://goo.gl/z1Btz

Change-Id: I4507f60739e1efefb1e0b59375a5aeddd9a63876

commit_message:
Added attribute 'ip' to server search options.

Allows all tenants to use attribute 'ip' in server search options.
For this fix, added attribute 'ip' to server search options.
Modified the existing test case to verify 'ip' based server search
for all tenants.

Change-Id: Ia53ab0ab3553b5b09612f2989addbf39868b125d
Implements: blueprint add-attribute-ip-in-server-search-options

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: migration error when running db-sync

migration incorrectly sorted order of tables for Events causing Event
and Trait tables to be generated before unique_name table which both tables
require

Change-Id: I6fe7ceb0905ace3993116c6a274b6c39e11554bf
Fixes:Bug #1186283

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-29 20:56:27.000000000', 'message': 'Handle versioned egg fragments in dependency URLs

If you include a dependency URL in your requirements file that has an
egg fragment e.g.

  http://tarballs.openstack.org/oslo.config/oslo.config-1.2.0a2.tar.gz#egg=oslo.config

we include the full URL in dependency_links (as you'd expect), but also
include the egg fragment in our requires.

With oslo.config, we're seeing a situation where 1.1.1 is installed and,
while pip knows that 1.2.0a2 is available (via dependency_links),
because our requires only say 'oslo.config' and we haven't passed
--upgrade, then pip sees the requirement as satisfied and doesn't
install 1.2.0a2.

What we really want to express is "we require at least 1.2.0a2 and
here's where you can find it" so, for example, we'll be happy if a newer
version is installed or available from pypi but, if not, then we'll
install from the supplied URL.

Now, egg fragments can be versioned e.g.

  http://tarballs.openstack.org/oslo.config/oslo.config-1.2.0a2.tar.gz#egg=oslo.config-1.2.0a2

but we need to transform the fragment so our requires becomes:

  oslo.config>=1.2.0a2

We should be fine for a backwards compatibility perspective, because
an egg fragment which included a hyphen just wouldn't have worked.

Change-Id: I6ec1b935d08ed5db993a3e47f591104528582101
'}]
commit_message:
Handle versioned egg fragments in dependency URLs

If you include a dependency URL in your requirements file that has an
egg fragment e.g.

  http://tarballs.openstack.org/oslo.config/oslo.config-1.2.0a2.tar.gz#egg=oslo.config

we include the full URL in dependency_links (as you'd expect), but also
include the egg fragment in our requires.

With oslo.config, we're seeing a situation where 1.1.1 is installed and,
while pip knows that 1.2.0a2 is available (via dependency_links),
because our requires only say 'oslo.config' and we haven't passed
--upgrade, then pip sees the requirement as satisfied and doesn't
install 1.2.0a2.

What we really want to express is "we require at least 1.2.0a2 and
here's where you can find it" so, for example, we'll be happy if a newer
version is installed or available from pypi but, if not, then we'll
install from the supplied URL.

Now, egg fragments can be versioned e.g.

  http://tarballs.openstack.org/oslo.config/oslo.config-1.2.0a2.tar.gz#egg=oslo.config-1.2.0a2

but we need to transform the fragment so our requires becomes:

  oslo.config>=1.2.0a2

We should be fine for a backwards compatibility perspective, because
an egg fragment which included a hyphen just wouldn't have worked.

Change-Id: I6ec1b935d08ed5db993a3e47f591104528582101

pattern.

Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Change-Id: Ic220b54de5ce7c15f442b8ffcb97cd03c2344f9a
Fixes: bug #1179008

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names.

Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Change-Id: Ic220b54de5ce7c15f442b8ffcb97cd03c2344f9a
Fixes: bug #1179008

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

After looking into it further, adding "#egg=python-reddwarfclient" to the tarball url in test-requires will fix things in the VM.

I was wrong- the error I'm seeing is because my own working copy is in a submodule. 

I request that we wait to merge this until pbr works with submodules as it currently will keep me from using every working copy of the code I have. It will also introduce an immediate impediment to the deployment procedures we use at Rackspace.

I have a pull request for PBR that fixes an issue with submodules I saw in the VM. I'm not sure if it will fix the Tox issue as well or not.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29619/1'}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@ed Your line is similar to the one I suggested, which fixes the issue I saw when running setup.py in a VM.

However, after changing it like you suggest I still get that error. :('}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In the VM we're seeing the following error message:

"""error in setup command: 'tests_require' must be a string or list of strings containing valid project/version requirement specifiers"""

The culprit is a line in tools/test-requires where python-reddwarfclient is pulled down from a tarball on stackforge.

I looked into if pbr was causing this, but it the exception seems to originate in the Python core libs and pbr is simply triggering it somehow.

I did find a work around for the VM, with one *enormous* caveat: if the test-require line gets "#egg=python-reddwarfclient" appended to it, calling "sudo python setup.py develop" works fine:
"""
https://github.com/stackforge/python-reddwarfclient/tarball/master#egg=python-reddwarfclient
"""

However, on my host machine (OSX) this triggers a different bug when I wipe the .tox directory and try to build it again with tox -epy27 (haven't tried running tox with sudo permissions to see if that fixes it): https://gist.github.com/TimSimpsonR/5605056'}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Here's a recreate: https://gist.github.com/TimSimpsonR/5615992

Hopefully this doesn't end up being some weird OSX thing. I'm using git version 1.8.2.1."}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

This looks really cool but there's an issue breaking the test VM which I'd like to sort out in pbr before we use it."}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Mike just let me know he ran the recreate in OSX and it worked, so I'll assume my environment is funky."}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1375, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

diff --git a/tools/test-requires b/tools/test-requires
index e646ce4..e6f8b4a 100644
--- a/tools/test-requires
+++ b/tools/test-requires
@@ -14,7 +14,7 @@ openstack.nose_plugin
 webtest
 wsgi_intercept
 proboscis==1.2.5.3
-https://github.com/stackforge/python-reddwarfclient/tarball/master
+-e git://github.com/stackforge/python-reddwarfclient.git#egg=reddwarfclient
 mock
 mox
 testtools>=0.9.22'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build succeeded.

[{'created': '2013-06-03 19:44:39.000000000', 'message': 'Always create the `signing_dir` basedir

Since the `signing_dir` is always set in api-paste.ini,
the basedir must exist or the openstack compute API fails
to start.  No reason to guard the creation of this dir
now that it is always referenced.

Change-Id: I4c62cba37b801aa5d07151e049e6ad30bf6a8a29
'}]
commit_message:
Always create the `signing_dir` basedir

Since the `signing_dir` is always set in api-paste.ini,
the basedir must exist or the openstack compute API fails
to start.  No reason to guard the creation of this dir
now that it is always referenced.

Change-Id: I4c62cba37b801aa5d07151e049e6ad30bf6a8a29

[{'created': '2013-06-03 18:09:47.000000000', 'message': 'Tests should be using require_relative

is relative to the file containing the #require_relative

commit_message:
Initial commit of cinder-common

Noticed that every recipe in the cookbook had a declaration for the
cinder.conf template, with a notify to the service defined in that recipie.

I moved the template, and the variables that it needs to populate,
to cinder-common.rb, included that in all the other recipes,
and changed the notify in the template to subscribes in each service
Also, added a spec for this.

All tests pass

Change-Id: Ibcab9566a907e1ea9febbd61e37b9587625a15e6

commit_message:
updated content_type in the exception where it is missing.

Fixes bug 1184279

Added missing content_type in HTTPConflict, while attempting to upload a duplicate image.

Change-Id: I4dbef69b6f9e83d4b5090cc0bbfcb01611c05a37

commit_message:
Fixing delete backup

- Backup is not able to be delete because the object is not found in swift
- Issue is that the filename parsing is incorrect

fixes bug # 1186454

Change-Id: I0195aa72bf42a3d87d7e6c541655b172cae7f195

commit_message:
python3: Add py33 to tox.ini

Introduce py33 to tox.ini to make testing with
python3 easier.

Change-Id: I3f966efc1a845aaa8e317d810bd6a1366acd323c
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Adds ability to black/whitelist v3 API extensions

Adds a config option which will blacklist specific v3 API extensions
from being loaded even if they are detected.

Adds a config option which if the list is not empty will stop
any v3 API extension from being loaded unless it is in the whitelist.
No filtering occurs if the whitelist is empty

Creates a config option group osapi_v3 to hold the two new options
and osapi_v3_enabled renamed to just enabled within the new group

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-extension-framework

Change-Id: Iec7fdb073b933791b0110dae485538c9080f2670

chmod a+x bin/quantum-mlnx-agent

commit_message:
Add InvalidExternalNetwork exception to display correct error

Fixes bug 1075089

The message in the BadRequest exception raised in file
quantum/tests/unit/test_l3_plugin.py is
being muted in the logfile  since the BadRequest is
catched and writes its own log message.

Change-Id: Ia0140620205a80dd4b3637b2d41562adb7992b5c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-03 17:19:30.000000000', 'message': 'All tests should be using spec_helper

Not every test is utilizing spec_helper.  Clean up tests
so they are consistent with our other openstack tests.
Also, #require_relative allows you to load a file that
is relative to the file containing the #require_relative
statement.  We should update the remaining cookbook
tests to use this.

Change-Id: Iea7e94789629956458a0ec60a10ab8af0d7fae52
'}]
commit_message:
All tests should be using spec_helper

Not every test is utilizing spec_helper.  Clean up tests
so they are consistent with our other openstack tests.
Also, #require_relative allows you to load a file that
is relative to the file containing the #require_relative
statement.  We should update the remaining cookbook
tests to use this.

Change-Id: Iea7e94789629956458a0ec60a10ab8af0d7fae52

commit_message:
Moved sample network creation out of unittest base class constructor.

This sample networks only needed in:

 nova.tests.api.ec2.test_cloud
 nova.tests.integrated.test_api_samples
 nova.tests.network.test_manager
 nova.tests.test_libvirt
 nova.tests.test_xenapi

Moreover, base class constructor is not good place for sample
data creation. Database should be empty before runing tests.

Fixes: bug 1181502

Change-Id: I8dcaa5b36a1da0c0928c9445c556d788d463844e

commit_message:
heat-jeos.sh: Use netinst ISOs instead of full DVD isos

The netinst isos produce smaller qcow2 images and are faster
to download.  Use netinst ISOs for F17 instead.

Change-Id: I76c59728ed1b9b90b43487f93fdc2e55ee604916

commit_message:
Handle metadata updates during stack creation

Don't try to recalculate the metadata on an instance that hasn't yet been
stored in the database.

Fixes bug #1185530

Change-Id: I39f2733e2ba4730ea05a4a50962cb30f044ef752

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-02 19:05:32.000000000', 'message': 'Add sudo -E to heat-jeos recommended command

Normally heat would be run without root capabilities.  The
directory /var/lib/libvirt/images is typically not world
readable.  As a result, the glance operation requires root
permissions to actually read the file, and may be a source
of confusion for users.

Also break the notification into two lines since it wraps on
80 character windows.

Change-Id: I905f3c24ed253ddc1e843bc73c93464c65d3df0b
'}]
commit_message:
Add sudo -E to heat-jeos recommended command

Normally heat would be run without root capabilities.  The
directory /var/lib/libvirt/images is typically not world
readable.  As a result, the glance operation requires root
permissions to actually read the file, and may be a source
of confusion for users.

Also break the notification into two lines since it wraps on
80 character windows.

Change-Id: I905f3c24ed253ddc1e843bc73c93464c65d3df0b

commit_message:
HDS Cinder Driver. Rev #1

blueprint hds-hus-iscsi-cinder-driver
This is the first rev of Hitachi Data Systems Cinder iSCSI driver.
This driver works with HUS (df850) array.
This driver contains all the base-line features specified for Havana release.
Amended into this submission are changes from code-reviews.

Docimpact: Bug #1180648

Change-Id: Ia27d076443b10da2c653456f9292dd192362b853

commit_message:
Changed #config_by_role keystone handling

Identity attributes are no longer at the top level of
the node.  Need to properly access the new attributes.
Tests needed to be adjusted so that they would pass.

Change-Id: I0a697c217364a26ae97cf31d37a32e97f11c2e85

commit_message:
xenapi: kernel_cmdline moved out from template

The kernel's cmdline was set during the initial devstack machine
installation. Thus, during second runs, the kernel's cmdline was not
updated. This patch extracts append_kernel_cmdline, and configures
domU's kernel cmdline every time. As some networking parameters are
passed through the kernel cmdline, this patch makes it possible to
change the network configuration, even if a cached devstack exists.

Related to blueprint xenapi-devstack-cleanup

Change-Id: I3b7175f4e83326c3e28825ac50625f6bd2a9a029

Build succeeded.

'}, {'account_id': 7220, 'date': '2013-06-03 15:44:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Cool, I like having the thing we're looking like this. Better than hardcoding it."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-06-03 16:01:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

I really don't see the need for this particular addition. I mean, our standard best practice is to ONLY access attributes via dictionary key notation -- i.e. node["key1"]["key2"] -- and not use dotted notation -- i.e. node.key1.key2. In fact, we have a new style checker that verifies code doesn't use dotted notation.

And this addition now breaks that practice.'}, {'account_id': 216, 'date': '2013-06-03 17:13:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

This is no longer necessary.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-03 06:55:23.000000000', 'message': 'Added functionality to access nested attributes

Since moving to the new attributes we now have another level of
nesting.  Previously we were searching for attributes at the top
level (e.g. node['keystone']).  Now that we are nested under
`['openstack']` we need the functionality to perform deep finds.
Opted to add functionality to openstack-common vs hard-coding the
methods to always look under `['openstack']`.  Will submit a
follow-up bug to fix the following from `"openstack-identity"` to
"`openstack.identity`".
  https://github.com/stackforge/cookbook-openstack-compute/blob/master/recipes/nova-common.rb#L80

Change-Id: Id097666992e7457623e344ad914a736bce6a2fe5
'}]
commit_message:
Added functionality to access nested attributes

Since moving to the new attributes we now have another level of
nesting.  Previously we were searching for attributes at the top
level (e.g. node['keystone']).  Now that we are nested under
`['openstack']` we need the functionality to perform deep finds.
Opted to add functionality to openstack-common vs hard-coding the
methods to always look under `['openstack']`.  Will submit a
follow-up bug to fix the following from `"openstack-identity"` to
"`openstack.identity`".
  https://github.com/stackforge/cookbook-openstack-compute/blob/master/recipes/nova-common.rb#L80

Change-Id: Id097666992e7457623e344ad914a736bce6a2fe5

commit_message:
All tests should be using spec_helper

Not every test is utilizing spec_helper.  Clean up tests
so they are consistent with our other openstack tests.
Also, #require_relative allows you to load a file that
is relative to the file containing the #require_relative
statement.  We should update the remaining cookbook
tests to use this.

Change-Id: I4b48ce2f0589a9fcd9e699fe8a94c536ddb14ef6

commit_message:
Add a slave db handle for the SQLAlchemy backend.

Adds an option for a slave DB connection for scaling
purposes. Read queries can be sent here to spread out
db load a bit. This patch adds a new configuration option:
slave_connection.

Implements: blueprint db-slave-handle
Change-Id: I5cc5e0696e3fcd8609ee6b5466b0377ca52b8b58
DocImpact

commit_message:
Tests were not passing due to postgresql cookbook

Changes to the upstream postgresql cookbook broke tests.
Gemfile.lock was updated to bring in fauxhai 1.1.1 which
has these attributes mocked.

Also, Berksfile.lock shouldn't be checked in.  Removed from
this patch, since it impacts testing.

Change-Id: Ic33bd1121b1612ee415de9e51f649f3c9c0a9763

commit_message:
Fix unused imports(flake8 F401, F999)

- F401: imported but unused
- F999: syntax error in doctest

Fixing a couple of the F401's simply required fixing the doctests syntax
where the imports were actually in use.

Change-Id: If78abbb143daf8d005a71c5ab52836df29c5e0cd

commit_message:
Fix line continuations (flake8 E125, E126)

- E125: continuation line does not distinguish itself from next logical
  line
- E126: continuation line over-indented for hanging indent

Change-Id: I626a6d5d57db927e8b239f90569b5601c772f28b

commit_message:
Makes run_tests.sh exit code match the nosetests exit value.

This will simply make the script exit with the same exit value
given by the run_tests function, addressing bug #1185755.

Change-Id: Iac1a37169db4e29d845c77d87a2df1fa07b201e1
Fixes: bug #1185755

commit_message:
Merged 2 tests dependent on each other

One created metadata, the other deleted them. They would fail if they would get
ran in a different order or individually.

I also refactored them a bit to do this.

Change-Id: I21a8ab9f077e742eb40ea29fcea5e04f9d7dd043

messages:
[{'account_id': 7217, 'date': '2013-06-03 11:31:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-03 11:31:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 7217, 'date': '2013-06-03 11:42:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-06-03 11:42:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-03 11:44:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/31485/2/check/gate-python-openstackclient-pep8/375 : SUCCESS in 1m 01s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/31485/2/check/gate-python-openstackclient-docs/299/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 59s
- http://logs.openstack.org/31485/2/check/gate-python-openstackclient-python26/367 : SUCCESS in 1m 32s
- http://logs.openstack.org/31485/2/check/gate-python-openstackclient-python27/371 : SUCCESS in 1m 04s
'}, {'account_id': 7217, 'date': '2013-06-03 14:18:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

I'll WIP this for now as I have found a few other instances of required options, and it should probably be a wholesale change that can be accepted/rejected as a batch."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-06-03 15:11:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think we had size as a 'required' optional for a reason, I think it was to make things slightly easier for the user. I'm okay with it as a positional argument. 

I'll add dhellmann and dtroyer as reviewers, maybe they can remember why we had it as a required optional parameter, or give guidance for what it should be for the rest of the volume cases."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-06-03 15:25:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

This was quite intentional on my part, the goal being that there should be exactly one positional argument for commands.  This goal is not always reasonable as sane defaults are not always possible, hence the oxy-moronic 'required option'.  

The documented exception to this are add/remove commands which always have exactly two positional arguments, both nouns, to specify the objects in the relationship being formed or broken.

I do see that the wiki page (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/UnifiedCLI/Mapping) is not very clear on this goal."}, {'account_id': 7217, 'date': '2013-06-03 15:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Thanks for explaining that Dean. 

Change abandoned due to earlier design decision.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-03 11:30:04.000000000', 'message': "Make 'size' a positional argument for volume ceate.

At the moment it is a required-option, which is confusing.

Change-Id: I0e663a9eae15cc91617a25051c3620c865958212
"}, {'created': '2013-06-03 11:42:45.000000000', 'message': "Make 'size' a positional argument for volume create.

Currently it is a required option, which doesn't make much sense.

Change-Id: I0e663a9eae15cc91617a25051c3620c865958212
"}]
commit_message:
Make 'size' a positional argument for volume create.

Currently it is a required option, which doesn't make much sense.

Change-Id: I0e663a9eae15cc91617a25051c3620c865958212

Add requirements.txt to the source distribution

Also remove the tools directory, since it is no longer used, now that
https://review.openstack.org/30887 is merged, which renamed the
requirements files to requirements.txt and test-requirements.txt.

Change-Id: I3371e44ea00b7ba79b482379322c960df5e9621d
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
List Domains Test Case-V3

Adds a test script "test_domains.py" so as to test the list
domains functionality. And added required support functions
to identity_client.py of both v3/xml and v3/json interfaces.

Change-Id: I931be12bc2ea7a08b0272dfe145c13e195e69029
Implements: blueprint keystone-v3-domain-api-test

commit_message:
Don't use BaseException.message

This patch fixes the deprecation warning when testing under py26, and
gets us one step closer to Python 3 compatibility.

Change-Id: Ia6ac113a917eca075ef5abee937634bd4e488fa5

[{'created': '2013-05-24 15:39:06.000000000', 'message': 'python3: python3 binary/text data compatbility

Python3 enforces the distinction between byte strings
far more rigorously than Python 2 does; binary data
cannot be automatically coerced to or from text data.

Use six to provide a fake file object for textual data.
It provides an alias for StringIO.StringIO in python2
and io.StringIO in python3

Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
python3: python3 binary/text data compatbility

Python3 enforces the distinction between byte strings
far more rigorously than Python 2 does; binary data
cannot be automatically coerced to or from text data.

Use six to provide a fake file object for textual data.
It provides an alias for StringIO.StringIO in python2
and io.StringIO in python3

Change-Id: I65897bb0cca2cbeb5819a769b98645c9eb066401
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-02 22:27:35.000000000', 'message': 'Alternate refactor of info caching

This is just a reimplementation of the work David Hadas is doing at:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30481/

This rework was mainly just so I could get my head around what the
state of things were, what state we were trying to get them in, and
what was required to get it there. I felt some things were not quite
right with David's work, but I was at a loss to explain why.
Hopefully this will help when I re-review his work.

I'm mainly posting this up so other reviewers of David's work might
get a better view into things from a different perspective and
consider some of the ideas here as alternatives.

This is an area to tread lightly. The starting state of things is a
mess and the ending state should be cleaner, even if not "perfect".

Now, I do like this approach better (of course, I wrote it :P) but
let me state why:

* No all-in-one functions. I know this is what David wanted, but I
  disagree. I find the all-in-ones harder to read and easier to make
  mistakes with when in use elsewhere. Having them separate doesn't
  prevent making an all-in-one that calls the separate functions for
  convenience, but honestly, is a quick "if container:
  container_func() else: account_func()" that much harder to type or
  read?

* No "magic" HEADs that happen to set the cache values and, if they
  don't, blow things up. If I implement a stand-in proxy app, I
  wouldn't expect to have to feed a cache when implementing my HEAD
  functionality. With this approach, the caching stays in the caching
  functions and they fail gracefully.

* Account autocreation happens only within controllers/account.py
  Everyone else just indicates they're asking for account information
  in order to perform a pending write and the account is autocreated
  if configured to so.

I used comments liberally in this patch set to help a reviewer
understand what changed and why. A final patch set would be needed to
clear out these comments as they're mostly just noise after the fact,
though it should probably be a separate review/merge so that the
history isn't completely lost.

I was especially careful to alter the existing tests as little as
possible and to comment liberally again when I had to change things.
If this were to truly be a candidate for merging, new tests for the
new functions and functionality would need to be added.

One last note: We need to fix our test paths! Wow, talk about a lot
of screwy paths. All over the place we use paths like '/a/c' when we
should have used '/v1/a/c'. The tests happened to pass all this time
because so much relied on controller.account_name and .container_name
and not PATH_INFO. But we really need to fix these paths at some
point.

Change-Id: I60fd1d22956eab1a961deaf7444971d59325d4db
'}]
commit_message:
Alternate refactor of info caching

This is just a reimplementation of the work David Hadas is doing at:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30481/

This rework was mainly just so I could get my head around what the
state of things were, what state we were trying to get them in, and
what was required to get it there. I felt some things were not quite
right with David's work, but I was at a loss to explain why.
Hopefully this will help when I re-review his work.

I'm mainly posting this up so other reviewers of David's work might
get a better view into things from a different perspective and
consider some of the ideas here as alternatives.

This is an area to tread lightly. The starting state of things is a
mess and the ending state should be cleaner, even if not "perfect".

Now, I do like this approach better (of course, I wrote it :P) but
let me state why:

* No all-in-one functions. I know this is what David wanted, but I
  disagree. I find the all-in-ones harder to read and easier to make
  mistakes with when in use elsewhere. Having them separate doesn't
  prevent making an all-in-one that calls the separate functions for
  convenience, but honestly, is a quick "if container:
  container_func() else: account_func()" that much harder to type or
  read?

* No "magic" HEADs that happen to set the cache values and, if they
  don't, blow things up. If I implement a stand-in proxy app, I
  wouldn't expect to have to feed a cache when implementing my HEAD
  functionality. With this approach, the caching stays in the caching
  functions and they fail gracefully.

* Account autocreation happens only within controllers/account.py
  Everyone else just indicates they're asking for account information
  in order to perform a pending write and the account is autocreated
  if configured to so.

I used comments liberally in this patch set to help a reviewer
understand what changed and why. A final patch set would be needed to
clear out these comments as they're mostly just noise after the fact,
though it should probably be a separate review/merge so that the
history isn't completely lost.

I was especially careful to alter the existing tests as little as
possible and to comment liberally again when I had to change things.
If this were to truly be a candidate for merging, new tests for the
new functions and functionality would need to be added.

One last note: We need to fix our test paths! Wow, talk about a lot
of screwy paths. All over the place we use paths like '/a/c' when we
should have used '/v1/a/c'. The tests happened to pass all this time
because so much relied on controller.account_name and .container_name
and not PATH_INFO. But we really need to fix these paths at some
point.

Change-Id: I60fd1d22956eab1a961deaf7444971d59325d4db

commit_message:
Prevent Intermittent error by creating temp db files

Avoid creating "openstack/common/db/oslo.sqlite" in the source
directories by creating a temp db file for the test cases. This
also gets rid of intermittent test failures in local runs.

Fixes LP#: 1186320

Change-Id: I75111d635cf32e25c62887c1de053c102887b1b9

commit_message:
Improve database model.

* add username property to NodeGroup
* hide private_key in Cluster
* remote is now a property of Instance

Change-Id: Iddcd0a3d2a17d71649e4c5a7ddcfd439993c8130

commit_message:
Move glance image service client from nova and cinder into oslo.

This is now present in nova and cinder, and it's also needed in ironic,
so moving it into a common location.

List of new files and origin:

openstack/common/image/glance.py  => nova.image.glance <=> cincer.image.glance

openstack/common/exception.py => nova.exception <=> cinder.exception
    GlanceConnectionFailed
    ImageNotFound
    ImageNotAuthorized

tests/utils.py => nova.test <=> cinder.test
    flags

tests/unit/image/matchers.py => nova.tests.image
    DictKeysMismatch
    DictMismatch
    DictMatches

tests/unit/glance/stubs.py => nova.tests.glance
tests/unit/image/abs.tar.gz => nova.tests.image
tests/unit/image/rel.tar.gz => nova.tests.image
tests/unit/image/test_glance.py => nova.tests.image

Change-Id: Id025d5b28faa968aec326b7d8b68d75f9f47df91
Implements: blueprint image-tools

commit_message:
Modify primary key of routerl3agentbindings

Use router_id as primary key of routerl3agentbindings table instead
of id. Because in all l3 agents there should be only a single router
for a certain subnet.

Update pip-requires for alembic since create_primary_key is used by
this patch and it is added in version 0.5.0.

Fixes bug 1154622

Change-Id: Idc19868243dd420b03acce1cc0a7694495d1ec06

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-16 23:39:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This supersedes Idafec44d059cafd8b8862864b8b09efde2e38266

I think this new behaviour is what most people will expect. The only reason I didn't originally do it this way was because it's pretty tricky to get right

I'm still unhappy to be changing the semantics of the API in incompatible ways, but I think it's pretty unlikely anyone will be depending on the old behaviour and be broken by the new behaviour - more likely people will be blocked by the old behaviour and be glad to see the new behaviour"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-17 08:26:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Cool, code looks good, I just added a doc-nit comment.

What happens when no config-file is specified? Is it read before or after CLI args?

I still think we don't need this. I don't see the point of adding this kind of complexity and I personally don't think this is the behavior people would expect. For example, when testing a CLI I usually do:

  glance-api -d -v --config-file foo.conf

then I might want to change the config-file so I just delete the config file parameter and make it point somewhere else

  glance-api -d -v --config-file bar.conf

It's not about how many CLI params I'd have to delete but about the fact I expect -d -v to work regardless the order they're specified. You might argue saying that I could edit the config files but that's not something I should be forced to do if there are CLI args, IMHO.

Please, help me understand why we *really* need this, I might be missing something.

Cheers"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-17 10:27:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

When no --config-file is specified, the default config files get read before the CLI args - see _parse_cli_opts()

To repeat the use case I care about - if a systemd unit contains command line parameters, you need to allow the config file to override them.

Also, this behaviour gets us back to the behaviour we originally had in Nova with gflags.'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-17 11:00:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> When no --config-file is specified, the default config files get read before the CLI args - see _parse_cli_opts()

Cool, thanks!

> To repeat the use case I care about - if a systemd unit contains command line parameters, you need to allow the config file to override them.

In this case, why would the system unit specify the command line parameter instead of just using the config file?'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-05-20 14:18:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-05-20 14:18:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-20 21:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 21:18:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29459/2/check/gate-oslo.config-pep8/108 : SUCCESS in 29s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29459/2/check/gate-oslo.config-docs/108/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 34s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29459/2/check/gate-oslo.config-python26/108 : SUCCESS in 49s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29459/2/check/gate-oslo.config-python27/108 : SUCCESS in 34s
'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-05-21 02:19:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 7223, 'date': '2013-05-21 09:46:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Mark, can you explain your use case again about:
"To repeat the use case I care about - if a systemd unit contains command line parameters, you need to allow the config file to override them."
I don't understand this at all.

Any entity that passes params should expect those params to be respected.  If it wants to use the config file then it just wouldn't pass those params.
I'm not familiar with any linux utility that behaves in this way.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-22 05:44:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

You never want users to have to modify a systemd unit.If CLI options always have priority and you specify an option in the systemd unit, they have no alternative other than changing the unit file if they want to override that option.

The point about gflags is significant - this change in semantics can be thought of as a bugfix to restore Nova's original behaviour.

I also think the semantics are perfectly clear, offer great flexibility and have a sensible default behaviour."}, {'account_id': 7223, 'date': '2013-05-22 10:37:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The simple solution to not having to modify unit files is to not specify arguments there, only in the config file.
The expected behaviour for any utility in linux is that cli arguments take precedence.

Wrt semantics I think the bug proves that it this behaviour is not expected and confusing (e.g. https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1175570)

IMO, the whole point of CLI args when you already have a conf file is to be able to temporarily override the 'static' behaviour."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-22 10:54:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This change will fix bug #1175570'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-22 16:55:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-23 21:02:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-24 06:21:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

cool. just one suggestion but lgtm'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-24 12:37:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-24 12:38:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 23:31:52.000000000', 'message': "Fix the priority of CLI args vs config file values

Fixes bug #1176817

The API enforces a special requirement for CLI options - they must be
registered before the command line is parsed.

This means that as we parse the command line - and parse config files
specified on the command line - we can fully process CLI options whether
we find values for them on the command line or in config files.

This allows us to fundamentally change how we reconcile values specified
on the CLI with values specified in config files. No longer do we have
to first look at the set of values found on the command line and then
look at the values found in config files. Instead, we can treat all
values for CLI options as if they were found on the command line, even
if they were actually found in config files.

The long and short of this is that if you do:

  --config-file foo.conf --blaa --config-file bar.conf

then '--blaa' will override any value for the 'blaa' option in foo.conf
but we can also override the 'blaa' value on the command line from
within bar.conf.

Change-Id: I0a584a3c26ddadf24e3f473c773ee34a914667b3
"}, {'created': '2013-05-20 21:17:27.000000000', 'message': "Fix the priority of CLI args vs config file values

commit_message:
Fix the priority of CLI args vs config file values

Fixes bug #1176817

The API enforces a special requirement for CLI options - they must be
registered before the command line is parsed.

This means that as we parse the command line - and parse config files
specified on the command line - we can fully process CLI options whether
we find values for them on the command line or in config files.

This allows us to fundamentally change how we reconcile values specified
on the CLI with values specified in config files. No longer do we have
to first look at the set of values found on the command line and then
look at the values found in config files. Instead, we can treat all
values for CLI options as if they were found on the command line, even
if they were actually found in config files.

The long and short of this is that if you do:

  --config-file foo.conf --blaa --config-file bar.conf

then '--blaa' will override any value for the 'blaa' option in foo.conf
but we can also override the 'blaa' value on the command line from
within bar.conf.

Change-Id: I0a584a3c26ddadf24e3f473c773ee34a914667b3

commit_message:
Make reference lbaas implementation as a pluggable driver

implements blueprint multi-vendor-support-for-lbaas

Split current lbaas plugin in two parts: generic plugin and
plugin driver. Plugin driver is responsible for additional
tasks such as: communicating with the agent, receiving specific
callbacks, communicating with external vendor-specific components.
Note that plugin driver is not a device driver and it's main goal
is to provide flexibility in choosing lbaas architecture.

Change-Id: Ib4bfe286826acde51755b96f4713448c073378d2

commit_message:
Switch to openstack.common.apiclient

openstack.common.apiclient can be used in novaclient,
keystoneclient, glanceclient, and other client projects.
The library contains common code and uses python-requests
for HTTP communication.

Features:
* auth_plugins
* secrets_helper to use keyring and get password from a tty
* rich exceptions hierarchy

Partially implements: blueprint common-client-library

Change-Id: I2fac9f6e62670611686306d3ae30aa4e45a6cf81

[{'created': '2013-06-03 02:03:42.000000000', 'message': "Add rollback for Cisco plugin update_port failure

Fixes bug 1174433

This fix adds a rollback of the OVS plugin update_port operation
following a failure to update the port in the Cisco Nexus sub-plugin.

Also, this fix removes an unneccessary call to the Nexus sub-plugin's
update_network method within the Cisco plugin model layer's
update_network method (as well as the associated argument setup).
The Nexus sub-plugin's update_network is a no-op, so there's no

commit_message:
Add rollback for Cisco plugin update_port failure

Fixes bug 1174433

This fix adds a rollback of the OVS plugin update_port operation
following a failure to update the port in the Cisco Nexus sub-plugin.

Also, this fix removes an unneccessary call to the Nexus sub-plugin's
update_network method within the Cisco plugin model layer's
update_network method (as well as the associated argument setup).
The Nexus sub-plugin's update_network is a no-op, so there's no
need to call it.

Change-Id: I10cba0d7f1d632c7f77eb6c4a94ea82b958bc6a2

Start to use Hacking

Instead of ignoring all Hacking warnings, blacklist
those that need lots of changes and fix the easy one.

[{'created': '2013-05-23 01:24:51.000000000', 'message': "Install nodejs for RHEL/Fedora

nodejs is required for Horizon (ships a copy of lessc internally).  I
couldn't find nodejs in the rpm list, despite it being installed in
lib/horizon.  This adds to the rpm list as NOPRIME and retains the old
install point.

RHEL6 has nodejs in EPEL now, so we remove the old hack that installed
an upstream version and add it to the install mentioned previously

Change-Id: Ib3ee2f7d77e22666c9055c8528288c01b46a95d3
"}, {'created': '2013-05-23 01:24:51.000000000', 'message': "Install nodejs for RHEL/Fedora

nodejs is required for Horizon (ships a copy of lessc internally).  I
couldn't find nodejs in the rpm list, despite it being installed in
lib/horizon.  This adds to the rpm list as NOPRIME and retains the old
install point.

RHEL6 has nodejs in EPEL now, so we remove the old hack that installed
an upstream version and add it to the install mentioned previously

Change-Id: Ib3ee2f7d77e22666c9055c8528288c01b46a95d3
"}]
commit_message:
Install nodejs for RHEL/Fedora

nodejs is required for Horizon (ships a copy of lessc internally).  I
couldn't find nodejs in the rpm list, despite it being installed in
lib/horizon.  This adds to the rpm list as NOPRIME and retains the old
install point.

RHEL6 has nodejs in EPEL now, so we remove the old hack that installed
an upstream version and add it to the install mentioned previously

Change-Id: Ib3ee2f7d77e22666c9055c8528288c01b46a95d3

use [database]connection setting from openstack.common sqlalchemy session

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-28 14:57:21.000000000', 'message': "In utils.tempdir, pass CONF.tempdir as an argument.

It's ugly, and potentially racy, to mess around with other modules'
global variables.  Instead, pass CONF.tempdir into tempfile.mkdtemp
as the 'dir' keyword argument.

Because we already pass **kwargs to mkdtemp, inspect **kwargs and
only set 'dir' if it's not already there.

Change-Id: I8a2b34cd051919db29facabc1664cf357073b1d7
"}]
commit_message:
In utils.tempdir, pass CONF.tempdir as an argument.

It's ugly, and potentially racy, to mess around with other modules'
global variables.  Instead, pass CONF.tempdir into tempfile.mkdtemp
as the 'dir' keyword argument.

Because we already pass **kwargs to mkdtemp, inspect **kwargs and
only set 'dir' if it's not already there.

Change-Id: I8a2b34cd051919db29facabc1664cf357073b1d7

commit_message:
Fixes text split for parameters

Make text split only on the first "=" element, this will
allow for values to have multiple "=" in the string.
Also, ensure that key = value pair is honored in parameters,
exit otherwise with error message. Tests included.
Fixes bug #1183842

Change-Id: Ic8897405c61dee49f5927b53f055b0d0686eea7d

Given that resource creation can happen in parallel, the call to
check_create_complete may not follow the call to handle_create, so mock
those without checking the order.

Change-Id: Icf40f7339dc4c6e885c4a42f3a2c3f546f14c08d
'}]
commit_message:
Fix an intermitting failure in test_metadata_refresh

Given that resource creation can happen in parallel, the call to
check_create_complete may not follow the call to handle_create, so mock
those without checking the order.

commit_message:
Update run_tests and bring back colorizer.

This patch adds output of tests and their results to run_tests.sh.
It also brings back colorizer to the output and updates the test-requirements.

Should align with cinder changes that are in progress
at: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30291/

Change-Id: I3df6d861f4b4d4355464ceb2d507e69bcf682fbe

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-28 20:35:27.000000000', 'message': "rbd: simplify configuration and use librbd and librados

Add an rbd_ceph_conf options to mirror glance configuration, and use
the existing rbd_user option to choose how to connect to the cluster
instead of relying on an environment variable.  Use these settings
when running command line programs and when connecting via librados.

Use absolute imports so that importing the python librbd bindings
via 'import rbd' does not try to import cinder.drivers.rbd again.

Create some convenience wrappers to simplify librbd and librados
error handling and cleanup. Using these everywhere also simplifies
testing. Mock out all the librados and librbd calls in the tests
so these libraries don't need to be installed.

Remove the local_path() method since it's never used. It was
left over from nova-volume.

There are only three things still relying on the command line:
- importing an image
- exporting to an image
- getting monitor addresses

Importing and exporting on the command line include zero-detection
that would be little benefit to replicate here. librados and librbd
don't have a simple interface to obtain the monitor addresses, so
leave that to a command line tool as well.

Fixes: bug 1083540
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

Change-Id: I32d059c5e460c2dd8423119b3dbe4a9921f5e907

commit_message:
rbd: simplify configuration and use librbd and librados

Add an rbd_ceph_conf options to mirror glance configuration, and use
the existing rbd_user option to choose how to connect to the cluster
instead of relying on an environment variable.  Use these settings
when running command line programs and when connecting via librados.

Use absolute imports so that importing the python librbd bindings
via 'import rbd' does not try to import cinder.drivers.rbd again.

Create some convenience wrappers to simplify librbd and librados
error handling and cleanup. Using these everywhere also simplifies
testing. Mock out all the librados and librbd calls in the tests
so these libraries don't need to be installed.

Remove the local_path() method since it's never used. It was
left over from nova-volume.

There are only three things still relying on the command line:
- importing an image
- exporting to an image
- getting monitor addresses

Importing and exporting on the command line include zero-detection
that would be little benefit to replicate here. librados and librbd
don't have a simple interface to obtain the monitor addresses, so
leave that to a command line tool as well.

Fixes: bug 1083540
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

Change-Id: I32d059c5e460c2dd8423119b3dbe4a9921f5e907

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 10:46:00.000000000', 'message': "Add error reporting to tools/conf/generate_sample.sh on import failure.

Currently tools/conf/generate_sample.sh collect options from project modules
by importing each module and looking at it's global variables for instances
of classes derived from cfg.Opt (or lists of such instances). Sometimes
this import can fail due to various reasons, cfg.DuplicateOptError for
example. And if import fails no options from imported module written to
sample config file. Error reporting will at least warn user that some of
options didn't get into sample config.

Change-Id: I831464b1c1575c106d866a936a50ec74b2d44e59
Fixes: bug #1182611
"}, {'created': '2013-05-31 10:56:14.000000000', 'message': "Add error reporting to generate_sample.sh on import failure.

Currently tools/conf/generate_sample.sh collect options from project
modules by importing each module and looking at it's global variables
for instances of classes derived from cfg.Opt (or lists of such
instances). Sometimes this import can fail due to various reasons,
cfg.DuplicateOptError for example. And if import fails no options
from imported module written to sample config file. Error reporting
will at least warn user that some of options didn't get into sample
config.

Change-Id: I831464b1c1575c106d866a936a50ec74b2d44e59
Fixes: bug #1182611
"}]
commit_message:
Add error reporting to generate_sample.sh on import failure.

Currently tools/conf/generate_sample.sh collect options from project
modules by importing each module and looking at it's global variables
for instances of classes derived from cfg.Opt (or lists of such
instances). Sometimes this import can fail due to various reasons,
cfg.DuplicateOptError for example. And if import fails no options
from imported module written to sample config file. Error reporting
will at least warn user that some of options didn't get into sample
config.

Change-Id: I831464b1c1575c106d866a936a50ec74b2d44e59
Fixes: bug #1182611

commit_message:
Fix tests to redirect stdout

Add default TestCase that uses fixtures to save stdout and stderr (based
off nova/test.py).  save stdout and stderr by default but overrideable in
order to run pdb.

Also use fixtures.Timeout

Change-Id: Iece6a96e5e54e252df943934ea465db78e1c5421

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 19:09:06.000000000', 'message': 'Update 3PAR driver session management

The 3PAR REST API server has a limited number of active sessions.
This change to the driver removes the ability of keeping the
REST API session alive for the life of the driver.  Now on every
driver entry point, which is synchronized, we login to the 3PAR
and when the work is complete, we log out of the 3PAR.  This has
the side affect of more overhead to the 3PAR but helps eliminate
failed commands due to maximum sessions reached to the 3PAR.

This patch also changes the locking to be the same lock for all
driver entry points and adds locking around the volume stats.
This patch also migrates all of the client code access to the common
class, which simplifies the drivers.

Change-Id: Ibcec4cf1781262521ccbdf99c4ba4167634a09c4
'}]
commit_message:
Update 3PAR driver session management

The 3PAR REST API server has a limited number of active sessions.
This change to the driver removes the ability of keeping the
REST API session alive for the life of the driver.  Now on every
driver entry point, which is synchronized, we login to the 3PAR
and when the work is complete, we log out of the 3PAR.  This has
the side affect of more overhead to the 3PAR but helps eliminate
failed commands due to maximum sessions reached to the 3PAR.

This patch also changes the locking to be the same lock for all
driver entry points and adds locking around the volume stats.
This patch also migrates all of the client code access to the common
class, which simplifies the drivers.

Change-Id: Ibcec4cf1781262521ccbdf99c4ba4167634a09c4

[{'created': '2013-06-02 10:11:52.000000000', 'message': 'Modify primary key of routerl3agentbindings

Use router_id as primary key of routerl3agentbindings table instead
of id. Because in all l3 agents there should be only a single router
for a certain subnet.

Update pip-requires for alembic since create_primary_key is used by
this patch and it is added in version 0.5.0.

Fixes bug 1154622

Change-Id: I7ecc54d3eb4adad3e9bd6ffb030966444d7ce1aa
'}]
commit_message:
Modify primary key of routerl3agentbindings

Use router_id as primary key of routerl3agentbindings table instead
of id. Because in all l3 agents there should be only a single router
for a certain subnet.

Update pip-requires for alembic since create_primary_key is used by
this patch and it is added in version 0.5.0.

Fixes bug 1154622

Change-Id: I7ecc54d3eb4adad3e9bd6ffb030966444d7ce1aa

[{'created': '2013-05-25 11:24:43.000000000', 'message': 'help for command keystone user-create is changed.

corresponding user-create testcases have been modified.
The syntax will now change for the command keystone user-create as below:

usage: keystone user-create [--tenant-id <tenant-id>] [--pass <pass>]
                            [--email <email>] [--enabled <true|false>]
                            <user-name>

Create new user

Positional arguments:
  <user-name>           New user name (must be unique)

Optional arguments:
  --tenant-id <tenant-id>
                        New user default tenant
  --pass <pass>         New user password
  --email <email>       New user email address
  --enabled <true|false>
                        Initial user enabled status (default true)

Now username will be shown as mandatory.

Fixes bug#1182130

Change-Id: If41bf912a879c860d40c1e4357590cfbd0fdd117
'}]
commit_message:
help for command keystone user-create is changed.

corresponding user-create testcases have been modified.
The syntax will now change for the command keystone user-create as below:

usage: keystone user-create [--tenant-id <tenant-id>] [--pass <pass>]
                            [--email <email>] [--enabled <true|false>]
                            <user-name>

Create new user

Positional arguments:
  <user-name>           New user name (must be unique)

Optional arguments:
  --tenant-id <tenant-id>
                        New user default tenant
  --pass <pass>         New user password
  --email <email>       New user email address
  --enabled <true|false>
                        Initial user enabled status (default true)

Now username will be shown as mandatory.

Fixes bug#1182130

Change-Id: If41bf912a879c860d40c1e4357590cfbd0fdd117

commit_message:
xenapi - quantum: L2 agents for dom0 and domU

This patch makes it easier to support the all-in-one installation of
XenServer with Quantum:
- separate agents for domU and dom0 openvswitches. The domU agent's name
  is "q-domua", and the dom0 agent is called "q-agt"
- create a physnet1 physical network to connect those openvswitches

Note: This patch depends on the quantum patch:

    https://review.openstack.org/15022

For a diagram, see:
    http://goo.gl/BuAdg

Change-Id: Iff851438553528b9051edd380ecbb2c0415cbf78

commit_message:
Functions are required to parse localrc

This is essentially a revert of
73695d0ea490c4c7a1158957dd5a85586cfa0933. Since stackrc is
responsible for sourcing localrc, the required functions
are necessary (like for enable_service).

fixes bug 1186488

Change-Id: Iad90f802e77b94416821008c294c1a2ede8a4729

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 22:59:09.000000000', 'message': "Silence exceptions from qpid connection.close()

Fixes bug 1185465

Don't log exceptions that happen during connection.close().  They're
not surprising (a closed socket can't be read or written), don't
require sysadmin attention, and provide red herrings in the logs
to distract from finding real root causes of problems.

Change-Id: Ie414ba3f4ff1f1dee13e6168ac2e28dab535581b
"}]
commit_message:
Silence exceptions from qpid connection.close()

Fixes bug 1185465

Don't log exceptions that happen during connection.close().  They're
not surprising (a closed socket can't be read or written), don't
require sysadmin attention, and provide red herrings in the logs
to distract from finding real root causes of problems.

Change-Id: Ie414ba3f4ff1f1dee13e6168ac2e28dab535581b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 08:56:39.000000000', 'message': 'Don't restrict is_public on client side but leave authentication to server

The patch is to fix:
  I have a non-public flavor.
  Name = my
  ID = 84d6ed4a-849b-4d66-837e-e2e853a383e3

  Running
  nova flavor-access-list --flavor 84d6ed4a-849b-4d66-837e-e2e853a383e3
  can get results.

  However, running
  nova flavor-access-list --flavor my
  says "ERROR: No flavor with a name or ID of 'my' exists."

Ditto to run
"nova flavor-access-add 84d6ed4a-849b-4d66-837e-e2e853a383e3 1"
and "nova flavor-access-add my 1". I think the behaviours should be the
same. So to allow is_public on the client side. The server will verify
whether some flavors can't be accessed if not.

Change-Id: Ifb56cbec0eab25e0af75412e7505ae78488a813a
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-05-23 13:45:15.000000000', 'message': 'Don't restrict is_public on client side but leave decision making to server

The patch is to fix:
  I have a private (is_public = False) flavor.
  Name = my
  ID = 84d6ed4a-849b-4d66-837e-e2e853a383e3

  Running
  nova flavor-access-list --flavor 84d6ed4a-849b-4d66-837e-e2e853a383e3
  can get results.

  However, running
  nova flavor-access-list --flavor my
  says "ERROR: No flavor with a name or ID of 'my' exists."

Ditto to run
"nova flavor-access-add 84d6ed4a-849b-4d66-837e-e2e853a383e3 1"
and "nova flavor-access-add my 1". I think the behaviours should be the
same, otherwise, it doesn't make any sense. So skip is_public on client side.
The server decides whether some flavors can't be accessed if not.

Change-Id: Ifb56cbec0eab25e0af75412e7505ae78488a813a
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Don't restrict is_public on client side but leave decision making to server

The patch is to fix:
  I have a private (is_public = False) flavor.
  Name = my
  ID = 84d6ed4a-849b-4d66-837e-e2e853a383e3

  Running
  nova flavor-access-list --flavor 84d6ed4a-849b-4d66-837e-e2e853a383e3
  can get results.

  However, running
  nova flavor-access-list --flavor my
  says "ERROR: No flavor with a name or ID of 'my' exists."

Ditto to run
"nova flavor-access-add 84d6ed4a-849b-4d66-837e-e2e853a383e3 1"
and "nova flavor-access-add my 1". I think the behaviours should be the
same, otherwise, it doesn't make any sense. So skip is_public on client side.
The server decides whether some flavors can't be accessed if not.

Change-Id: Ifb56cbec0eab25e0af75412e7505ae78488a813a
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>

[{'created': '2013-05-23 01:58:35.000000000', 'message': 'Require keystoneclient in pip-requires.

python-keystoneclient was in test-requires. Move it to pip-requires as
keystone auth v2 requires keystoneclient.

Change-Id: Ifb988f7c74a27283cf3d2210c7644f04d03bd94c
'}]
commit_message:
Require keystoneclient in pip-requires.

python-keystoneclient was in test-requires. Move it to pip-requires as
keystone auth v2 requires keystoneclient.

Change-Id: Ifb988f7c74a27283cf3d2210c7644f04d03bd94c

commit_message:
Adds v3 API disable config option

Adds the ability to disable the v3 API and it is disabled by
default for now. The API is explictly enabled when running the
unittests though.

Change-Id: I34597d35b9739e06561579651f7ec72afa357919

(1 inline comment)

I'd also like to see at least a test for each of list_databases and list_access. Fake mode should be easy enough--we can modify the fake user list and add bogus database entries to them easily enough, it's all dictionaries."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work
