'}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not merge

Will approve when the removal of validation occurs within Reddwarf as well as the reference guest.'}, {'account_id': 1375, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/ubuntu/reddwarf-integration/scripts/../tests//integration/int_tests.py", line 174, in <module>
    from reddwarf.tests.config import CONFIG
ImportError: No module named reddwarf.tests.config

in case you're wondering about Jenkins


I still want some tests for this'}, {'account_id': 1375, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

You're right about fake-mode tests being meaningless with the code as you've implemented it.
For some reason I thought the validation overrides you added here were happening in reddwarf service or models and not in the guest agent.
Guess it won't be as easy as adding a fake-mode test to cover the changes in the guest agent itself.

The changes to the guest agent here won't matter, though, unless you also make changes to the reddwarf service and models:
  https://github.com/stackforge/reddwarf/blob/master/reddwarf/extensions/mysql/models.py#L300
  https://github.com/stackforge/reddwarf/blob/master/reddwarf/extensions/mysql/service.py#L264
to name two places.
There are also the User Access calls that use the names of databases both as input and output.

For output, it makes sense that we can't call databases that exist but aren't named the way we like as invalid.

For input, though, we can't just stop scrubbing input altogether.
That can lead to problems of its own.
Maybe we should discuss more thoroughly how to treat a request that's otherwise valid but names an extant database that has an invalid name.

Those changes to the service and models, by the way, could be tested in fake mode as the fake guestagent doesn't do any input validation of its own anyway
In fact, it doesn't even use the guestagent models at all.


I wonder if maybe the whole approach in this changeset should be rethought.
Maybe we simply need to change our validation to closer match what MySQL (or whatever implementation is in use on the instance) does, so we can avoid strange cases like this?
That question's not just for you and me to discuss, though.
I'll bring it up at tomorrow's meeting."}, {'account_id': 1375, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

You'll need to remove it both in the guest agent and the API, because they both make user of the guestagent models for validation."}, {'account_id': 4240, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

BTW @ed-cranford you forgot to bring this up i think in the meeting."}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Ed,

For the list_database and list_access tests, I looked at what you suggested. Ie, adding the bogus DB in the guest_agent fake mode.

But i am not sure how that would test the code that was added. If i am not mistaken, the guest agent fake mode fakes out the guest agent API. So if we do this, the code in the mysql.py would not even run.

Let me know if im confused.'}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Is there a reason why we validate during output? Im thinking of just removing this check during output. Validating during input should be enough i think. And that validation logic should be similar to the one mysql does as you said. So that it is done in the service layer and not in the guest agent.'}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Tim,

Just to be clear, so you will like to remove the validation from the guest and move it to the reddwarf service layer?

How about input and output? Do we validate only during input? Or output as well?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28850/3/check/gate-reddwarf-pep8/694 : SUCCESS in 2m 34s
- http://logs.openstack.org/28850/3/check/gate-reddwarf-python26/678 : SUCCESS in 3m 26s
- http://logs.openstack.org/28850/3/check/gate-reddwarf-python27/679 : SUCCESS in 3m 07s
'}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 4240, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I believe the best idea is to validate in the service that fields exist in the json/xml schema. But no the validation of configurable names that the backend system should accept or not. 

The main reason to handle it this way is because it should be abstracted away from the service for other backend systems like postgres or any other sql. Also keeping in mind like Tim said a manage-cli tool."}, {'account_id': 5390, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
Use database name validation only on listing and loading of databases

* We don't need to validate the database names in the
  response of a 'list_databases' call, since they may have been
  created via the root_enabled backdoor

fixes bug 1178089

Change-Id: I2f74e63cfd8b78feec9c38b5fec75138245a7f64

'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-05-16 22:05:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

In order to make it work I had to:

a) Replace my nova/openstack/common/processutils.py with the one from this change.
b) install this version of oslo-incubator on the system
c) add the ability for nova to run oslo-rootwrap in the sudoers file.

Once I did those steps, it did in fact work right.

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-22 15:10:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The rootwrap_config option is already being defined in some of the other projects. Is this version meant to take the place of those definitions?'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-05-31 13:06:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This bug no longer exists in *-rpc-zmq-receiver as ZeroMQ no longer relies on processutils / rootwrap.

If this patch is otherwise useful, you should change the commit message."}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-05-31 23:29:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 18:43:10.000000000', 'message': "Fix NoRootWrapSpecified when running nova-rpc-zmq-receiver

We need a rootwrap_config in oslo's processutils as well to
cover calls initiated from oslo code.

Fixes LP# 1180631

Change-Id: I66c6daa091b89e313abffe67f6fb07e380ce2d1c
"}]
commit_message:
Fix NoRootWrapSpecified when running nova-rpc-zmq-receiver

We need a rootwrap_config in oslo's processutils as well to
cover calls initiated from oslo code.

Fixes LP# 1180631

Change-Id: I66c6daa091b89e313abffe67f6fb07e380ce2d1c

commit_message:
Add qpid-python to test-requires

The qpid notification tests are not run if the qpid-python package
is not installed.  This change adds it to the test-requires list
and removes the check for it since it should always be present.

Fixes bug 1173380

Change-Id: I2763e320e6018fde196c903f515920ad33f28aa6

commit_message:
Live SQL migration tests

Make it possible to run the migration tests for the supported databases
without editing the config files.

Blueprint live-sql-gate

Change-Id: Iaf14ad42333b0a0cd1f7d0fb37f135a8bf7af14a

commit_message:
Add ssh check to quantum smoke test.

 * Doing a ping check to verify that a vm is reachable may result
   in a false positive if the target ip is routed in error to a
   nonetheless pingable host.  This patch adds an ssh check that will
   fail if the target is not configured with the expected (and
   dynamically generated) ssh keypair.
 * Adding the ssh check uncovered a bug in security group creation -
   source group rules were being used that restricted traffic to
   ports associated with the security group.  This is now fixed.
 * Addresses bug 1182343

Change-Id: I4112ad9a8854fc113d5fefc7ea03a55da7d0ed1b

[{'created': '2013-05-31 05:51:32.000000000', 'message': "Fix incorrect role assignment in migration.

In the case where a user has existing roles on a project running the
migration would assign those same roles to all the user's projects.

Change-Id: Ibd99bb7cf6cb84b577eca57f903abf9d48e908c1
Fixes: bug 1186128
"}]
commit_message:
Fix incorrect role assignment in migration.

In the case where a user has existing roles on a project running the
migration would assign those same roles to all the user's projects.

Change-Id: Ibd99bb7cf6cb84b577eca57f903abf9d48e908c1
Fixes: bug 1186128

I think I buy Rick's argument"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-29 22:07:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This needs a rebase, also I would like to hear back from Monty  about his comment and your response.  The internals of flake8/pep8 can be a little magical, as he wrote this piece I am deferring to him.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-05-29 23:04:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Joe: Thanks, rebased.

Would love to hear back from Monty on this well.

In the mean time, you can verify this yourself in any number of ways, but the way I went about it was just sticking a `raise Exception('got here')` and then running flake8 with and without the `__init__` defined. In both cases, the exception was raised.

This makes sense, there's nothing magical about redefining an __init__ versus inheriting it. It just matters what the func-args are since pep8 is doing that funky introspection."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2013-05-30 14:28:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Ok. I'm sold."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 14:30:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

commit_message:
Style-fixes to hacking/core.py

Makes a few small style-cleanups:

    * Removes need for duplicated empty __init__ methods
    * Changes `return(` to `return (`
    * Turns `_has_run_registry` from a global dict to a class-scoped set
    * Moves GIT_REGEX to the class that uses it

Change-Id: I3b15b74fe5006461edf3a28c62674ba152a07249

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 21:38:44.000000000', 'message': 'Sphinx-ify QuantumPluginBaseV2 docstrings

The quantum.quantum_plugin_base_v2 module had some good docstrings,
but there was no corresponding sphinx code that would generate
docs from them. There were also some syntax issues with the
sphinx markup in the docstrings.

This change adds sphinx directives so these docs will be auto-
generated. It also modifies the docstrings in the QuantumPluginBaseV2
methods so they are parsed by the Sphinx documentation generator
without any errors.

If this patch is accepted, a "Plugin API" link to these docs
will appear at

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/quantum/

Change-Id: I96eddcc516d109766d7f4c52edd595748696b595

commit_message:
Sphinx-ify QuantumPluginBaseV2 docstrings

The quantum.quantum_plugin_base_v2 module had some good docstrings,
but there was no corresponding sphinx code that would generate
docs from them. There were also some syntax issues with the
sphinx markup in the docstrings.

This change adds sphinx directives so these docs will be auto-
generated. It also modifies the docstrings in the QuantumPluginBaseV2
methods so they are parsed by the Sphinx documentation generator
without any errors.

If this patch is accepted, a "Plugin API" link to these docs
will appear at

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/quantum/

Fixes bug 1186255

Change-Id: I96eddcc516d109766d7f4c52edd595748696b595

commit_message:
Migrate to Oslo DB code

 - engine and session handling code is reused
 - integrity errors caused by duplicating entries
   are handled properly
 - the base class for models is mostly reused
   (the only exception is SoftDeleteMixin, which
    requires changes to existing DB schema; this
    will be implemented in BP db-unique-keys)
 - use common exceptions handling code

Blueprint: db-session-cleanup

Change-Id: I7f5eb53daddc57066af9c73caa633b37a2afd9c2

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names.

Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Change-Id: Ib3e50a811868e2969923d978ee00c4f92682aa1c
Fixes: bug #1179008

subject: Implement minimum basic scenario
messages:
[{'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-07 21:06:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-07 23:05:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-08 01:39:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-05-08 06:55:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

What is your opinion about adding some additional steps:
* adding a floating ip
* Rebooting the machine
* ssh into the machine and checking is the attached disk is there (/proc/partitions)'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-08 07:27:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Hi, afazekas.
Thank you for your comment.

I agree with your suggestion.
I think these steps are suitable for this testing. I will add them in the next patch set.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-05-08 09:31:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-08 12:07:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

please propose a blueprint timeline, I was surprised to see a blueprint that wasn't proposed for havana. See thread on openstack-qa list.

I don't think these tests should wrap the CLI, they should use the python client libraries directly. The CLI isn't a guarunteed interface, and going from python -> shell -> python is just extra places for breaks."}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-09 03:18:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Hi, Sean.
Thank you for your review and comment.

I have set my blueprint havana-1 a little while ago.

The reasons why I chose the CLI are:
 * The CLI is popular for users.
 * It's easy to understand the test code will do.
 * I feel Tempest should find out the CLI compatibility problem.
   Because some CLI test cases have been implemented in tempest/cli directory.
   So I think these scenario test cases may use the CLI.

Do you think the testing with the CLI should do in tempest/cli directory only?"}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-05-09 12:36:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

IMO, the only place in tempest where the CLI should be used is for tests of the CLI itself. There is a policy on stability of OpenStack REST apis at https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Governance/Approved/APIStability. I think the stability policy for the cli and python client libraries needs to be clarified and uniform across projects."}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-10 09:14:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Hi, David.
Thank you for your review and comment.

OK, I got it. I'll use the python client libraries directly in the next patch."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-18 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-18 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-23 06:51:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Restored'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-23 06:52:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-23 06:55:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Work In Progress

There are some TODOs:
  * adding a floating ip
  * testing for nova-network'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 07:43:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Doesn't seem to work

- http://logs.openstack.org/26403/8/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum-full/1582 : FAILURE in 38m 46s (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-23 10:41:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-23 11:32:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I like the flow of this, however I think we should have this test be able to run without admin credentials (so drop the flavor create).

Having another admin scenario test would be useful and relevant, but we should have a scenario that's a normal user flow without requiring admin (which this almost is)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 11:39:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Doesn't seem to work

OK. I will separate the scenario and drop the flavor create in the next patch.'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-24 01:57:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-24 02:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Yes, you should wait properly.

Consider using the 
TestCase.status_timeout.

The wait function little bit chaotic, now If you really need invent a new wait function.
Hopefully someone will unifies them anyway."}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2013-05-24 06:35:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

I'll use the TestCase.status_timeout in the next patch.

However, I think this test should be a normal user flow. So I feel I should drop the keystone test cases."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-05-24 08:38:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 19:36:33.000000000', 'message': 'scheduler: Fix inifinite loop for no-wait tasks

When a task run by a DependencyTaskGroup completed immediately (i.e. it
was marked as done right after calling start()), the corresponding entry in
the dependency graph was never removed. As a result the DependencyTaskGroup
would continue running forever (or until it timed out).

Fixes bug #1186389

Change-Id: I9715b54a61d1c3adc22403bc39f8673306bffead
'}]
commit_message:
scheduler: Fix inifinite loop for no-wait tasks

When a task run by a DependencyTaskGroup completed immediately (i.e. it
was marked as done right after calling start()), the corresponding entry in
the dependency graph was never removed. As a result the DependencyTaskGroup
would continue running forever (or until it timed out).

Fixes bug #1186389

Change-Id: I9715b54a61d1c3adc22403bc39f8673306bffead

commit_message:
libvirt: Tolerate existing vm(s) with cdrom(s)

When there is an existing vm with cdrom (not started by Nova), we
should tolerate missing file attribute (just skip those)

Fixes LP# 1144756

Change-Id: I43d45872e2d7348801b2e54cd43651609676f372
(cherry picked from commit cb369dab7184e72f24e70554828a7c4ca754d268)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 00:35:02.000000000', 'message': "Mock SysLogHandler for proxy/test_server.py

Our tests get rather grabby with file descriptors, mostly due to the
SysLogHandler. In recent work I'm doing, my additional tests put
things just over the 1024 limit and tests would start to fail
somewhat randomly. This alleviates the problem by mocking out one of
the bigger users of SysLogHandler, proxy/test_server.py. If you want
to verify this has an impact, you can put the following in your
proxy/test_server.py's overall teardown method and try it with and
without the mocking:

    import subprocess
    print >>sys.stderr, '%s OPEN FILES' % len(subprocess.Popen(
        ['lsof'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE).communicate()[0].split('\n'))

Change-Id: I1bd3efe46ee69d09a32c5a964f04e36e46506446
"}]
commit_message:
Mock SysLogHandler for proxy/test_server.py

Our tests get rather grabby with file descriptors, mostly due to the
SysLogHandler. In recent work I'm doing, my additional tests put
things just over the 1024 limit and tests would start to fail
somewhat randomly. This alleviates the problem by mocking out one of
the bigger users of SysLogHandler, proxy/test_server.py. If you want
to verify this has an impact, you can put the following in your
proxy/test_server.py's overall teardown method and try it with and
without the mocking:

    import subprocess
    print >>sys.stderr, '%s OPEN FILES' % len(subprocess.Popen(
        ['lsof'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE).communicate()[0].split('\n'))

Change-Id: I1bd3efe46ee69d09a32c5a964f04e36e46506446

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names.

Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Change-Id: I9c1356f22f6527be44b4b3f6a77012156ff1637b
Fixes: bug #1179008

talked with morgan on irc, sounds like this should probably be target at grizzly backports and we'll look into replacing the revocation of things with not-a-list"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-05-01 00:56:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

termie, Here's my understanding of the approach you are recommending.  Assuming that each user has a score with the highest level of unrevoked token, initialized to 0.  When tokens get revoked, the user score increments to 1, and all tokens with a score of 0 are not invalid.  To test for validity, you look up the user object and see what its score is.  If the score on the user is greater than the score on the token, the token i invalid.

I don't think that approach is going to work for remote revocation lists.  When tokens get revoked, we need to generate a list of all the revoked tokens and send them to the auth_token middleware etc.  The scoreboard approach does not provide a way to enumerate the revoked tokens and generate the list."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-05-03 02:08:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2013-05-08 02:57:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2013-05-08 02:58:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

In this case, we do create and maintain a revoked token list,  However, we need information in the main token list in order to build that.  This patch keeps the main list from growing out of control.

This one as it is fixing a real problem.  A redesign will take much longer.'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-20 21:42:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-26 20:39:55.000000000', 'message': "Fixing backend Token purging for memcache

Added in functionality to prune the token_lists (user or revocation)
to ensure we do not fill up a complete memcache page and cause
token issuing/revoking to fail.  The flush only occurs if a memcache
page is full when a new token is issued (or revoked) with exception
to the list functions if the max_*_list_size options are set to a
non-zero value.

This changeset also adds in the capability to administratively
expire long-lived-tokens in the case the that list(s) have
exceeded an appropriate size (filled up a page).

The dummy memcache driver will now behave a bit more like a
real memcache (where the data stored in the cache isn't modified
when a reference to the original data/get of data is changed).

New options added:
* max_revocation_list_size: maximum size of the revocation list
                            before a flush is called.  0 means
                            no flush will be called unless the
                            memcache page is full.

* max_user_record_list_size: maximum size of the user_record holding
                             the references to the actual tokens.
                             This is only relevant when a call to
                             token_api.list_tokens() is made. A
                             value of 0 indicates we do not care
                             about the list size and will only
                             flush if the memcache page is full

* max_cas_retry: The number of retries that will be attempted when
                 performing an update of the user_record or the
                 revocation-list record.  This is relevant due to
                 the use of CAS (compare and set) function of the
                 memcache client. This allows for multiple keystone
                 processes/wsgi/etc to run without worry of race
                 conditions clobbering the lists.

* max_token_age: if a flush is called on a user-record list, this
                 setting will specify the number of seconds since
                 creation a token (that is still valid) can be. If
                 a token's age exceeds this count, the token will
                 be removed from memcache and the user-record.
                 A value of 0 disables the functionality.

Change-Id: I95ac0ce589608a77a022663e933778b87d5c3bac
Fixes: bug #1171985

token issuing/revoking to fail.  The flush only occurs if a memcache
page is full when a new token is issued (or revoked) with exception
to the list functions if the max_*_list_size options are set to a
non-zero value.

real memcache (where the data stored in the cache isn't modified
when a reference to the original data/get of data is changed).

commit_message:
Fixing backend Token purging for memcache

Added in functionality to prune the user_token_lists
to ensure we do not fill up a complete memcache page and cause
token issuing/revoking to fail.  The flush only occurs if a memcache
page is full when a new token is issued with exception
to the list functions if the max_user_list_size option is set to a
non-zero value.

The dummy memcache driver will now behave a bit more like a
real memcache (where the data stored in the cache isn't modified
when a reference to the original data/get of data is changed).

New options added:
* max_user_record_list_size:
        maximum size of the user_record holding the references to
        the actual tokens. This is only relevant when a call to
        token_api.list_tokens() is made. A value of 0 indicates
        we do not care about the list size and will only
        flush if the memcache page is full

* max_compare_and_set_retry:
        The number of retries that will be attempted when performing
        an update of the user_record or the revocation-list record.
        This is relevant due to the use of CAS (compare and set)
        function of the memcache client. This allows for multiple
        keystone processes/wsgi/etc to run without worry of race
        conditions clobbering the lists.

Change-Id: I95ac0ce589608a77a022663e933778b87d5c3bac
Fixes: bug #1171985

commit_message:
root_helper shouldn't be set in the agent ini files in grizzly

root_helper shouldn't be configured in the agent ini files. In
addition, root_helper should be configured under the AGENT section
in quantum.conf.

Change-Id: Ifa3320f6972450ff16a4cff7eab2397705d35f8b

commit_message:
Encode headers and params

BaseClient currently fails when non-ascii characters are passed in
paramas and headers. This patch ensures those params are correctly
encoded before the request is made.

The patch adds strutils from oslo and updates gettextutils.

Fixes bug: #1182824

Change-Id: I813d745d76700c77f1871b151a76ff8b72ea92d4

commit_message:
Update run_tests.sh to match nova.

This is my draft patch to try and update the
run_tests.sh script to match how nova does their
runs using testr.

[{'created': '2013-05-31 15:39:00.000000000', 'message': "Don't make functional tests inherit from IsolatedUnitTest

There were some functional tests inheriting from IsolatedUnitTest which
doesn't make sense and was causing some issues in newer developments
since IsolatedUnitTest stubs some classes (like Registry's client).

Fixes bug: #1186291

Change-Id: Icafac9edf8b0cec6a96532c609923de2c4d8d6bb
"}]
commit_message:
Don't make functional tests inherit from IsolatedUnitTest

There were some functional tests inheriting from IsolatedUnitTest which
doesn't make sense and was causing some issues in newer developments
since IsolatedUnitTest stubs some classes (like Registry's client).

Fixes bug: #1186291

Change-Id: Icafac9edf8b0cec6a96532c609923de2c4d8d6bb

commit_message:
ceilometer does not set db in conf file

Set [database]connection option to mongodb rather than sqlite as mongodb
is the only fully supported db.

Change-Id: I2b9fbc65de4476593d456a782dbc7e6540a75141
Fixes: bug #1186240

commit_message:
Enable Nova v3 API

The Nova v3 API will be disabled by default after 31164 goes through.
This change explicitly enables the v3 API in the nova config file

Change-Id: I8b4c64b4718fc96d7a928c6fa3a0e8716c7edba1

subject: Install EPEL for rhel6 if not detected
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 01:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29177/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/15992 : SUCCESS in 44m 47s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29177/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/15708 : FAILURE in 45m 23s (non-voting)

- http://logs.openstack.org/29177/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/3631 : FAILURE in 10m 47s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-15 02:32:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If enabling EPEL is not to be automatic, I would suggest that it be possible for devstack to enable EPEL if explicitly configured to do so (i.e. ENABLE_EPEL=True).  The fact that it is a personal preference shouldn't require manual intervention be for devstack to be able to work, and it would reflect poorly on RHEL if the process for running devstack was more involved than for other distros."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-05-15 02:47:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We already have to do a number of specific things to get running on RHEL6 due to the age of its components.  Honestly, in the years I've been around production RHEL installations (can you say AS 2.1?) I've almost always enabled EPEL (since it existed) and before that RPMForge.  And with the pace of OpenStack development, I don't see how we can do without it for development purposes.  I'd vote for enabling EPEL by default.

Then again, my home Xen box is still on CentOS 5.8 so who am I to complain?"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-15 02:52:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

if you are installing devstack, we are taking over your system, and typically in a not very nice way. I don't really see letting users opt out of EPEL to be an option."}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-05-15 04:22:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-15 04:25:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Just a comment about the EPEL RPM source URL."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-15 20:07:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Now that EPEL is to be assured of being enabled, is python-pip guaranteed to be installed?  I see that python-pip is in files/rpms/general already, and I'm a bit confused as to why devstack wasn't previously failing if it couldn't install it.  If package installation failure will halt devstack, as I would assume it should, the check for pip should be redundant."}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-05-19 23:06:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-05-19 23:13:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-05-19 23:18:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> and I'm a bit confused as to why devstack wasn't previously failing if it couldn't install it. 

> If package installation failure will halt devstack, as I would assume it should, the check for pip should be redundant.

This is a separate bug that I'm thinking about.  We use "yum --assumeyes" to install without the "is this ok" prompt, but it seems that that also assumes that you're ok with missing packages.

I'm trying to figure out if there's a "yes, assume i say yes to installing those packages but stop if any are missing" flag'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 00:00:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-15 00:47:44.000000000', 'message': "Additional sanity checks for RHEL6

Simple check to see if EPEL repo is enabled for RHEL6.  Installing
repos such as EPEL may be a personal preference, so we give the user
the URL to fix it rather than any automated action.

Also adds an additional sanity check which checking for pip.  In the
prior case of EPEL being disabled, a RHEL6 host may not have access to
python-pip.  Although this shouldn't happen, its a good sanity check.

Change-Id: I4e8a4dda9475b75d071534d4eef469198502a048
"}, {'created': '2013-05-15 04:22:39.000000000', 'message': "Install EPEL for rhel6 if not detected

Simple check to see if EPEL repo is enabled for RHEL6 and, if not,
automated install of the repo RPM.

Also adds an additional sanity check which checking for pip.  In the
prior case of EPEL being disabled, a RHEL6 host may not have access to
python-pip.  Although this shouldn't happen, its a good sanity check.

Change-Id: I4e8a4dda9475b75d071534d4eef469198502a048
"}, {'created': '2013-05-15 05:26:35.000000000', 'message': "Install EPEL for rhel6 if not detected

Simple check to see if EPEL repo is enabled for RHEL6 and, if not,
automated install of the repo RPM.

Also adds an additional sanity check which checking for pip.  In the
prior case of EPEL being disabled, a RHEL6 host may not have access to
python-pip.  Although this shouldn't happen, its a good sanity check.

Change-Id: I4e8a4dda9475b75d071534d4eef469198502a048

commit_message:
Install EPEL for rhel6 if not detected

Simple check to see if EPEL repo is enabled for RHEL6 and, if not,
automated install of the repo RPM.

Also adds an additional sanity check which checking for pip.  In the
prior case of EPEL being disabled, a RHEL6 host may not have access to
python-pip.  Although this shouldn't happen, its a good sanity check.

Change-Id: I4e8a4dda9475b75d071534d4eef469198502a048

commit_message:
add firewall driver if we use quantum security group

fixes bug 1179820

we must set firewall driver if we want to use quantum security group because
quantum will disable security group if we do not change the default firewall
driver. Currently devstack will not change the default firewall driver
if we just running quantum server on a node which will cause nova unable to
security group information.

Change-Id: Ie274325decbf252630a237ed3d6ee3136eb259fe

commit_message:
specify session name on perform rejoin stack

rejoin-stack.sh would not specify screen session name which will lead
unstack.sh unable to kill the screen session started by rejoin-stack.sh
after hypervisor rebooted. So specify the session name if
rejoin-stack.sh need to start a new sreen session.

fixes bug 1182806

Change-Id: I68635887aa82fa63f3667e0f090ea2836eec7b68

commit_message:
Switch to sphinxcontrib-pecanwsme for API docs

Move the ceilext code into a separate package
so it can be worked on and reused by other
projects using Pecan and WSME.

The new package is being added to the requirements
list under https://review.openstack.org/29149.

Change-Id: If38a69ed8ef654e75bb29da998fbb731143c506c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

changes responses when requested for a invalid fixed ip address (which is
different of a non existent ip) from NotFound to BadRequest.

commit_message:
Change expected response when asking for invalid fixed ip

This depends on change I83d532c28c9aec690e8e1ffad8b58e71d619d728 on nova which
changes responses when requested for a invalid fixed ip address (which is
different of a non existent ip) from NotFound to BadRequest.

Also adds a test to check a non existent ip and hopefully get a NotFound

Change-Id: I075eb6da4a39e159aa266a6313b0f89dc76ff1f2

commit_message:
Add L3 resources to policy.json

This patch adds the l3 resources to policy.json. I tested changing the
rule to rule:admin_only for all the resources added and they were
enforced as expected.

Fixes bug 1186077

Change-Id: Ib5e2879165d9dc6416be4c96c62d6e49452d3be5

There was some dissent at the summit for this change which needs to be addressed.  I don't know the full reasoning for that stance but I believe it was against the idea of Nova continuing to be an API proxy for Glance.

There's also been some push back recently about including things in the Nova API which don't fit in the scope of what Nova is trying to provide(compute resources).  Given that I think this change warrants some discussion on the ML before considering a merge."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-13 13:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I should clarify that this is just about images.'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-05-15 14:15:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-05-15 14:17:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-10 02:46:32.000000000', 'message': "Ports images and ips api to v3 API

Port the core images and apis to the V3 API as plugins along
with the corresponding tests. Combines the two in the same changeset
because some of the tests are coupled together in test_servers
and I don't want to have to break them all up just to port them
and then have to put them together again in the next changeset

WIP: doesn't yet pass all the unittests. There is some crosstalk
between the v2 and v3 test_servers tests

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-core-as-extensions

Change-Id: I6e9f8ab71745791e6bc18999810f39764cd40116

commit_message:
Ports ips api to v3 API

Port the core ips api to the V3 API as plugins along
with the corresponding tests for the ips and servers API.

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-core-as-extensions

Change-Id: I6e9f8ab71745791e6bc18999810f39764cd40116

commit_message:
Simplify combo.css

The combo.css file was very complicated and difficult to
edit, pulled out unused sections so it's easier to
maintain and compatible with our s header.

Change-Id: I23b223d3c5af7db49da9ede47f69ef9792106888
Reviewed-on: https://review.openstack.org/31141
Approved: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>
Reviewed-by: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>
Tested-by: Jenkins

Hi Dan, fair enough, I'll intend this patch for Havana.  I just have a question.  Will it make a difference if I submit something that requires smaller changes (if that's possible)?  The reason why I'm still a bit concerned right now is that in the current code, any change to QuantumDbPluginV2TestCase could break the MidoNet plugin unit tests, so this may cause problems with commits coming in before Havana.  I would hate this plugin to cause delays in the upcoming bug fixes.  What I can do is try to make all the changes inside the unit tests module and not touch anything in the plugin code. commit_message:
Make MidoNet plugin code more testable

Refactor plugin.py and midonet_lib.py to improve unit testing of
the MidoNet plugin.  Make all the tests pass in the plugin except
those that test features that are not currently supported by the
plugin, which are IPv6 and multiple subnets per network.
Consolidate the mocking code in mock_lib.py to be shared by
plugin.py and midonet_lib.py.

Change-Id: Idcdfc3d90d5ec9e0be29bb6833d336af596fe363
Fixes: bug #1133215
Signed-off-by: Ryu Ishimoto <ryu@midokura.com>
Signed-off-by: Tomoe Sugihara <tomoe@midokura.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-29 16:06:36.000000000', 'message': "Reduce duplicated code related to policys

This patch adds some logic that is currently duplicated throughout
Openstack. As part of this de-duplication, the patch also modifies
current implementation.

Major Changes:
    * check, set_rules, reset, init are now part of the Enforcer class
    * check was renamed into enforce
    * init was renamed into load_rules
    * It is now possible to load multiple files and have per instance
      rules instead of global rules.
    * There's a global instance of the Enforcer class that can be used as
      main enforcer.

        from openstack.common import policy
        ENFORCER = policy.ENFORCER
        ENFORCER.check(rule, target, creds)

Minor Changes:
    * Added do_raise to the enforce method
    * Enforcer instance is now passed to the Check call.

NOTE: If / once this patch gets in, I'll update other projects and port
them to the latest version.

Change-Id: Ife909bdf3277ef33c2fb1eae16ae261fa6374c63

NOTE: If / once this patch gets in, I'll update other projects and port
them to the latest version.

Change-Id: Ife909bdf3277ef33c2fb1eae16ae261fa6374c63
"}]
commit_message:
Reduce duplicated code related to policies

This patch adds some logic that is currently duplicated throughout
Openstack. As part of this de-duplication, the patch also modifies
current implementation.

Major Changes:
    * check, set_rules, reset, init are now part of the Enforcer class
    * check was renamed into enforce
    * init was renamed into load_rules
    * It is now possible to load multiple files and have per instance
      rules instead of global rules.
    * There's a global instance of the Enforcer class that can be used as
      main enforcer.

        from openstack.common import policy
        ENFORCER = policy.ENFORCER
        ENFORCER.enforce(rule, target, creds)

Minor Changes:
    * Added do_raise to the enforce method
    * Enforcer instance is now passed to the Check call.

NOTE: If / once this patch gets in, I'll update other projects and port
them to the latest version.

Change-Id: Ife909bdf3277ef33c2fb1eae16ae261fa6374c63

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-29 15:00:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As this is an optimization, what kind of performance bump do we get?'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-05-29 15:24:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This will halve the memory usage of messages in ZmqProxy (*-rpc-zmq-proxy) which otherwise would keep two copies in memory. I opine this is the biggest gain.

While marginal, this also improves latency according to this chart (affected by message size):  http://www.zeromq.org/results:copying

Overall, this is a quick and easy change that doesn't really add much complexity. I withheld it earlier as not to prematurely optimize."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-29 21:10:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Now, messages will not be copied into the Python memory space
from the C library. The 'topic' key *will* be copied, to make
use of several string/bytes functions that are available to us.
(Potentially, we might be able to work with this as a memoryview

commit_message:
Use zero-copy in ZeroMQ proxy (zmq-rpc-receiver)

Now, messages will not be copied into the Python memory space
from the C library. The 'topic' key *will* be copied, to make
use of several string/bytes functions that are available to us.
(Potentially, we might be able to work with this as a memoryview
in the future as a further optimization?)

Implements blueprint zmq-zero-copy

Change-Id: I20a700867ac642b1a1788b31e3a21f8a299c97c8

commit_message:
Use mox object from moxstubout fixture

The moxstubout fixture creates a mox object which we can re-use in
tests.

It also ensures verify() is called, which it clearly wasn't in the
case of the qpid tests.

Change-Id: Ibf3326f18b160865012d40a5841b65438262c4df

commit_message:
Cleanup openrc.

- Cleanup openrc, removing the sourcing of functions (which was failing
  for zsh) and remove the *_DEBUG comment since they have been removed
  from the clients.

Change-Id: Ie2e6fb1e770403c4ef3463a850e8151bd312614c

commit_message:
Don't use pecan to configure logging

Fixes bug #1184941

openstack.common.log gives a mechanism to configure logging and, by
default, we will set up a handler on root logger. Using pecan to also
configure a handler on the 'ironic' logger means every log message gets
logged to console twice.

It seems that the pecan logging configuration stuff is redundant with
our existing logging configuration infrastructure.

Change-Id: Iec0630b0e842e3b6a90021bf552d9b857c5a0552
(cherry picked from commit e6a083fc5acb6f3ad03cc1df0943e4e746629128)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 13:01:38.000000000', 'message': 'ImagePollster record duplicate counter during one poll

When using ImagePollster to poll image status from Glance, there might
be duplicate image status event recorded down if there are private
images together with public images stored in Glance.

In Glance, the get image list API looks like:
    def _get_images(self, context, filters, **params):
        ...
 # NOTE(markwash): for backwards compatibility, is_public=True for
 # admins actually means "treat me as if I'm not an admin and show
 # all my images"
        if context.is_admin and params.get('is_public') is True:
            context.is_admin = False
            del params['is_public']
        ...
The above code shows that if a user is of 'admin_role'(this option is
configured in the glance-api.conf)  and querying for public images,
Glance will return all the public images together with the private
ones

While in ceilometer/image/glance.py#_Base.iter_images method,
ceilometer get the image list by querying public and private images
respectively and then chain the result lists together. This causes
the duplication of image in the image list.

This fix changes the code in ImagePollster.get_counters method to
filter out the duplicate images based on their image id.

Change-Id: Ib5e213161043033c20195efc0c6e7edd78982bd6
Fixes: Bug 1180630
(cherry picked from commit dfcd0dd7c4dad64b282843f681213b335ab735f4)
'}]
commit_message:
ImagePollster record duplicate counter during one poll

When using ImagePollster to poll image status from Glance, there might
be duplicate image status event recorded down if there are private
images together with public images stored in Glance.

In Glance, the get image list API looks like:
    def _get_images(self, context, filters, **params):
        ...
 # NOTE(markwash): for backwards compatibility, is_public=True for
 # admins actually means "treat me as if I'm not an admin and show
 # all my images"
        if context.is_admin and params.get('is_public') is True:
            context.is_admin = False
            del params['is_public']
        ...
The above code shows that if a user is of 'admin_role'(this option is
configured in the glance-api.conf)  and querying for public images,
Glance will return all the public images together with the private
ones

While in ceilometer/image/glance.py#_Base.iter_images method,
ceilometer get the image list by querying public and private images
respectively and then chain the result lists together. This causes
the duplication of image in the image list.

This fix changes the code in ImagePollster.get_counters method to
filter out the duplicate images based on their image id.

Change-Id: Ib5e213161043033c20195efc0c6e7edd78982bd6
Fixes: Bug 1180630
(cherry picked from commit dfcd0dd7c4dad64b282843f681213b335ab735f4)

commit_message:
vnics: don't presume existence of filterref/filter

With quantum/ovs plugin, there is no necessarily a "filteref" in interface param.
If not present don't lookup the "filter", let it to None and no more use
vnics.fref as resource_id.
resource_id becomes : instance_name + instance_uuid + vnic_name

fix Bug #1180466

Change-Id: I21c15f9ee4bd5303a7f2e287c7fe69aa7d0d5b0a
(cherry picked from commit f5d82ac17c0f8dfaed92670649c4bed0794dacf6)

commit_message:
Restore default interval

As we switched to multi-publisher pipelining, we modified,
I believe by mistake, the default polling interval from 600
to 60 second.

Change-Id: I4192a52aab1cbb744cd7ddf212e5ed3b0a3a27e6
Fixes: bug #1181153
(cherry picked from commit c48284bdd4bcaac975f98b8f0ff89f059a910480)

commit_message:
Document keystone_authtoken section

It's necessary to document how to configure the keystone_authtoken
section in the ceilometer.conf file so clients can authenticate
against the API server.

Fixes bug: 1177765

Change-Id: I93b45a7e65546246bbf1af795be5887e9a80c1fa
(cherry picked from commit c043106309415d7540c22f80eae9963927cd7f6c)

commit_message:
Shrink size of aggregate_metadata_get_by_host sql query

* Remove unnecessary secondary joins in Aggregate model.
* Remove unnecessary backrefs (only needed to create bidirectional relationship)

aggregate_metadata_get_by_host goes from 6 JOINS down to two JOINS.

Fix bug 1133495

Change-Id: I72966fa205973ec638816b07bfdcd54f1102feb5
(cherry picked from commit ce23d6c1d679355bafede816bca39ea1eb24073c)

Force deletes were eventually failing on the volume manager layer due to
being in an attached state. This will check that up front to inform the

Fixes: bug #1164929
Change-Id: I24ade24fd750dc647331ef25b835f45f29c10fd7
'}]
commit_message:
Prevent force delete if the volume is attached

Force deletes were eventually failing on the volume manager layer due to
being in an attached state. This will check that up front to inform the
user that they need to detach first.

Fixes: bug #1164929
Change-Id: I24ade24fd750dc647331ef25b835f45f29c10fd7

subject: xenapi: define LIBVIRT_{TYPE,GROUP}
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-28 12:02:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30703/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/18755 : SUCCESS in 43m 55s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30703/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/18465 : FAILURE in 49m 14s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/30703/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/25580 : SUCCESS in 21m 18s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30703/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/6191 : SUCCESS in 13m 49s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-28 21:03:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

this seems like the hacky way around this. If it's really an issue we should change the name of the variables to reflect what they really are."}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-05-29 12:04:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

The bigger problem is that devstack assumes in all sorts of places that we're using libvirt.

For example, lib/nova uses LIBVIRT_GROUP in many places which do not make sense for a XenServer installation.

Admittedly the "right" fix is to make devstack hypervisor agnostic and not try and install libvirt nomatterwhat but that's a significantly bigger change.

For now we need something that gets XenServer working in devstack again - I'd prefer it was either this change or a revert to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30703/'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-05-29 12:06:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sorry - wrong paste - the patch to revert should have been https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29379/'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-05-29 12:30:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Let's not revert that change. That makes sense, it just highlighted this issue, which is good. Let's instead try to give meaining to these variables / eliminate their use in the xenserver case."}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-05-29 12:42:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'm nervous that "fixing" this could be huge - devstack and specifically nova assume that KVM and libvirt is installed - in fact it's currently a dependency, which is clearly wrong.

"Doing the right thing" and creating appropriate separations could be a large volume of work - and it's certainly currently unmeasurable.

We need a patch that gets XenServer back working again - and actually, I believe that _all_ non-libvirt hypervisors were broken by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29379/ (including baremetal)'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-29 13:23:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

right, but the misleading variables are just going to cause it to break again in the future. You just caught it first.

I'm concerned about papering over this because I think we'll be right back here in a month doing it again."}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-05-31 10:13:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Probably abandon this change in favour of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/31177/ ?"}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-05-31 13:42:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Bob, you could've update this change, anyhow, I will abort this one, and look at your way."}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-05-31 13:42:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Aborting this change in favour of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/31177/'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 00:40:36.000000000', 'message': 'Clarify a comment which says we require KeyName - which is incorrect

The Nova create API requires a name, image, and flavor.  The key_name
is not mandatory.  Possibly in AWS InstanceType (flavor) is not
mandatory but it is with Nova.

blueprint native-nova-instance

Change-Id: I6f5a77d7999ea4d8e91402ae215179b982a947f6
'}]
commit_message:
Clarify a comment which says we require KeyName - which is incorrect

The Nova create API requires a name, image, and flavor.  The key_name
is not mandatory.  Possibly in AWS InstanceType (flavor) is not
mandatory but it is with Nova.

blueprint native-nova-instance

Change-Id: I6f5a77d7999ea4d8e91402ae215179b982a947f6

commit_message:
Create nested stacks in parallel

Use check_create_complete() to advance the nested stack creation, so that
it can occur in parallel with other resources in the parent stack.

Implements blueprint concurrent-resource-scheduling

Change-Id: I841b4c93b257409eecd0d2a43b35d9bee114ab87

commit_message:
Implement timeouts for nested stacks

This also means that if no default is specified, nested stacks will not
time out (previously they used the default timeout of 60 minutes). Of
course, like other resources, creation of the nested stack will stop if and
when the parent stack times out.

Change-Id: Ibd55c32d63e971f79319ed40321fa4be52b65419

commit_message:
Allow stacks to be created without a timeout

This should be the default for nested stacks, rather than the default
timeout of 60 minutes for stacks created through the API.

Change-Id: Iacee6eaf8f345e506b417e776f696db6b11bbf20

commit_message:
uses os.urandom instead of Crypto.Random for backward compatibility

Crypto.Random has been introduced by pycrypto 2.1 but in RHEL6 and
derivates you will only find pycrypto 2.0.1

bug #1186022

Change-Id: Ib601981b0b8fcb5b3e8fc8761ee05adf7f6574fa

commit_message:
Renames OpenVSwitch OVS section to ovs

Fixes bug: #1183127

The OVS configuration file section in Quantum has been renamed ovs
(lowercase).

This patch provides the corresponding fix in devstack.

Change-Id: I37c5014fd35223ca8c995fc36750a3590c3d223c

commit_message:
Initial version of Savanna v0.2

* pluggable provisioning mechanism
* a lot of old code has been removed
* new version of REST API (1.0)
* image registry draft implemented as novaclient extension
* oslo updated
* using oslo.db instead of flask-sqlalchemy
* some hacking fixes
* using alembic for db migrations

Partially implements blueprint pluggable-cluster-provisioning.
Partially implements blueprint savanna-rest-api-1-0.
Implements blueprint hadoop-image-registry.
Implements blueprint fulfill-openstack-requirements.
Implements blueprint db-migrate-support.

Change-Id: I5df80d67e25c2f4f8367f78f67fb9e9e76fc3647

commit_message:
Added first elements and instructions for creation ubuntu cloud images.

* creating ubuntu cloud image
* java installation
* hadoop installation
* created images can work with Savanna 0.1.x

Partially implements: blueprint savanna-image-elements

Change-Id: I62f8345ec69cbc2c9f445d359e3245ef78ff9bc8

commit_message:
Restrict python-cinderclient to <2 for now

Better be safe than sorry and restore the upper bound
on python-cinderclient. See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30858/
for the discussion.

Change-Id: Ia82e2f0c04dd36092059bc04e8e07990ad41ff58

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names.

Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Change-Id: Ifb2735151dc8c7f89ec01d237226669f7051ffa8
Fixes: bug #1179008

'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-14 00:24:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-14 01:54:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

Is this really the way to do this?

The problem I see is, what if the user has this VM stopped because they don't want it running (say, pulling things off a producer's queue)? If we let the VM start briefly and then quickly stop, isn't that likely to surprise the user?

I know that it becomes active now, but at least it would remain active and be clear to the user what happened. However, I think this makes it a little more confusing than it already is.

Can you change this so that it never starts the instance in the first place?"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-14 02:36:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (4 inline comments)

Addressed inline comments.

Dan, for your other general comment, I'm not sure how to handle since I thought the point of leaving the instance in RESIZED state was for the user to test it out and then confirm or reject - and for them to verify it must be running (ACTIVE state). So how would you resize an instance and never bring it up to verify? Or do you propose the user must manually start it up and then confirm/reject the resize? That seems overly complicated to me for this case, unless I'm missing a more elegant solution (which is entirely possible)."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-14 04:08:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

That is the point, yeah, and may speak to why the instance is powered on for confirm right now. In a system configured for auto-confirm, then they'd see the instance power on and then off. That said, I think it is also strange for confirm to end up powering off the instance. Further, imagine the case where an admin uses the migrate function (same code here) to move instances off to another host for a pre-fail scenario. The admin migrating an instance (which should be invisible to the user) would be causing the instance to power on until the admin confirmed, which would potentially disrupt something.

So, I think that one of the following is best:

 - the shutoff -> resize_confirm -> shutoff process should be able to do the entire thing without starting the instance
 - The migrate/resize operation refuses to run if the instance is shutoff
 - We leave it as it is and power on (and leave on) the guest to avoid the power state flap and the odd confirm-powers-off behavior

I prefer the first. Just MHO."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-14 13:33:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Dan, OK, I'll look at implementing that first option (shutoff -> resize_confirm -> stay shutoff).

What about the resize-reject flow?  Same story or is reject totally out of the picture now if you're doing an auto-confirm (user has no option to reject if you're automating the confirm flow)?  Maybe that would have to take into account the value for the resize_confirm_window config entry?

What I'm wondering about is how "auto" is resize_confirm_window if the value isn't 1 (second)?  Maybe the user sets it to 3600 seconds (1 hour), then it seems odd to automatically confirm the resize from STOPPED state before that time limit is reached.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-14 17:10:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

Spoke with Dan Smith and Chris Behrens about this in IRC. The plan is:

a) If a resize starts from an instance that's STOPPED, we never power it on automatically. However, the user might power it on to confirm the resize.

b) If the user does manually power it on and confirms the resize, we leave it on. If the user rejects it, we power it back off."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-14 17:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Yeah, I believe that logic makes sense.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-14 23:18:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-14 23:19:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Work In Progress

I haven't touched the unit tests yet. I've got the general direction I'm going with this down though. I'm hitting problems testing it because I don't have the libvirt driver working with the power_on parameter, I'm having a hard time figuring out just where exactly the libvirt driver powers on the resized instance when compute.manager.finish_resize calls it. The other drivers are pretty nice in that they call their own power_on() method so everything is separated nicely."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-14 23:25:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Do not merge

Just marking this as unmerge-able until unit tests and other stuff get worked out.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-14 23:29:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-14 23:30:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Work In Progress

Just cleaned up a couple of nits before any interim reviews.  Still don't have the libvirt driver working."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-14 23:45:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (8 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 00:15:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

The major problem that I see here is there's no accounting for the fact that migrations prior to this code will not have any 'old_vm_state' in their sys_meta.  We need to make sure we don't bomb out on that.

I didn't comment on every place inline.. but noted a few of the spots that need fixed."}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-05-16 18:29:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (6 inline comments)

"}, {'created': '2013-05-14 23:18:12.000000000', 'message': "Set resized instance back to original vm_state

You can resize an instance when it's in the ACTIVE or STOPPED state but
the code currently always finishes the resize (either confirmed or
rejected) by putting the instance into ACTIVE state. This change
saves the original vm_state and uses it to restore the state on the
instance after the resize is confirmed or rejected.

With this change, the resize flow will never automatically power on an
instance that is originally shutoff. The user, however, can manually
power on the resized instance to test it before confirming or rejecting
the resize. If the user powered on the instance and confirmed the
resize, then this change will leave the instance active. If the user
powered on the instance and then rejected the resize, this change will
stop the instance when it finishes the revert operation.

Fixes bug 1177811

"}, {'created': '2013-05-24 21:57:00.000000000', 'message': "Set resized instance back to original vm_state (2 of 2)

You can resize an instance when it's in the ACTIVE or STOPPED state but
the code currently always finishes the resize (either confirmed or
rejected) by putting the instance into ACTIVE state. This change
saves the original vm_state and uses it to restore the state on the
instance after the resize is confirmed or rejected.

With this change, the resize flow will never automatically power on an
instance that is originally shutoff. The user, however, can manually
power on the resized instance to test it before confirming or rejecting
the resize. If the user powered on the instance and confirmed the
resize, then this change will leave the instance active. If the user
powered on the instance and then rejected the resize, this change will
stop the instance when it finishes the revert operation.

This is the second part of the bug fix which adds the logic to the
compute manager to save the vm_state before resize/migrate and use that
to determine if the instance needs to be powered on or not.

Related to bug 1177811

commit_message:
Set resized instance back to original vm_state

You can resize an instance when it's in the ACTIVE or STOPPED state but
the code currently always finishes the resize (either confirmed or
rejected) by putting the instance into ACTIVE state. This change
saves the original vm_state and uses it to restore the state on the
instance after the resize is confirmed or rejected.

With this change, the resize flow will never automatically power on an
instance that is originally shutoff. The user, however, can manually
power on the resized instance to test it before confirming or rejecting
the resize. If the user powered on the instance and confirmed the
resize, then this change will leave the instance active. If the user
powered on the instance and then rejected the resize, this change will
stop the instance when it finishes the revert operation.

Related to bug 1177811

Change-Id: I19fa61d467edd5a7572040d084824972569ef65a

subject: Add power_on flag to virt driver finish/revert migration methods

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-24 21:56:58.000000000', 'message': "Set resized instance back to original vm_state (1 of 2)

You can resize an instance when it's in the ACTIVE or STOPPED state but
the code currently always finishes the resize (either confirmed or
rejected) by putting the instance into ACTIVE state. This change
saves the original vm_state and uses it to restore the state on the
instance after the resize is confirmed or rejected.

With this change, the resize flow will never automatically power on an
instance that is originally shutoff. The user, however, can manually
power on the resized instance to test it before confirming or rejecting
the resize. If the user powered on the instance and confirmed the
resize, then this change will leave the instance active. If the user
powered on the instance and then rejected the resize, this change will
stop the instance when it finishes the revert operation.

Note that this patch is part of a larger change. This patch updates the
driver code to handle the new power_on method signature and builds the
tests around that. A later patch will handle the changes to the compute
manager for the logic of toggling the power_on argument.

Related to bug 1177811

Change-Id: I76c7d6912eda2c333554855a8956bd0fbb1e8b6d
"}, {'created': '2013-05-25 01:53:46.000000000', 'message': 'Add power_on flag to virt driver finish/revert migration methods

or not to power on the instance as part of the resize/migrate operation.
The default is to power on the instance.

Related to bug 1177811

Change-Id: I76c7d6912eda2c333554855a8956bd0fbb1e8b6d

commit_message:
Add power_on flag to virt driver finish/revert migration methods

This patch adds a boolean power_on flag to the virt driver
finish_migration and finish_revert_migration methods to indicate whether
or not to power on the instance as part of the resize/migrate operation.
The default is to power on the instance.

Related to bug 1177811

Change-Id: I76c7d6912eda2c333554855a8956bd0fbb1e8b6d

commit_message:
Improve the performance of tokens deletion for user

Provide new delete the tokens api 'delete_tokens' to support
delete all the tokens for user in one session in the sql backend. For
the kvs and memcache, I also provide the corresponding implementation.

Fix bug 1178063

Change-Id: I986a583e5900ea04e26cbdb7c49638a33818bca7

commit_message:
Remove obsolete Fedora rc-local install.d hook.

After the refactor of the first-boot routine there's no use for this
script anymore, in fact all it's doing is to create a broken link.

Change-Id: Ic09e7208bc950380341e8a073647950ac99a05fd

commit_message:
Make sure that hypervisor nodename is set correctly in FakeDriver

This resolves an issue where the wrong host name is used when
executing some sample_api tests individually.

Resolves bug 1177802.

Change-Id: I29af026e29ff8c70bb6b4c81f1bdf28cdea11140
(cherry picked from commit 8b79ac24a83854de9f57bb3526a2edbd0b6d64d2)

[{'created': '2013-05-16 20:27:04.000000000', 'message': "Make nova.virt.fake.FakeDriver useable in integration testing

With this change nova.virt.fake.FakeDriver can be used for scale testing
using devstack. By setting 'compute_driver = nova.virt.fake.FakeDriver'
in nova.conf and disabiling quota and other limits, we can load up nova
to think it is running 1000's of instances.  This particular scenario is
analagous to how the baremetal driver will work (one machine managing
100's to 1000's of instances).

Make nova.virt.fake.FakeDriver use CONF.host for hostname.

Change-Id: I731ca2968176b4e39dd2fe7fc99f479cc568398b
(cherry picked from commit 03a2463be8034ee4764ac97e8020fc3d3a32f1fd)
"}]
commit_message:
Make nova.virt.fake.FakeDriver useable in integration testing

With this change nova.virt.fake.FakeDriver can be used for scale testing
using devstack. By setting 'compute_driver = nova.virt.fake.FakeDriver'
in nova.conf and disabiling quota and other limits, we can load up nova
to think it is running 1000's of instances.  This particular scenario is
analagous to how the baremetal driver will work (one machine managing
100's to 1000's of instances).

Make nova.virt.fake.FakeDriver use CONF.host for hostname.

Change-Id: I731ca2968176b4e39dd2fe7fc99f479cc568398b
(cherry picked from commit 03a2463be8034ee4764ac97e8020fc3d3a32f1fd)

commit_message:
Fix incorrect authorization rule in quota contrib api.

Incorrect policy and authorization extension name in
 contrib quota api. Legacy from nova.

Change-Id: Ida8262ad63d6f881dd50a385a9913c2ed57b441c
Fixes: bug #1185974

commit_message:
Add rough check for fixed_ips quota to API level

Preventing an attempt to start instances when reservation for fixed_ips
quota cannot be made.

Fixes: bug #1161188
Change-Id: I9ca3aa2635b147f4215b1b489be28db75f7e2861

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-22 18:49:03.000000000', 'message': 'Add test for posting a message with an incorrect body type

Previously, the WSGI unit test for messages only tested
malformed JSON and empty lists. This patch adds a test
to verify that an unexpected JSON type is handled correctly
as well.

Confirms fix: bug #1169838

Change-Id: Ia2e512138a465af70110d88e8e11ae58ee5e4aab
'}, {'created': '2013-05-22 19:25:50.000000000', 'message': 'Properly handle message post with an empty list.

The MongoDB driver was not detecting an empty list and
returning an empty ID list as a response.

I fixed the bug in this patch and have included two new
unit tests to cover this scenario.

Fixes: bug #1169838

Change-Id: Ia2e512138a465af70110d88e8e11ae58ee5e4aab
'}, {'created': '2013-05-23 21:30:07.000000000', 'message': "Properly handle message post with an empty iterable.

Storage drivers expect at least one item in messages iterable,
so I modified the WSGI driver to check when this is not
the case and return an error response to the client rather
than blindly passing the messages generator into the
driver's post method.

Fixes: bug #1169838

Change-Id: Ia2e512138a465af70110d88e8e11ae58ee5e4aab

commit_message:
Properly handle message post with an empty iterable.

Storage drivers expect at least one item in messages iterable,
so I modified the WSGI driver to check when this is not
the case and return an error response to the client rather
than blindly passing the messages generator into the
driver's post method.

Fixes: bug #1169838

Change-Id: Ia2e512138a465af70110d88e8e11ae58ee5e4aab

commit_message:
Control resource extension process defining required extensions

Blueprint l3-ext-gw-modes

The resource extension process is slightly altered so that an
API extension can specify which extensions should be processed before
its attributes can be processed. This is needed to ensure the
l3-ext-gw-mode API extension sets up correctly validators and other
attributes for the external_gateway_info attribute

Change-Id: I7c05746e67b1324a73082dde8b5c862d631c083c

commit_message:
identity v3 token

Adds a test where get a token using identity api v3,
and use that to perform an operation using compute api.

Fixes bug 1161633

Change-Id: I5d8121d1734ec7f1991758360b829c7889540c71

commit_message:
Update importutils and openstack-common.conf format

THe patch updates the importutils module and uses a per-line module
specification instead of the old modules= options.

Change-Id: Ieb28780bb9034fd61942305ff1eec21b3637027a

commit_message:
Fix Cisco nexus plugin failure for first VLAN on phy interface

Fixes bug 1174852

This fix changes the command being sent to the Nexus switch for
enabling a VLAN on an interface such that the 'add' keyword is
included only when there are prior VLANs already enabled on that
interface.

Change-Id: I466bcb839912b164b84be0e6721d87206c0e53eb

commit_message:
Fix pool update error in lbaas

fixes bug 1185687

Do not notify namespace agent of modified pool
if pool doesn't have vip

Change-Id: Ibe3399aaa145d19fc758f08adb51c7ffefa5bb3a

'}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-05-28 06:41:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

It is nice to see a fellow pycharm user!  Can you elaborate a bit more on the environment that you have and what caused this?  A bug report may be better than blueprint here.  I have the feeling that one of the imports is correct and the other is a misconfigured environment so perhaps a better fix would be to make sure we support the correct environment and log a good error message when the module is not found.  What are your thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 7703, 'date': '2013-05-28 14:53:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi John, 
Amala and I were working on this fix. You are right it should have been a bug than a blueprint. We would ensure that we choose the right option next time.

We totally agree with the approach you'd suggested to support the right environment and log a good error message for the wrong one. As we were planning to fix it on the same line you'd suggested, we happened to come across the following comment for a similar fix done on 'openstack/keystone' project.

-----------------------------------------------------
Dolph Mathews	

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I imagine that if this merges we'll just get another patch to revert it. I found examples of both imports online, but wasn't able to find an egg or anything on pypi to test with.

Anyway, I imagine two different version of pycharm are floating around with two different API's. To support both, can you revise this to:

try:
	from pydevd import pydevd
except ImportError:
	import pydevd"
--------------------------------------------------------
openstack/keystone fix reviewed page: https://review.openstack.org/23663

Hence we thought it might be appropriate to consider the point mentioned in the comment while fixing it on 'openstack/glance' code base as well. But If you think some better approach can be taken than the one we committed, please do suggest us. We would fix the pydevd import issue appropriately as per your suggestion.'}, {'account_id': 7701, 'date': '2013-05-28 15:21:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-28 15:28:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 7701, 'date': '2013-05-28 15:29:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

There was a typo in the code which has been fixed. I found the same on the keystone code also. Is it fine to fix it there as well?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-28 16:06:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Fix pydevd module import error

Introduces a try-except block in 'setup_remote_pydev_debug' that will
handle the pydevd module import error gracefully.

Implements: blueprint pydevd-module-import
Change-Id: Ia25b8ef21266ab52dc11c11e9db0bbfa8542f1b9

commit_message:
Changed endpoints from https to http

Did this because when creating a tenant for example, it will hang because it can't reach the api throught https, limit exceeded error.

Change-Id: I4a7582e584f9a7496406f75ea845848aa880f62d

Rick, you need to rebase to master and bring in the latest changes from other people.

Do this locally:

 git checkout master
 git pull
 git checkout grizzly
 git rebase master
 # You may need to resolve conflicts... if you do need to
 # remember to git add <FILE> for each conflicted file
 # after you resolve the conflicts, and then do:
 # git rebase --continue
 # after all the resolutions and finally do:
 git review

Thanks!

-jay"}, {'account_id': 7648, 'date': '2013-05-31 07:54:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

Changed config_by_roles to accept new namespaces

Changed the config_by_roles librarie to accapt the new namespaces,
addad "openstack" in front of it so its only needed to add the type of role in the recipes

commit_message:
Add missing oslo module.

Policy was being used, and there was a copy in openstack.common,
but it didn't appear in the openstack-common.conf config file. Fix
that.

Resolves bug 1181893.

Change-Id: Ib62bec4fcfc6c04d8f53ef503b028c287c4d1c63

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 23:31:52.000000000', 'message': 'Parse config files in an argparse callback

Part of fixing bug #1176817

We want to have the priority order of config file value vs CLI argument
to be determined by where on the command line the --config-file argument
appears.

e.g.

  --config-file nova.conf --log-file nova.log

would mean that a log_file value in nova.conf would be ignored, whereas

  --log-file nova.log --config-file nova.conf

would mean the value in the config file takes priority.

As a first step towards that, we move to parsing config files in an
argparse callback while processing the CLI args rather than parsing all
the config files together after CLI args processing. This allows us to
know whether a config file was loaded before or after a given CLI
argument.

Even this introduces a change in semantics - previously, the files in
the directory passed to --config-dir were parsed after any of the files
passed to --config-file. With this change, we now have --config-dir
processed according to where it appears on the command line e.g.

  --config-file foo.conf --config-dir blaa.d --config-file bar.conf

means that the files in blaa.d take precedence over foo.conf, but
bar.conf takes precedence over blaa.d. This is obviously the proper
semantics and we were never happy with the current semantics, so this is
all good.

Change-Id: I421e2d0c2cc41f361832c997c6c2198eb92c07c3
'}, {'created': '2013-05-20 21:17:27.000000000', 'message': 'Parse config files in an argparse callback

would mean the value in the config file takes priority.

the config files together after CLI args processing. This allows us to
know whether a config file was loaded before or after a given CLI
