Even this introduces a change in semantics - previously, the files in
the directory passed to --config-dir were parsed after any of the files
passed to --config-file. With this change, we now have --config-dir

means that the files in blaa.d take precedence over foo.conf, but

Change-Id: I421e2d0c2cc41f361832c997c6c2198eb92c07c3

argparse callback while processing the CLI args rather than parsing all

know whether a config file was loaded before or after a given CLI

Even this introduces a change in semantics - previously, the files in
the directory passed to --config-dir were parsed after any of the files
passed to --config-file. With this change, we now have --config-dir
processed according to where it appears on the command line e.g.

means that the files in blaa.d take precedence over foo.conf, but
bar.conf takes precedence over blaa.d. This is obviously the proper

commit_message:
Parse config files in an argparse callback

Part of fixing bug #1176817

We want to have the priority order of config file value vs CLI argument
to be determined by where on the command line the --config-file argument
appears.

e.g.

  --config-file nova.conf --log-file nova.log

would mean that a log_file value in nova.conf would be ignored, whereas

  --log-file nova.log --config-file nova.conf

would mean the value in the config file takes priority.

As a first step towards that, we move to parsing config files in an
argparse callback while processing the CLI args rather than parsing all
the config files together after CLI args processing. This allows us to
know whether a config file was loaded before or after a given CLI
argument.

Even this introduces a change in semantics - previously, the files in
the directory passed to --config-dir were parsed after any of the files
passed to --config-file. With this change, we now have --config-dir
processed according to where it appears on the command line e.g.

  --config-file foo.conf --config-dir blaa.d --config-file bar.conf

means that the files in blaa.d take precedence over foo.conf, but
bar.conf takes precedence over blaa.d. This is obviously the proper
semantics and we were never happy with the current semantics, so this is
all good.

Change-Id: I421e2d0c2cc41f361832c997c6c2198eb92c07c3

commit_message:
Revert additions to ConfigParser public APIs

In commit 2e1c685, we fixed the MultiConfigParser breakage but we also
added to the public APIs of MultiConfigParser and ConfigParser APIs.

There's no reason to lock ourselves into supporting these new semantics,
so let's add them in a way that they're private to cfg.

Change-Id: Ief1e491590f022dc16cca78b2c4aa2d418aec68f

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-24 12:37:04.000000000', 'message': "Refactor type conversion

The way each opt subclass has to override _get_from_config_parser() just
to perform type conversion is lame. Add an explicit type conversion
callable attribute on Opt and pass it to MultiConfigParser when we're
looking up a value.

This will be useful in a future patch where we'll use MultiConfigParser
(renamed to Namespace) to look up CLI values too - since these get
converted by argparse, we want to avoid converting those values again.

Change-Id: I52003026e788e83c355af55accb73d02150a6b0b
"}, {'created': '2013-05-31 06:29:13.000000000', 'message': "Refactor type conversion

The way each opt subclass has to override _get_from_config_parser() just
to perform type conversion is lame. Add an explicit type conversion
callable attribute on Opt and pass it to MultiConfigParser when we're
looking up a value.

This will be useful in a future patch where we'll use MultiConfigParser
(renamed to Namespace) to look up CLI values too - since these get
converted by argparse, we want to avoid converting those values again.

Change-Id: I52003026e788e83c355af55accb73d02150a6b0b
"}]
commit_message:
Refactor type conversion

The way each opt subclass has to override _get_from_config_parser() just
to perform type conversion is lame. Add an explicit type conversion
callable attribute on Opt and pass it to MultiConfigParser when we're
looking up a value.

This will be useful in a future patch where we'll use MultiConfigParser
(renamed to Namespace) to look up CLI values too - since these get
converted by argparse, we want to avoid converting those values again.

Change-Id: I52003026e788e83c355af55accb73d02150a6b0b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 19:55:33.000000000', 'message': "New Revocation List Caching/Handling

Implements a new mechanism for handling revocation lists so that
proper caching can be done independantly of the token driver. There
are three provided revocation-list drivers: memcache, sql, and kvs.

SQL revocation-list driver is a simple passthrough driver than
mimics the previous behavior, relying on the SQL DB to provide all
of the relevant information.

KVS revocation-list driver works in a similar mechanism to the KVS
Token driver and will result in unreliable results when running
Keystone under HTTPD/gunicorn/etc because the DictKvs() object is
instantiated per driver-object and is not shared.  It should be
sufficient for caching the SQL revocation-list when running under
eventlet (or when running the kvs token driver).

Memcache revocation-list driver is the recommended driver to use as
it will handle the most scenarios.  The memcache driver will also
handle scenarios where the revoked-token list exceeds the maximum
page size of the memcache server with the smallest max_item_size.
This means that the memcache driver has to do some minimal
construction of the revocation-list from 1 or more pages.  The
majority of the cases will be loading in 2 pages to report the
revocation-list, the index page, and the actual JSON page.  In the
rare case that there is a massive revocation-list.  Memcache driver
will only reload from memcache if the index page differs from it's
internal cache.  New UUIDs are used for each page to ensure that
the internal cache is not stale if the revocation-list is rebuilt.

New Options added
    * (memcache) maximum_revocation_list_pages:
            The maximum number of pages that can be consumed for
            the revocation-list.  This is to set a hard-limit on
            the memory-footprint allowed to be consumed by the
            revocation-list itself.  It is extremely unlikely
            that the revocation-list will ever overflow to a
            2nd or 3rd page.
            Default: 10

    * revoked_token_driver:
            string of the new revoked token driver (similar to
            how the token driver works).
            Default:
                keystone.token.revocation.backends.kvs.Revocation

bp cache-token-revocations

Change-Id: I6c062bbe4bd6e90dc585d3e207d00f2461cfb8bd

commit_message:
New Revocation List Caching/Handling

Implements a new mechanism for handling revocation lists so that
proper caching can be done independantly of the token driver. There
are three provided revocation-list drivers: memcache, sql, and kvs.

SQL revocation-list driver is a simple passthrough driver than
mimics the previous behavior, relying on the SQL DB to provide all
of the relevant information.

KVS revocation-list driver works in a similar mechanism to the KVS
Token driver and will result in unreliable results when running
Keystone under HTTPD/gunicorn/etc because the DictKvs() object is
instantiated per driver-object and is not shared.  It should be
sufficient for caching the SQL revocation-list when running under
eventlet (or when running the kvs token driver).

Memcache revocation-list driver is the recommended driver to use as
it will handle the most scenarios.  The memcache driver will also
handle scenarios where the revoked-token list exceeds the maximum
page size of the memcache server with the smallest max_item_size.
This means that the memcache driver has to do some minimal
construction of the revocation-list from 1 or more pages.  The
majority of the cases will be loading in 2 pages to report the
revocation-list, the index page, and the actual JSON page.  In the
rare case that there is a massive revocation-list.  Memcache driver
will only reload from memcache if the index page differs from it's
internal cache.  New UUIDs are used for each page to ensure that
the internal cache is not stale if the revocation-list is rebuilt.

New Options added
    * (memcache) maximum_revocation_list_pages:
            The maximum number of pages that can be consumed for
            the revocation-list.  This is to set a hard-limit on
            the memory-footprint allowed to be consumed by the
            revocation-list itself.  It is extremely unlikely
            that the revocation-list will ever overflow to a
            2nd or 3rd page.
            Default: 10

    * (token) revoked_token_driver:
            string of the new revoked token driver (similar to
            how the token driver works).
            Default:
                keystone.token.revocation.backends.kvs.Revocation

DocImpact: New Options / New Driver for Revocation Handling

bp cache-token-revocations

Change-Id: I6c062bbe4bd6e90dc585d3e207d00f2461cfb8bd

commit_message:
WIP: Add different rpc timeout configuration for nova-network calls

Setting up networks and allocating IP addresses and deleting them can
take long time depending on quantum and the plugin being used. So
adding a different rpc timeout configuration value will allow us
to increase timeout value only for nova-network calls.

Change-Id: I5a0bd3fdacdaf38ceac99dff455a707bb090bcc6

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-07 16:33:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

A few quick points ...

I consider changing the order to be a backwards incompatible change to the API ... so we need to make this something a program would have to opt-in to

I also posted some thoughts here: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-May/008691.html

I'm still thinking it probably makes sense to only switch the order for CLI tools like nova-manage. I think the order is correct for the services. So, those tools could opt-in to the new behaviour.

Finally, if we could figure out how to make the location of the config file in the command line determine the order, that might help us ... i.e.

  --config-file foo.conf --debug
  --debug --config-file foo.conf

only in the latter case would debug=False in the config file overwrite the --debug flag"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-13 16:23:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Would it make sense to load the configuration file when that option is encountered, instead of after the command line options are finished?'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-14 10:50:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@doug Not sure I understand what you mean. Do you mean taking under consideration the file option "just" when it was explicitly specified in it?

@mark Do you have any new thoughts / considerations about this? It would be great to agree on something and keep this going asap. 

FWIW, I think, as pointed in the list thread, we should invert the behavior here without adding more complexity.'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-14 13:20:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Looks correct. Moving code and the testcases are extensive.'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-14 13:20:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks correct. Moving code and the testcases are extensive.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-15 14:21:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Flavio: If we attach a callback to the config file option handler, argparse will tell us where it appears in the incoming command line arguments. We can read the file immediately from within the callback and update the current config settings. Any command line options that come after the configuration file would then override the settings in the configuration file.'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-16 14:04:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Doug: I guess we could do something like that but, I still don't see the point. I mean, that would be helpful to easily enable / disable this behavior and keep backward compatibility, which I still don't know if will be broken with this patch at all, what I'm struggling to understand is why we need that hack. The current behavior is wrong so why do we need to workaround a fix for something that is wrong in first place?

I'm not OK with adding more complexity to how oslo.config parses arguments but, I'd be OK with that as far as the default behavior is giving priority.

Hopefully the above makes sense :P"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-16 23:37:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

What Doug describes is the most obvious behaviour IMHO

The only reason I didn't originally do it this way was because it's pretty tricky to get right

Inspired by Doug's thoughts, I've taken a stab at implementing it - see I0a584a3c26ddadf24e3f473c773ee34a914667b3

I'm still unhappy to be changing the semantics of the API in incompatible ways, but I think it's pretty unlikely anyone will be depending on the old behaviour and be broken by the new behaviour - more likely people will be blocked by the old behaviour and be glad to see the new behaviour"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-31 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

[{'created': '2013-05-07 11:35:59.000000000', 'message': 'Let CLI arguments override config's ones

Currently, oslo.config gives priority to parameters configured in the
configuration files. This behavior has caused some confusion to final
users and doesn't respect the "natural" way unix CLI apps work. This has
also caused some issues in other apps that expect the opposite to
happen.

After some discussion in the m-l [0], it looks like inverting this behavior
makes sense and projects would benefit from it.

This patch does exactly that. It looks for the required config first in
the CLI arguments and then in the configuration files. In this patch,
the override tests methods were duplicated in order to test 2 things:

1) The second config file should override the first one
2) CLI arguments should override config's ones.

Fixes bug #1176817
Fixes bug #1175570

commit_message:
Let CLI arguments override config's ones

Currently, oslo.config gives priority to parameters configured in the
configuration files. This behavior has caused some confusion to final
users and doesn't respect the "natural" way unix CLI apps work. This has
also caused some issues in other apps that expect the opposite to
happen.

After some discussion in the m-l [0], it looks like inverting this behavior
makes sense and projects would benefit from it.

This patch does exactly that. It looks for the required config first in
the CLI arguments and then in the configuration files. In this patch,
the override tests methods were duplicated in order to test 2 things:

1) The second config file should override the first one
2) CLI arguments should override config's ones.

Fixes bug #1176817
Fixes bug #1175570

[0]
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-May/008551.html

Change-Id: Idafec44d059cafd8b8862864b8b09efde2e38266

[{'created': '2013-05-24 14:28:45.000000000', 'message': 'Disallow resize if image not available

If a resize is attempted on an instance that was started from an image
that has since been deleted, a resize will fail. This change makes error
reporting a bit cleaner.

This change is needed since in order to actually properly support
resize/migrate when the image is deleted - it is necessary for nova to keep
a copy of the image metadata and re-use it in case of migration/resize.

Fixes bug: 1160773
Fixes bug: 1177001

Change-Id: Ifaea71f79c97046a4cde094e3a5e676772fcceb4
(cherry picked from commit 65a6264c236a779712694d2379cfe4f9e46e2732)
'}]
commit_message:
Disallow resize if image not available

If a resize is attempted on an instance that was started from an image
that has since been deleted, a resize will fail. This change makes error
reporting a bit cleaner.

This change is needed since in order to actually properly support
resize/migrate when the image is deleted - it is necessary for nova to keep
a copy of the image metadata and re-use it in case of migration/resize.

Fixes bug: 1160773
Fixes bug: 1177001

Change-Id: Ifaea71f79c97046a4cde094e3a5e676772fcceb4
(cherry picked from commit 65a6264c236a779712694d2379cfe4f9e46e2732)

There is incomplete format in exception's message.

Fixes: bug 1184870

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names.

Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Fixes: bug #1179008
Change-Id: I6f8a11988982133249d443403f63b4f8724e156e

[{'created': '2013-05-16 20:36:56.000000000', 'message': "Fix for missing multipath device name

Due to formatting changes in the multipath -l output
we were sometimes missing the device name for each of the
multipath devices which gave us a device of '/dev/'.  This
causes problems on detach.

Fixes Bug: #1180497

Change-Id: I6017dda149776624fac452140d3d0f5df3f5fd5a
(cherry picked from commit 565dfc65fbab1df4ec5e83be627805c313aab04b)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix for missing multipath device name

Due to formatting changes in the multipath -l output
we were sometimes missing the device name for each of the
multipath devices which gave us a device of '/dev/'.  This
causes problems on detach.

Fixes Bug: #1180497

Change-Id: I6017dda149776624fac452140d3d0f5df3f5fd5a
(cherry picked from commit 565dfc65fbab1df4ec5e83be627805c313aab04b)

commit_message:
set bdm['volume_id'] to None rather than delete it

bdm is a sqlalchemy model object, it doesn't make sense to delete
an attribute, so just set it to None

Fix bug 1166160

Change-Id: I41017af602f0c8369d442b4a6936e1a829d2f9a9
(cherry picked from commit 85c3c89f1d44ab4b26755958fec29161b0090ce0)

[{'created': '2013-05-27 02:18:56.000000000', 'message': "get_instance_security_groups() fails if no name on security group

The following patch fixes a bug in get_instance_security_groups() where
it tries to access security_groups['id'] but security_groups is a string.
This patch also removes some stubs that were not needed in a few unit test.

Fixes bug 1182738

Change-Id: Ia64db2e40d4a0e163344b4234112dbde71b1e132
(cherry picked from commit 5d40fb635b1abac3828245124e392a4c9af52f60)

commit_message:
get_instance_security_groups() fails if no name on security group

The following patch fixes a bug in get_instance_security_groups() where
it tries to access security_groups['id'] but security_groups is a string.
This patch also removes some stubs that were not needed in a few unit test.

Fixes bug 1182738

Change-Id: Ia64db2e40d4a0e163344b4234112dbde71b1e132
(cherry picked from commit 5d40fb635b1abac3828245124e392a4c9af52f60)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 20:31:06.000000000', 'message': 'Catch volume create exception

Catch InvalidInput exception from cinder when the parameters
are invalid such as an invalid size. Currently the exception
is not caught which results in a 400 Bad Request correctly being
returned, but also leaving a traceback in the logs. Correctly
catching the exception and explicitly raising an HTTPBadRequest
removes the production of the traceback

Fixes bug #1098048

Change-Id: Ia66e67f302cf20e96417f4ff3c1430b755a4a861
(cherry picked from commit 46ce2e345bce18c2e2f645bb90aea11ca53ba825)
'}]
commit_message:
Catch volume create exception

Catch InvalidInput exception from cinder when the parameters
are invalid such as an invalid size. Currently the exception
is not caught which results in a 400 Bad Request correctly being
returned, but also leaving a traceback in the logs. Correctly
catching the exception and explicitly raising an HTTPBadRequest
removes the production of the traceback

Fixes bug #1098048

Change-Id: Ia66e67f302cf20e96417f4ff3c1430b755a4a861
(cherry picked from commit 46ce2e345bce18c2e2f645bb90aea11ca53ba825)

commit_message:
Updated translations from Transifex

Fixes bug #1175241

This is a grizzly version of commit b7e36244c0
in master branch. To avoid fuzzy strings PO files are directly downloaded
from Transifex instead of cherry-picking from master.
This commit does not override the source language 'en'
to avoid the bug fixed by commit a7505869c4.

Change-Id: I4810c45d15413bdf21b9f68f59096c907bb1e624

commit_message:
Enumerate ignored flake8 rules

We were previously ignoring all F* and H* rules; this patch specifically
identifies them so that we can eliminate them one by one, without
introducing regressions along the way.

Change-Id: Iaf9ee17acf44aba1c93c1af50c84bd8216544b89

commit_message:
Revert "Set EVENTLET_NO_GREENDNS=yes in tox.ini."

We don't need this since EVENTLET_NO_GREENDNS=yes is set in
keystone.common.wsgi_server .

This reverts commit 46b224abf1c6f7c9bd579806f202a019e2695b29.

Change-Id: I96c2c567f68cdd509425245c7772196918b44b44

[{'created': '2013-05-19 15:30:03.000000000', 'message': "Disable eventlet monkey-patching of DNS

This change avoids eventlet's monkey-patching of DNS resolution.
eventlet's doesn't support IPv6, for example.

The way to avoid eventlet's DNS is to set an environment
variable. The trick is the environment variable needs to be set
before eventlet is imported.

A similar change was made in nova, so this is just copying that
code and technique to Keystone.

This allows re-enabling the IPv6 tests, too.

Change-Id: I1e4d4bbfea374d386796d1505a602fd187e75c67
"}, {'created': '2013-05-19 15:30:03.000000000', 'message': "Disable eventlet monkey-patching of DNS

This change avoids eventlet's monkey-patching of DNS resolution.
eventlet's doesn't support IPv6, for example.

The way to avoid eventlet's DNS is to set an environment
variable. The trick is the environment variable needs to be set
before eventlet is imported.

A similar change was made in nova, so this is just copying that
code and technique to Keystone.

This allows re-enabling the IPv6 tests, too.

Change-Id: I1e4d4bbfea374d386796d1505a602fd187e75c67
"}]
commit_message:
Disable eventlet monkey-patching of DNS

This change avoids eventlet's monkey-patching of DNS resolution.
eventlet's doesn't support IPv6, for example.

The way to avoid eventlet's DNS is to set an environment
variable. The trick is the environment variable needs to be set
before eventlet is imported.

A similar change was made in nova, so this is just copying that
code and technique to Keystone.

This allows re-enabling the IPv6 tests, too.

Change-Id: I1e4d4bbfea374d386796d1505a602fd187e75c67

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names.

    Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
    to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the
    general world are growing intelligence about them.

Fixes: bug #1179008
Change-Id: I1a19f0c73ab48987e2ff0dade1a57a68b65f0a22

commit_message:
Updating to recent keystone/etc/policy.json.

Fixes bug 1185812.

Recent changes for validating tokens are required
as of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/23970/11

Without this change openstack services can't
validate token's and firstboot fails.

policy.json taken directly for the keystone repository.

Change-Id: I3efa6deb931e3b172fcb970aeb740576e10a86a9

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 03:37:40.000000000', 'message': 'Make boot-stack pass reachable IP to new machines.

The default configuration of boot-stack will have the boot-stack VM at
192.0.2.1. Thus, we want Heat to pass that as the metadata service
address rather than 127.0.0.1.

Change-Id: I2dd0867490914d65b7325322ef80919c843603e0
'}]
commit_message:
Make boot-stack pass reachable IP to new machines.

The default configuration of boot-stack will have the boot-stack VM at
192.0.2.1. Thus, we want Heat to pass that as the metadata service
address rather than 127.0.0.1.

Change-Id: I2dd0867490914d65b7325322ef80919c843603e0

Fixes: bug #1180393

commit_message:
Make ManagerWithFind abstract and fix TokenManager

ManagerWithFind requires list() method in its descendants.
Make it abstract and fix its improper descendant TokenManager
that do not implement list().

Change-Id: I83ae47d894c02d5cd1eb0da437dd05796d0b0160
Fixes: bug #1180393

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-05 03:05:01.000000000', 'message': 'vmwareapi: Add supported_instances to host state

The VMWareVCDriver uses the VCState class to report host state,
but VCState.update_status() does not include supported_instances.
Add supported_instances to the data returned by update_status(),
similar to HostState.update_status().

Change-Id: I15c0f930dd9e540f6fdb0d7246661a0c98e35ed4
(cherry picked from commit 7e86ab000e5b897d3b7fac6aca0c11f4db51ef7d)
'}]
commit_message:
vmwareapi: Add supported_instances to host state

The VMWareVCDriver uses the VCState class to report host state,
but VCState.update_status() does not include supported_instances.
Add supported_instances to the data returned by update_status(),
similar to HostState.update_status().

Change-Id: I15c0f930dd9e540f6fdb0d7246661a0c98e35ed4
(cherry picked from commit 7e86ab000e5b897d3b7fac6aca0c11f4db51ef7d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-09 12:16:22.000000000', 'message': 'Make sure confirm_resize finishes before setting vm_state to ACTIVE

Setting it to ACTIVE to early will allow new resize or whatever
operations to start before the current confirm has finished which
might result in all sorts of conflicts.

Resolves bug 1161529 where an intermittent failure in a tempest test
happens because a confirm operation conflicts with a later resize
carried out on the same instance. As the new resize starts to move
around instance disks, the still not finished confirm operation might
fail at recalculating total disk usage due to a missing disk.

Other possible conflicts might be due to system_metadata and/or quota
not being up-to-date at the moment the instance becomes ACTIVE.

Change-Id: I079da4e271469739504fa87e23149d03652d98f0
(cherry picked from commit fd26589afa2852762575feaae95a0c9b0c091461)
'}]
commit_message:
Make sure confirm_resize finishes before setting vm_state to ACTIVE

Setting it to ACTIVE to early will allow new resize or whatever
operations to start before the current confirm has finished which
might result in all sorts of conflicts.

Resolves bug 1161529 where an intermittent failure in a tempest test
happens because a confirm operation conflicts with a later resize
carried out on the same instance. As the new resize starts to move
around instance disks, the still not finished confirm operation might
fail at recalculating total disk usage due to a missing disk.

Other possible conflicts might be due to system_metadata and/or quota
not being up-to-date at the moment the instance becomes ACTIVE.

Change-Id: I079da4e271469739504fa87e23149d03652d98f0
(cherry picked from commit fd26589afa2852762575feaae95a0c9b0c091461)

[{'created': '2013-05-20 16:27:06.000000000', 'message': "Don't raise unnecessary stack traces in EC2 API

exception.EC2APIError exceptions are always expected, so no reason to have a
LOG.exception when one is raised.  Furthermore nova.api.ec2.ec2_error already
logs the exception so the duplicate log statement is just removed

Fix Bug 1180973

Change-Id: I4b42a9a764f6e15bb94a383e8a725d52d7436bd7
(cherry picked from commit dc887267572c821ce97bec9536a699b72bdae443)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't raise unnecessary stack traces in EC2 API

exception.EC2APIError exceptions are always expected, so no reason to have a
LOG.exception when one is raised.  Furthermore nova.api.ec2.ec2_error already
logs the exception so the duplicate log statement is just removed

Fix Bug 1180973

Change-Id: I4b42a9a764f6e15bb94a383e8a725d52d7436bd7
(cherry picked from commit dc887267572c821ce97bec9536a699b72bdae443)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-06 15:16:53.000000000', 'message': 'Update hypervisor_hostname after live migration

After a live migration, the OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hypervisor_hostname
attribute of the instance is not updated correctly.  This change
adds a parameter to the call to _instance_update that fixes the
problem.

Fixes bug 1173376

Change-Id: I40f1ead2d93c7a9979a914e0fb96e3e5bb287b48
(cherry picked from commit 8c8e44cf37be9c6a9f418e923c9ff16df8619832)
'}]
commit_message:
Update hypervisor_hostname after live migration

After a live migration, the OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hypervisor_hostname
attribute of the instance is not updated correctly.  This change
adds a parameter to the call to _instance_update that fixes the
problem.

Fixes bug 1173376

Change-Id: I40f1ead2d93c7a9979a914e0fb96e3e5bb287b48
(cherry picked from commit 8c8e44cf37be9c6a9f418e923c9ff16df8619832)

subject: Rework to support RFC 2616 Sec 4.4 Message Length
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-17 22:07:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me Build succeeded. - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/2393 : SUCCESS in 45s - http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29605/1/check/gate-swift-docs/2221/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 58s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/1/check/gate-swift-python26/2469 : SUCCESS in 1m 15s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/1/check/gate-swift-python27/2471 : SUCCESS in 59s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/16615 : SUCCESS in 44m 19s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/23172 : SUCCESS in 22m 27s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/16330 : FAILURE in 52m 38s (non-voting) - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/4192 : FAILURE in 11m 10s (non-voting) '}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:41:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this So, I love this patch, but the transfer-encoding validation needs to move into the proxy. Otherwise the GreenPile/_connect_put_node/Expect-100-continue business reaches in for handoffs and eventually just 503's. clayg@swift:~$ curl -H 'x-auth-token: AUTH_tkd45fcb62d6d0418eb56bbaa95644b8d9' http://localhost:8080/v1/AUTH_test/content/unicode-timeout-test.py -T unicode-timeout-test.py.gz -H 'transfer-encoding: gzip' -XPUT -v * About to connect() to localhost port 8080 (#0) * Trying 127.0.0.1... connected > PUT /v1/AUTH_test/content/unicode-timeout-test.py HTTP/1.1 > User-Agent: curl/7.22.0 (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu) libcurl/7.22.0 OpenSSL/1.0.1 zlib/1.2.3.4 libidn/1.23 librtmp/2.3 > Host: localhost:8080 > Accept: */* > x-auth-token: AUTH_tkd45fcb62d6d0418eb56bbaa95644b8d9 > transfer-encoding: gzip > Content-Length: 242 > Expect: 100-continue > < HTTP/1.1 503 Service Unavailable < Content-Length: 118 < Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 < Date: Mon, 20 May 2013 22:13:25 GMT * HTTP error before end of send, stop sending < * Closing connection #0

Service Unavailable

The server is currently unavailable. Please try again at a later time.

Basically I ran into this cause I was testing what "an unexperienced user" might run into if they were "confused about the different use cases for transfer-encoding vs. content-encoding". Not that *I* would ever need a refresher. :\ FWIW, the situation isn't that much better on master; but the file does seem to get created and you sometimes you get a 200. Regardless I think we need to stick with the precedent of validating incoming requests once at the proxy as much as possible. Raising 400's on PUT from the object servers has so far mostly been a tool for catching bugs; trying to correlate them into something meaningful for the user seems like double work (triple work?)'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-21 14:57:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:46:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work Build failed. For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/2/check/gate-swift-pep8/2430 : SUCCESS in 39s - http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29605/2/check/gate-swift-docs/2261/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 05s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/2/check/gate-swift-python26/2509 : SUCCESS in 1m 14s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/2/check/gate-swift-python27/2507 : SUCCESS in 1m 01s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/17315 : SUCCESS in 49m 22s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/23985 : FAILURE in 27m 03s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/17025 : FAILURE in 29m 50s (non-voting) - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/2/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/4854 : FAILURE in 9m 44s (non-voting) "}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:48:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer) Yup raising the 400 on bad transfer-encoding from the proxy there works a treat. Thanks for the super quick turn around, KUDOS! New proxy tests are pretty good. I think the SIGPIPE stuff is a little cargo cult, but it's no big deal: http://paste.openstack.org/show/37534/ Big plus two. Bonus points for adding the fast-fail RequestEntityTooLarge. Unrelated; but welcome in my book. If you have an extra second you might throw a bone to the commit message to make note of the change."}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:00:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:02:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:27:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer) recheck bug 1182550'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:52:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me Build succeeded. - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/4/check/gate-swift-pep8/2434 : SUCCESS in 47s - http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29605/4/check/gate-swift-docs/2265/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 20s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/4/check/gate-swift-python26/2513 : SUCCESS in 1m 17s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/4/check/gate-swift-python27/2511 : SUCCESS in 1m 04s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/17329 : SUCCESS in 49m 49s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/24001 : SUCCESS in 20m 02s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/17039 : FAILURE in 50m 15s (non-voting) - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/4/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/4866 : FAILURE in 10m 13s (non-voting) '}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-22 18:48:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment) I'm a little confused here. So, in Section 4.4 part 2, it says "If a Transfer-Encoding header field (section 14.41) is present and has any value other than "identity", then the transfer-length is defined by use of the "chunked" transfer-coding (section 3.6), unless the message is terminated by closing the connection." Consider a request with: Connection: close Transfer-Encoding: deflate Is that legal according to the RFC, or is that not legal because the message isn't terminated by the client closing the connection? (I mean, they could send a single FIN and leave it half-open, right? TCP allows that.)'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:44:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:37:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me Build succeeded. - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/5/check/gate-swift-pep8/2474 : SUCCESS in 58s - http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29605/5/check/gate-swift-docs/2304/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 22s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/5/check/gate-swift-python26/2552 : SUCCESS in 1m 21s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/5/check/gate-swift-python27/2550 : SUCCESS in 1m 14s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/18042 : SUCCESS in 44m 57s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/24788 : SUCCESS in 21m 21s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/17752 : FAILURE in 52m 14s (non-voting) - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/5/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/5532 : FAILURE in 11m 31s (non-voting) '}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-24 01:50:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-24 02:43:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me Build succeeded. - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/6/check/gate-swift-pep8/2482 : SUCCESS in 49s - http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29605/6/check/gate-swift-docs/2312/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 01s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/6/check/gate-swift-python26/2560 : SUCCESS in 1m 15s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/6/check/gate-swift-python27/2558 : SUCCESS in 59s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/18197 : SUCCESS in 49m 08s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/24958 : SUCCESS in 19m 55s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/17907 : FAILURE in 52m 18s (non-voting) - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/6/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/5675 : SUCCESS in 15m 33s (non-voting) '}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-26 01:06:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-26 01:55:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me Build succeeded. - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/7/check/gate-swift-pep8/2505 : SUCCESS in 38s - http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29605/7/check/gate-swift-docs/2335/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 57s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/7/check/gate-swift-python26/2583 : SUCCESS in 1m 13s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/7/check/gate-swift-python27/2581 : SUCCESS in 1m 01s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/18534 : SUCCESS in 49m 06s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/25321 : SUCCESS in 19m 36s - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/18244 : FAILURE in 41m 12s (non-voting) - http://logs.openstack.org/29605/7/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/5985 : SUCCESS in 16m 10s (non-voting) '}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-29 00:35:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment) Looks pretty good to me, but I have a couple of questions. If I specify "Transfer-Encoding: morsecode" on an object PUT, then I get a 400 response with body "Invalid Transfer-Encoding header value". Should that be a 501 Not Implemented response instead? The RFC is sort of making my head spin today, so I really can't tell. Second, there's two call sites for swob.Request.message_length(). In the proxy, you catch both ValueError and AttributeError, but in the object server, you only catch ValueError. Is that intentional, or is it an oversight?'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-29 02:49:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment) Regarding 400 vs 501, because the header is not "morsecode, chunked", it is a 400 value (at least that is how I am interpreting section 14.41, see commit message). Does that make sense? Regarding the two call sites: my thought was that if the object server receives a bad transfer encoding, then it would be from the proxy server, which should never happen (in theory). But perhaps that assumption is not worth making and so I should make the behavior identical. Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-29 23:42:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer) I'm not sure if the correct response is 400 or 501 due to my confusion over section 3.6 (the bit that says "unless the message is terminated by closing the connection"), but it's definitely one of those two. Realistically, this is still better than what we have today, and it's easy enough to return the right error code later should we figure out definitively that it's one or the other. Regarding the second call site (the one without AttributeError), that's probably fine. You're right that the proxy's not going to send an invalid Transfer-Encoding header to the backend, and even if it does, the resulting 500 will still show up in the logs.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-30 03:35:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: When I read Sec 4.4, item #5, it seems to me that one cannot define a message body by closing the connection, in that case, the message should be ignored. Not sure we if handle that currently. FYI: be aware of the errata: http://skrb.org/ietf/http_errata.html, and a somewhat old but useful paper on 1.0 vs 1.1 protocol differences: http://www8.org/w8-papers/5c-protocols/key/key.html.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-30 04:37:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Right; I think there is one case where you can define a message body by closing the connection. A client could send a PUT request (headers & body), then close its half of the TCP connection, then receive the response. Probably not worth worrying about, though; I've never heard of a client that does such a thing."}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-30 10:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: But #5 says, "5. By the server closing the connection. (Closing the connection cannot be used to indicate the end of a request body, since that would leave no possibility for the server to send back a response.)" So I understand that for requests only, you cannot use connection close to define the length of the message.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-30 16:55:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Ah, I hadn't seen that. Well, that clears it up for me. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-05-30 18:15:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved FWIW I prefer the BadRequest to ServerError (NotImplemented) just because people like to track 4XX and 5XX counts and garbage in the headers seems like the clients fault IMHO. If there was a well know and widely adopted transfer-encoding that we *don't* support and clients were expecting the 501 to degrade gracefully... well then I guess then ca file a bug. This fixes to many problems to NOT merge it. Good work Pete."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 18:15:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: No score Starting gate jobs. http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 20:11:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Fails Build failed. [{'created': '2013-05-17 21:14:58.000000000', 'message': 'Rework to support RFC 2616 Sec 4.4 Message Length

RFC 2616 Sec 4.4 Message Length describes how the content-length and
transfer-encoding headers interact. If transfer-encoding is anything
but "identity", it implies chunked encoding and content-length is
supposed to be ignored. If content-length does not need to be
specified, but if it is and the request is not using chunked encoding,
then the content-length must match the body length.

transfer-encoding headers interact. If transfer-encoding is anything

supposed to be ignored. The content-length header does not need to be

'}, {'created': '2013-05-23 15:44:17.000000000', 'message': 'Rework to support RFC 2616 Sec 4.4 Message Length

RFC 2616 Sec 4.4 Message Length describes how the content-length and
transfer-encoding headers interact. Basically, if chunked transfer
encoding is used, the content-length header value is ignored and if
the content-length header is present, and the request is not using
chunked transfer-encoding, then the content-length must match the body
length.

The only Transfer-Coding value we support in the Transfer-Encoding
header (to date) is "chunked". RFC 2616 Sec 14.41 specifies that if
"multiple encodings have been applied to an entity, the
transfer-codings MUST be listed in the order in which they were
applied." Since we only supported "chunked". If the Transfer-Encoding
header value has multiple transfer-codings, we return a 501 (Not
Implemented) (see RFC 2616 Sec 3.6) without checking if chunked is the
last one specified. Finally, if transfer-encoding is anything but
"chunked", we return a 400 (Bad Request) to the client.

object which will apply an algorithm based on RFC 2616 Sec 4.4
leveraging the existing content_length property.

In addition to these changes, the proxy server will now notice when
the message length specified by the content-length header is greater
than the configured object maximum size and fail the request with a
413, "Request Entity Too Large", before reading the entire body.

This work flows from https://review.openstack.org/27152.

commit_message:
Rework to support RFC 2616 Sec 4.4 Message Length

RFC 2616 Sec 4.4 Message Length describes how the content-length and
transfer-encoding headers interact. Basically, if chunked transfer
encoding is used, the content-length header value is ignored and if
the content-length header is present, and the request is not using
chunked transfer-encoding, then the content-length must match the body
length.

The only Transfer-Coding value we support in the Transfer-Encoding
header (to date) is "chunked". RFC 2616 Sec 14.41 specifies that if
"multiple encodings have been applied to an entity, the
transfer-codings MUST be listed in the order in which they were
applied." Since we only supported "chunked". If the Transfer-Encoding
header value has multiple transfer-codings, we return a 501 (Not
Implemented) (see RFC 2616 Sec 3.6) without checking if chunked is the
last one specified. Finally, if transfer-encoding is anything but
"chunked", we return a 400 (Bad Request) to the client.

This patch adds a new method, message_length, to the swob request
object which will apply an algorithm based on RFC 2616 Sec 4.4
leveraging the existing content_length property.

In addition to these changes, the proxy server will now notice when
the message length specified by the content-length header is greater
than the configured object maximum size and fail the request with a
413, "Request Entity Too Large", before reading the entire body.

This work flows from https://review.openstack.org/27152.

Change-Id: I5d2a30b89092680dee9d946e1aafd017eaaef8c0
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 17:01:32.000000000', 'message': 'Update cloned volumes QoS settings.

The SolidFire device inherits all settings (including QoS) from
the parent on a clone.  This meant that although we were expecting
QoS to be updated when a clone was issued with a different Volume
Type than the parent volume it was never acted upon.

This change fixes that bug by simply adding the *new* qos settings
to the ModifyVolume call after cloning.

Fixes bug: 1184235

Change-Id: I81786a07312027d543b9f06e54dfbf57e6085bc9
(cherry picked from commit 37fa1ef51ef389ed7ac0affb1dd59ba680ca52df)
'}]
commit_message:
Update cloned volumes QoS settings.

The SolidFire device inherits all settings (including QoS) from
the parent on a clone.  This meant that although we were expecting
QoS to be updated when a clone was issued with a different Volume
Type than the parent volume it was never acted upon.

This change fixes that bug by simply adding the *new* qos settings
to the ModifyVolume call after cloning.

Fixes bug: 1184235

Change-Id: I81786a07312027d543b9f06e54dfbf57e6085bc9
(cherry picked from commit 37fa1ef51ef389ed7ac0affb1dd59ba680ca52df)

commit_message:
The vm_state should not be modified until the task is complete.

Several methods in nova.compute.api alter the vm_state value before
proceeding with the actual work. The initial vm_state may be changed to
something other than the initial vm_state (which is a problem: since we
do not know what the initial state actually was, we cannot reasonably
recover and set the corresponding ERROR if a problem with the operation
occurs).

Actually done:

Removed vm_state update before executing task

Changed methods:
- reboot
- pause
- unpause
- suspend
- resume
- rescue
- unrescue

Fixes: bug #1158509
Change-Id: I5ee7aebf3c4831dd577ed5ab9aa155095152f8a8
(cherry picked from commit d4e762bd9ecffb6a945fbe938fff78fc2b0681e6)

commit_message:
Remove auth_token middleware and related tests.

Auth_token middleware has been moved to python-keystoneclient and
is deprecated in Grizzly, so we can remove it in Havana.

Change-Id: I824bc8205837e8e0f962c8c6618ce4e28e7563eb

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 13:27:09.000000000', 'message': "Fix F18 oz-install failures

F18 builds are unreliable (or for some people don't work at all),
this seems due to the following bug:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=906031

The simplest workaround is to use the netinst ISO instead of the DVD
so we pick up the newer curl package which fixes the problem

Fixes bug #1185810

Change-Id: I066356e8a780caa8ca2798644ec7594b0536005c
"}]
commit_message:
Fix F18 oz-install failures

F18 builds are unreliable (or for some people don't work at all),
this seems due to the following bug:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=906031

The simplest workaround is to use the netinst ISO instead of the DVD
so we pick up the newer curl package which fixes the problem

Fixes bug #1185810

Change-Id: I066356e8a780caa8ca2798644ec7594b0536005c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-19 22:42:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix error in instance_get_all_by_filters() use of soft_deleted filter

Commit 0f56d8ddb02f54ae389380dcd0790e55f2dcb479 introduced the use of
a soft_deleted filter to the above db method for use in combination
with the already existing deleted filter. In doing so, an error was
introduced that changed the original behavior of the deleted filter,
when used alone.

This changes it back to retain the original behavior that when setting
the deleted filter alone, it should either include or exclude both
soft- and hard-deleted instances.

Also add unit test coverage to changes to instance_get_all_by_filters()
that was introduced in commit 0f56d8ddb02f54ae389380dcd0790e55f2dcb479.

Resolves bug 1181865.

Change-Id: Ibb82af09d3876904455ca7c93e14e9722ed31d35
'}, {'created': '2013-05-20 21:42:39.000000000', 'message': "Fix error in instance_get_all_by_filters() use of soft_deleted filter

Change-Id: I7c2fab48944e34765b3fff8ce10bc64a5cd826c8 introduced the
'soft_deleted' filter to the above method to tweek the behavior of the
existing 'deleted' filter. In doing so, an error was introduced that
changed the original behavior of the 'deleted' filter when used by
itself, in how it treated both soft- and hard-deleted instances the
same.

The original merged patch did not include test coverage for the changes
made to the db api. This change fix the error so that the original
behavior of the 'deleted' filter is restored while also adding full
test coverage for the modifications to the db api that has already
merged.

Finally, the support method create_instances_with_args() used by the
new tests was renamed create_instance_with_args() to reflect that
when called, it just creates a single instance.

Resolves bug 1181865.

Change-Id: Ibb82af09d3876904455ca7c93e14e9722ed31d35
"}]
commit_message:
Fix error in instance_get_all_by_filters() use of soft_deleted filter

Change-Id: I7c2fab48944e34765b3fff8ce10bc64a5cd826c8 introduced the
'soft_deleted' filter to the above method to tweek the behavior of the
existing 'deleted' filter. In doing so, an error was introduced that
changed the original behavior of the 'deleted' filter when used by
itself, in how it treated both soft- and hard-deleted instances the
same.

The original merged patch did not include test coverage for the changes
made to the db api. This change fix the error so that the original
behavior of the 'deleted' filter is restored while also adding full
test coverage for the modifications to the db api that has already
merged.

Finally, the support method create_instances_with_args() used by the
new tests was renamed create_instance_with_args() to reflect that
when called, it just creates a single instance.

Resolves bug 1181865.

Change-Id: Ibb82af09d3876904455ca7c93e14e9722ed31d35

commit_message:
Switch from losetup+partprobe to kpartx for Fedora image creation.

Fedora's partprobe does not create devices the same way it does on
Ubuntu. Instead of using partprobe, this patch uses kpartx, which
works on both Fedora and Ubuntu.

Change-Id: Iac5cbac083e423425693c8210cd5d058ce4bce72

[{'created': '2013-05-23 19:05:04.000000000', 'message': 'Remove tempest hack for create/rebuild checks

A bug in Tempest required us to check quotas before requesting image
information. Now that this has been fixed upstream, we can remove our hack to
get around this.

Change-Id: I7ef1cd2f4f641fb5616945b66740820a4003b66d
'}]
commit_message:
Remove tempest hack for create/rebuild checks

A bug in Tempest required us to check quotas before requesting image
information. Now that this has been fixed upstream, we can remove our hack to
get around this.

Change-Id: I7ef1cd2f4f641fb5616945b66740820a4003b66d

Raise exception instances not exception classes

Replaces deprecated syntax of raising an exception class
with raising an instance of the exception class instead

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 15:35:02.000000000', 'message': "Make pylint ignore nova/objects/

The dynamic nature of our object model is going to cause lots of
heartache for pylint, especially in the actual definitions. This
just excludes that whole directory from pylint's view, which will
limit the heartache to only everywhere objects are actually used.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I7f1a4b10b8a5098aab2ab2e8ea5da15ec43f0e2e
"}]
commit_message:
Make pylint ignore nova/objects/

The dynamic nature of our object model is going to cause lots of
heartache for pylint, especially in the actual definitions. This
just excludes that whole directory from pylint's view, which will
limit the heartache to only everywhere objects are actually used.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I7f1a4b10b8a5098aab2ab2e8ea5da15ec43f0e2e

commit_message:
Add <version> arg to keystone-manage db_sync

This optional <version> argument allows a client of db_sync to indicate to
which database version to upgrade or downgrade.

Change-Id: I3ccf45eb572a3897e5d3bc5bd17566493a55f393

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-02 21:03:10.000000000', 'message': 'Handle DB creation race condition

Till now if a race occurs on a request to a DB when it is
first created, the loosing party die with 500...
... and an error stating a race is in the log file.

Both removed by simply acepting the fact that the DB is in fact
created by someone else - just less work for us to do... ;)

Fixes Bug #1051998

Change-Id: I8e29bf362edf2b1a84f9bffa39c04d5b3dc241b2

created by someone else - just less work for us to do... ;)

Fixes Bug #1051998

Change-Id: I8e29bf362edf2b1a84f9bffa39c04d5b3dc241b2
'}]
commit_message:
Handle DB creation race condition

Till now if a race occurs on a request to a DB when it is
first created, the loosing party die with 500...
... and an error stating a race is in the log file.

Both removed by simply accepting the fact that the DB is in fact
created by someone else - just less work for us to do... ;)

Fixes Bug #1051998

Change-Id: I8e29bf362edf2b1a84f9bffa39c04d5b3dc241b2

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-27 07:11:11.000000000', 'message': 'Missing command descriptions for 'token-get' and 'endpoint-get'

When using command "keystone help token-get" and "keystone help endpoint-get",
the description of these commands are missing. The main reason is that
keystoneclient is using the command action method's method doc as the command
description. In keystoneclient/v2_0/shell.py, the two commands' action method
are 'do_endpoint_get' and 'do_token_get'. These two methods have a decorator of
"require_service_catalog" which is a function wrapper, and this decorator has
changed the origin __doc__ of the wrapped function by default

Modify "require_service_catalog" to change the __doc__ back to the origin
function's __doc__

Change-Id: I9977a3d279529b2066667cd2ffe44dd953b4d2fb
Fixes: Bug 1182107
'}]
commit_message:
Missing command descriptions for 'token-get' and 'endpoint-get'

When using command "keystone help token-get" and "keystone help endpoint-get",
the description of these commands are missing. The main reason is that
keystoneclient is using the command action method's method doc as the command
description. In keystoneclient/v2_0/shell.py, the two commands' action method
are 'do_endpoint_get' and 'do_token_get'. These two methods have a decorator of
"require_service_catalog" which is a function wrapper, and this decorator has
changed the origin __doc__ of the wrapped function by default

Modify "require_service_catalog" to change the __doc__ back to the origin
function's __doc__

Change-Id: I9977a3d279529b2066667cd2ffe44dd953b4d2fb
Fixes: Bug 1182107

[{'created': '2013-05-29 23:14:33.000000000', 'message': "Catch and report errors from copy image to volume.

The copy image-to-volume errors weren't being handled
properly and the result was the lvcreate being retried
even though the lvcreate itself succeeded.

The result of this was misleading errors stating that
the volume couldn't be created because it already existed
(which it did, becuase the create itself was succesful).

Fixes bug: 1183283

Change-Id: I23f05fe64475c3efe285e05a258c4625b801375c
(cherry picked from commit b2371aeff9eccbd28952dd0f568da26722dc58f7)
"}]
commit_message:
Catch and report errors from copy image to volume.

The copy image-to-volume errors weren't being handled
properly and the result was the lvcreate being retried
even though the lvcreate itself succeeded.

The result of this was misleading errors stating that
the volume couldn't be created because it already existed
(which it did, becuase the create itself was succesful).

Fixes bug: 1183283

Change-Id: I23f05fe64475c3efe285e05a258c4625b801375c
(cherry picked from commit b2371aeff9eccbd28952dd0f568da26722dc58f7)

So, it looks to me like the behavior change is as follows:

If I turn off account autocreate and make a request for a nonexistent account, say 

    GET /v1/nonesuch
    Accept: application/interpretive-dance

then before this patch, I would get a 404. After this patch, I would get a 412.

Is that your expectation, or is there more to it?'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-29 01:39:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes, if the parameters and headers are not valid, fail the request before accessing the account or container databases.

If folks think this is not worth it, I don't mind abandoning it."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-29 04:19:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I don't see a problem with it. If a request is wrong in two ways, it makes sense to give the cheap error first. commit_message:
Move parameter checking before disk accesses

For HEAD and GET requests on both containers and accounts APIs we now
perform parameter checking before we access the database. The unit
tests were updated to show that the parameter checking is performed
before accesses are performed.

Change-Id: Ieb753316cdccabf45022e3d83522d87d34aa6b0e
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2013-05-30 18:20:04.000000000', 'message': 'Change kvm-img to qemu-img in the two places it remains.

qemu-img is the current canonical name of the tool.  kvm-img is a
compatibility symlink to it in Ubuntu, but is not present in Fedora
or RHOS.  The rest of the manuals use qemu-img; these are the last
two references to kvm-img.

Change-Id: I47036218ba5d3eff7d2e2c70a2d25542110edfb7

commit_message:
Change kvm-img to qemu-img in the two places it remains.

qemu-img is the current canonical name of the tool.  kvm-img is a
compatibility symlink to it in Ubuntu, but is not present in Fedora
or RHOS.  The rest of the manuals use qemu-img; these are the last
two references to kvm-img.

Change-Id: I47036218ba5d3eff7d2e2c70a2d25542110edfb7

commit_message:
Adds VPNaaS DataModel and Plugin support

This is work in progress towards the first iteration
and is meant to provide the basic API and DataModel for
the VPN Advanced Service Plugin.

NOTE: Unit tests are not included.

Fixed bugs based on the initial review provided.

Change-Id: I4d599cb00dc97fe92df0f8e584eb6ac3c96280c9
Implements: blueprint VPNaaS-Python-API
Fixes: bug #29812

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-29 15:08:14.000000000', 'message': 'Subtle change to tempurl content-disposition names

If an object name ends with a /, the content-disposition filename for
a tempurl ended up as an empty string. This fix just strips any
trailing slashes before calling basename.

Also, I added a test to verify that if the filename is passed as an
overriding query parameter, that it is used in full, no rstripping,
no basenaming.

Change-Id: I37725b6ded04ed3b91cdb21132490fd857276e2f
'}]
commit_message:
Subtle change to tempurl content-disposition names

If an object name ends with a /, the content-disposition filename for
a tempurl ended up as an empty string. This fix just strips any
trailing slashes before calling basename.

Also, I added a test to verify that if the filename is passed as an
overriding query parameter, that it is used in full, no rstripping,
no basenaming.

Change-Id: I37725b6ded04ed3b91cdb21132490fd857276e2f

One thing I don't get is, why would a config file for a guest set up to use just Percona or just plain MySQL have both package names defined?"}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2013-05-30 18:57:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

as per what kagan and i have talked about im good w/ this'}, {'account_id': 4693, 'date': '2013-05-30 18:57:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

"Is this changing the code to match config files already in place?"

the config values are not in a file, but rather in the code, set as default values. like most of the other values we use. it seems that config files are used to override those values when needed, which doesn't seem to happen that often.

"One thing I don't get is, why would a config file for a guest set up to use just Percona or just plain MySQL have both package names defined?"

as mentioned above, it's not a config file, it's the code. every guestagent pulls the entire code base, hence, has access to those config values.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 18:57:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Convert nova to use oslo wsgi server support

Nova versions of the SSL options are now deprecated in favor of their
equivalents defined in oslo-incubator.

blueprint use-oslo-wsgi

Change-Id: Ibb502a8aafa0110ed47291a829b2979d2b7753e8

* Allow passing in SSL config as arguments
* Added tests for sslutils

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 05:17:47.000000000', 'message': 'In TempURL, cache "no keys" for a shorter time.

In other places in the codebase, we cache a negative result for less
time (usually a tenth) than we cache a positive result. This commit
makes TempURL do the same.

This creates a slightly nicer experience for someone trying to set up
TempURL; if they get the initial key setup wrong, try it, then fix it,
it now takes only 6 seconds until they can use signed URLs, not
60. That's a short enough time that they may not even notice the
caching of no keys.

Change-Id: I521f023e7cddaecd07f0ce32aedd4059bd0b8ec4
'}]
commit_message:
In TempURL, cache "no keys" for a shorter time.

In other places in the codebase, we cache a negative result for less
time (usually a tenth) than we cache a positive result. This commit
makes TempURL do the same.

This creates a slightly nicer experience for someone trying to set up
TempURL; if they get the initial key setup wrong, try it, then fix it,
it now takes only 6 seconds until they can use signed URLs, not
60. That's a short enough time that they may not even notice the
caching of no keys.

Change-Id: I521f023e7cddaecd07f0ce32aedd4059bd0b8ec4

compute manager.

commit_message:
compute.api call conductor ComputeTaskManager for live-migrate

Before the compute api called the scheduler to perform
live migrate. This change makes the compute api call the
conductor, which in turn calls the scheduler.

For those not using the conductor service,
this does not add any extra rpc calls.

This change in control flow means we can look to move
live-migrate more related rpc calls into the conductor
from both schduler driver and compute manager.

part of blueprint live-migration-to-conductor
Change-Id: I081c5e090921d69878d044839616a48f198ecb7d

commit_message:
moving the decision on what pkg to use into the guestagent code

the decision is based on the service type (percona/mysql)
and the right pkg is selected based on that.

Change-Id: I659204606800dae55678fcf68422953489db226a
fixes: bug#1185140

NOTE: this patch effectively *removes* a feature new in grizzly (multi-domain support for LDAP) in favor of fixing our existing 99% use case (proper read-only support for LDAP for a single domain). Additionally, there's considerable hesitation to continue pursuing multi-domain support in LDAP during havana as it's not perceived to be a commonly desired use case at all."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-30 07:21:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 07:59:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

- http://logs.openstack.org/28423/6/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/6731 : SUCCESS in 18m 45s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-05-30 09:27:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This stretches a bit what is usually accepted in the stable branch release... We (stable maint team) need to discuss that a bit. Setting -1 to make sure it's not accidentally merged in the mean time."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-30 09:33:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Is "multi-domain support for LDAP" something existing grizzly users are likely to be using?

Is bug #1168726 essentially a regression from Folsom? i.e. would most users of the LDAP support hit this issue when upgrading from Folsom to Grizzly?'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-30 14:16:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Is "multi-domain support for LDAP" something existing grizzly users are likely to be using?

No, Brad Topol (an LDAP stakeholder & contributor here) pinged the mailing list inquiring about this, and zero multi-domain LDAP users responded. https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg23387.html

> Is bug #1168726 essentially a regression from Folsom? i.e. would most users of the LDAP support hit this issue when upgrading from Folsom to Grizzly?

Most users of LDAP in Folsom are deploying against an LDAP server were OpenStack is not allowed to modify LDAP (i.e. it's read-only). stable/grizzly currently requires new objects be added to LDAP to support the multi-domain use case, effectively blocking deployments that are read-only from migrating to grizzly at all.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-05-30 15:07:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: No score

Sounds like a regression we should fix, then. Waiting on markmc's advice though."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-30 15:17:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Yeah, seems like there's a good case for fixing this in stable/grizzly"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-05-30 15:29:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Definitely something that should be mentioned in release notes though'}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2013-05-30 16:52:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Yes, this is needed to fix F->G regression, very user-visible for LDAP users.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 16:52:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-30 17:36:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

thanks, everyone!

side noet- issue has been documented in keystone's Known Issues in the release notes for a while: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ReleaseNotes/Grizzly#OpenStack_Identity_.28Keystone.29"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 18:01:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified

commit_message:
Read-only default domain for LDAP (bug 1168726)

NOTE: this patch effectively *removes* a feature new in grizzly
(multi-domain support for LDAP) in favor of fixing our existing 99% use
case (proper read-only support for LDAP for a single domain).

A proper fix to the above was also blocked by bug 1117356, so that's
fixed here as well (updates properly return the resulting entities).

Change-Id: I672b90e67545cc1fe65b05ef7f8af5b42ca6afc3

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-21 23:42:53.000000000', 'message': 'Document that element type is needed

When creating users, groups, etc., it's required to put the data
in a { "user": {} }, { "group": {} }, etc, but the identity v3 doc
doesn't say this. This causes confusion because it's not obvious
what the problem is when you attempt to create a user, group, etc.

This change updates the identity v3 doc to make it explicit that
the wrapper is needed.

Change-Id: Ic5d0ef0b528364f80dad9ef72c79839212fa4d0a
'}]
commit_message:
Document that element type is needed

When creating users, groups, etc., it's required to put the data
in a { "user": {} }, { "group": {} }, etc, but the identity v3 doc
doesn't say this. This causes confusion because it's not obvious
what the problem is when you attempt to create a user, group, etc.

This change updates the identity v3 doc to make it explicit that
the wrapper is needed.

Change-Id: Ic5d0ef0b528364f80dad9ef72c79839212fa4d0a

[{'created': '2013-05-30 11:20:18.000000000', 'message': "Fix incorrect status for volume clone from image

If, when using a Ceph as a backend for Cinder and Glance, you
create a volume from a Glance image, the request is actioned
in one of two ways; (1) if Glance does not supply sufficient
information to Cinder, a full copy is made of the Glance
image or (2) Ceph uses it's copy-on-write capability to do a
clone. If a full copy is done, the volume is marked as
Bootable=True but if a clone is done it is not.

This does not appear to break nova boot from volume at present
but the status displayed by the cinder client is incorrect.

Change-Id: I2959fc3dfaf0e073781583019797bcd44f7789d6
Fixes: bug 1185533

commit_message:
Fix incorrect status for volume clone from image

If, when using a Ceph as a backend for Cinder and Glance, you
create a volume from a Glance image, the request is actioned
in one of two ways; (1) if Glance does not supply sufficient
information to Cinder, a full copy is made of the Glance
image or (2) Ceph uses it's copy-on-write capability to do a
clone. If a full copy is done, the volume is marked as
Bootable=True but if a clone is done it is not.

This does not appear to break nova boot from volume at present
but the status displayed by the cinder client is incorrect.

Change-Id: I2959fc3dfaf0e073781583019797bcd44f7789d6
Fixes: bug 1185533

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-28 08:26:16.000000000', 'message': "Fix 'Inheritance-based rule deprecated' log warning

A warning message appears in Cinder logs which state that
inheritance-based rules are deprecated and use default
Brain instead of HttpBrain. It looks like HttpBrain class
doesnt have any difference from Brain class, so changing
all the instances of HttpBrain to Brain shouldn't affect
anything and removes this warning from logs.

Digging further, I found out that the policy engine has
gone through a major rework in Oslo and Nova, and I think
at some point of time in future, we will also be moving
to use the latest policy engine code. In that way of
thinking, I guess this fix is acceptable for now.
Reference: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14122

Changed the brain from HttpBrain -> Brain, which makes the
warnings in the log disapper. A more comprehensive work will be
to pull the latest policy change code from Oslo.

Bug #1156608

Change-Id: I9f63ec4c41025042725db9b2e7c8ffa3d91e0596
"}]
commit_message:
Fix 'Inheritance-based rule deprecated' log warning

A warning message appears in Cinder logs which state that
inheritance-based rules are deprecated and use default
Brain instead of HttpBrain. It looks like HttpBrain class
doesnt have any difference from Brain class, so changing
all the instances of HttpBrain to Brain shouldn't affect
anything and removes this warning from logs.

Digging further, I found out that the policy engine has
gone through a major rework in Oslo and Nova, and I think
at some point of time in future, we will also be moving
to use the latest policy engine code. In that way of
thinking, I guess this fix is acceptable for now.
Reference: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14122

Changed the brain from HttpBrain -> Brain, which makes the
warnings in the log disapper. A more comprehensive work will be
to pull the latest policy change code from Oslo.

Bug #1156608

Change-Id: I9f63ec4c41025042725db9b2e7c8ffa3d91e0596

The nodes.extra field was defined in 001_init, but missing from the
model. This patch corrects that.

commit_message:
Tweak volume commands and add k=v argparse action

Basic cleanups:
* change metadata to property
* add new KeyValueAction to parse the property options
* multiple properties can be set using multiple --property args
* consistent formatting
* do lookups for volume args

Change-Id: Ib6c43f01ad46b395aee8c61e886f42e2a5f5573e

commit_message:
Return 404 from delete of extra spec if not found

API service now returns a 404 if the volume type that the
user is trying to delete doesn't exist.

Fixed Bug 1090306.

Change-Id: I3c1d4fdac1c2492f532ab4dbfd5c7aaf0ffa6fa4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 12:59:50.000000000', 'message': 'Allow suppression of v1 API.

Fixes bug 1180567

The v1 API is on the deprecation path, so should not require
that distros have all its dependencies available.

Thus we add a new configuration option to allow the v1 app
creation to be suppressed.

Change-Id: Ib5af241a57f54754be534c9acb92a377362571e3
(cherry picked from commit e2c1de041ab8f1d3ce820c06875752ea46f13a97)
'}]
commit_message:
Allow suppression of v1 API.

Fixes bug 1180567

The v1 API is on the deprecation path, so should not require
that distros have all its dependencies available.

Thus we add a new configuration option to allow the v1 app
creation to be suppressed.

Change-Id: Ib5af241a57f54754be534c9acb92a377362571e3
(cherry picked from commit e2c1de041ab8f1d3ce820c06875752ea46f13a97)

commit_message:
Fix shell tests for older prettytable versions.

Fix the shell tests so they pass for all supported prettytable
versions, as per requirements.txt (>=0.6,<0.8).

Fixes bug: #1185580.

Change-Id: I8dca23faa3c178494656ebc8088b6d1994e9869f
