[{'account_id': 7395, 'date': '2013-05-01 17:40:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

The only change I see needed are the quotes around the second description field value.'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-01 18:00:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-01 18:01:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

Published by mistake.'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-05-02 08:59:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Nice first pass, Randall!

A couple of comments/questions from my side:
1) You used "resources" as a top-level element, but based on the Heat DSL wiki page I thought we were thinking about components as top-level entities (which in turns might contain resources). Both is fine with me (i.e. having a structure of resources and relations, or components and relations), but we have to agree on the terminology. My preference would be "components", since it is the more general term for me.
2) Is the "constraints" element meant to constrain the myinstance resource in general, or the compute requirement? I would think the latter, so should the constraints element be indented?
3) You are pushing the type (was AWS::EC2::Instance) into the requirement now, i.e. the myinstance resource itself is type-less. I am not sure yet of the implications. I don't have an answer yet for myself ... so consider this just a comment to think about.
4) Use of "options" for input parameters: I was thinking about just naming this "inputs" (like we have outputs), and leaving "options" for covering what CFN has as "Mappings", i.e. conditional value options that depend on inputs. What do you think?
5) When I look at outputs, it is not obvious that this represents a function. The Fn::Join in the AWS original example makes this very clear, so maybe we should also think about functions and how to render them in the YAML DSL.

Anyway, those were my comments from a first pass. Really good that you posted this first concrete example to get the discussion started!'}, {'account_id': 6434, 'date': '2013-05-02 15:58:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I second Thomas' question about whether the Constraints are meant (in this specific example) to constrain the compute resource specifically, in which case it seems either indentation in the yaml or some sort of mapping back to the resource being constrained could be useful.  Otherwise, this looks good to me.  Thank you for taking time to create the example."}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-02 16:03:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Thomas: 

1) You used "resources" as a top-level element, but based on the Heat DSL wiki page I thought we were thinking about components as top-level entities (which in turns might contain resources). Both is fine with me (i.e. having a structure of resources and relations, or components and relations), but we have to agree on the terminology. My preference would be "components", since it is the more general term for me. 

[RB] Yeah, I keep waffling there. The idea was to use "resources" as top level elements (analogous to "service" in the original proposal) and "components" for things contained by the resource (the software and config stuff for the resource). The term "facet" just came to mind for this as well. Thoughts?

2) Is the "constraints" element meant to constrain the myinstance resource in general, or the compute requirement? I would think the latter, so should the constraints element be indented?

[RB] the constraints set attribute values on the compute requirement. I'll refactor this to better reflect the type/constraint suggestion

 3) You are pushing the type (was AWS::EC2::Instance) into the requirement now, i.e. the myinstance resource itself is type-less. I am not sure yet of the implications. I don't have an answer yet for myself ... so consider this just a comment to think about. 

[RB] Essentially, yes. I'm thinking that the specific type/implementation of the resource is just another requirement against capability.

4) Use of "options" for input parameters: I was thinking about just naming this "inputs" (like we have outputs), and leaving "options" for covering what CFN has as "Mappings", i.e. conditional value options that depend on inputs. What do you think? 

[RB] I like it except that I'm not sure what it looks like when specific values for this information are supplied at provisioning time. In our internal stuff, the user sends the template and option values together in a compound document to deploy the "stack". This makes more sense to me over something like query params especially with possible future support for complex values for inputs.

5) When I look at outputs, it is not obvious that this represents a function. The Fn::Join in the AWS original example makes this very clear, so maybe we should also think about functions and how to render them in the YAML DSL.

[RB] Yeah, full disclosure, I just don't like the syntax. or that it has to be that explicit. This was my attempt and simplifying that without going full blown template substitution. Very open to alternatives here and may have to just settle for keeping things as they are for now. We don't have any equivalent feature in our internal prototypes, so I'm just riffing here.'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-02 16:07:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-02 16:08:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27934/3/check/gate-noop/1365 : SUCCESS in 00:00:00
'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-02 16:08:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

Updated based on input from Keith and Thomas.'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-05-02 20:06:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Some more thoughts regarding the points in my original review comment:

(1) I still see "component" as the more general term and "resource" as something a component uses. E.g. a software package could be a resource, or the keypair example on the wiki. Anyway, as long as we nail down one naming or the other, we can let the community decide/vote.

(2) The constraints look much better now. One enhancement I could imagine is to not just spell out the type as a bullet, but label each requirement. Imagine, for example, two requirements for storage (two volumes with different sizes) where you would want to distinguish the two, which would not work in the current syntax. Not sure how gerrit formats the snippet below, but I'll try.

 requires:
   a_server:
     type: os::nova::compute
     constraints:
     - keyname: {inputs: KeyName}

(3) Did not fully understand your reply to my comment. I see a resource/component without a type (but type only on the requires clause) as a custom, non-typed resource. Maybe as soon as we want to do something with MyInstance (e.g. use Chef), we would give it a type like "ChefManagedResource".

(4) Looks clear now IMO. I can try to use "options" for the CFN Mappings thing when I work on the Wordpress sample and see where we get.

(5) Still think the current encoding does not convey to the users they are looking at a function. What I do like is the {0} like format statements. What about some functionish string like:

 Fn::Format('ssh ec2-user@{0}', Fn::GetAtt('MyInstance', 'PublicIp'))'}, {'account_id': 7432, 'date': '2013-05-03 17:18:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

comments on the template.  dovetails with other folks' comments."}, {'account_id': 7432, 'date': '2013-05-03 17:31:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

just seen Thomas's update. feels simpler to me.

all the options for variable replacement / calling functions are unpleasant, even in yaml.  wdyt about something like:

    value: fn::template: "ssh ec2-user@${myinstance::PublicIp}"

keep the convention "fn::" to indicate a function (much as i don't like it, feels wise to have a way to disambiguate?), but use template vars as much as possible?

other comment is whether "constraint" is too opinionated.  i buried that observation in a line comment, but what if we wanted to set tags / vm-user-metadata on the compute instance?  that isn't a constraint per se.  they are just config parameters being passed to initialize the type.  we could just promote them (remove "contraint:"), or if it's clearer to keep them isolated use a less opinionated name ("config" is what we use in brooklyn).

btw -- feels like we are iterating properly now so +1 gerrit and thanks for starting it randall.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-06 14:54:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

I agree with Alex's comments."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-07 09:00:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Basically I agree with most of the comments so far, in particular:

- I'm also not sure about the "constraints" naming, I've given this a lot of thought and I'm having a hard time coming up with a better alternative than "properties".  I know this aligns with AWSish resource properties, but also it aligns with more general OO object-properties, to me it just makes sense, given that we're trying to define an object-based model, to reuse existing terminology rather than reinventing new terms which will just confuse people.  Also related, we don't only specify contraint-data associated with resources, there are more general "data associated with this object" uses, e.g resource metadata, which IMO will not fit well with the "constraints" naming

- I agree that the outputs data reference currently looks awkward and it would be much better if we can work out a way to specify the thing providing the data inline, rather than having some long list of backreference style references.

Overall great job so far, thanks to all for getting this discussion rolling! :)'}, {'account_id': 7514, 'date': '2013-05-09 22:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-10 18:17:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:03:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Restored

Whoops. Just meant to abandon that one patch set. Still getting used to Gerrit.'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:03:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:03:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27934/4/check/gate-noop/1499 : SUCCESS in 00:00:00
'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:06:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Work In Progress

This is starting to converge back to the original CFN version minus some key formatting, so I think this just may be too simple for meaningful discussion. I think discussion may need to move to the Wordpress templates unless people are satisfied with these latest changes.'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:06:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Ready For Review'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-05-13 09:45:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Randall: Agree that real progress on the DSL can only be made when looking at more than just a nova instance. Still I think we should nail down here how the most simple use case would be expressed.

In one of your comments on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28598 you talked about implicit assumptions on nova compute instances or rendering as "nested" resources. So I think this is somehow related.'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-22 20:16:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 20:16:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

commit_message:
Initial Modular L2 plugin implementation.

The Modular L2 Plugin uses drivers to support separately extensible
sets of network types and of mechanisms for accessing networks of
those types. This is an initial implementation that has been tested
with the openvswitch and linuxbridge agents, and should also work with
the hyperv agent. See quantum/plugins/ml2/README for details.

Implements: blueprint modular-l2
Change-Id: Ia8cae480180f0990af7d5e5e56f29eaeac205e0e

commit_message:
Fix problem with colorizer and failed tests

The colorizer script is not handling failed tests correctly
because it is receiving some unexpected input when they happen.
This change allows colorizer to handle the problem and complete
successfully.

Fixes bug 1183602

Change-Id: I317229b5d4f1756a1564548bec58b67db5573e9e

[{'created': '2013-05-30 13:37:37.000000000', 'message': 'Configurable external gateway modes

Blueprint l3-ext-gw-modes

This patch introduces an API extension for enabling or disabling
source/destination NAT on the router gateway interface, and implements
support for this extension in the l3 agent, which has also been
refactored in order to ensure SNAT rules are applied (or removed)
in a single place in the process_router routine.
The patch therefore enables the extension on all plugins which
leverage this agent.
In this patch the validate_boolean function is re-introduced, as it
used for validating a field of the external_gateway_info dict.
The resource extension process is also slightly changed so that an
API extension can specify which extension should be processed before
its attributes can be processed. This is needed to ensure the
proper validator for external_gateway_info is installed.

Change-Id: Ia80cb56135229366b1706dd3c6d366e40cde1500
'}]
commit_message:
Configurable external gateway modes

Blueprint l3-ext-gw-modes

This patch introduces an API extension for enabling or disabling
source/destination NAT on the router gateway interface, and implements
support for this extension in the l3 agent, which has also been
refactored in order to ensure SNAT rules are applied (or removed)
in a single place in the process_router routine.
The patch therefore enables the extension on all plugins which
leverage this agent.
In this patch the validate_boolean function is re-introduced, as it
used for validating a field of the external_gateway_info dict.
The resource extension process is also slightly changed so that an
API extension can specify which extension should be processed before
its attributes can be processed. This is needed to ensure the
proper validator for external_gateway_info is installed.

Change-Id: Ia80cb56135229366b1706dd3c6d366e40cde1500

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names.

Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Change-Id: I31fa9fb5e6b1e4656424b4a56f58b71903641875
Fixes: bug #1179008

Wouldn't it be better to support a backslash escape character, allowing

commit_message:
Support for NFS shares with spaces in path.

Unescape share address string listed in nfs_shares_config so that
'x.y.z.w:/foo\040bar' would become 'x.y.z.w:/foo bar' to support
mounting shares with spaces in name.
Use stat command to get available and total space on device instead
of df since it's output is easier to parse.

Fixes: bug #1180984
Change-Id: I552aba91ca8db14130f854c739594a818186bbe2

subject: Fixes 3PAR Host already exists error.

commit_message:
Fixes 3PAR Host already exists error.

Fixed “Host already exists” error by,
* Screen scraping error message and extracting the host name
used by the 3PAR backend.
* Cache the host name used by the 3PAR backend for subsequent
methods using host name.
* After a restart, and 3PAR host name it no longer available,
retrieve 3PAR host name using wwn/iqn, if a terminate_connection
fails.

Fixes bug 1182134

Change-Id: Ia08a311af168ae19dbe7c1405db9c606fd878e53

The patch sets the process group id to its process id. Note that this
change raises an OSError in Glance's tests because they are run under
Popen and using glance-control, which changes children's session ids and
other parameters. That for, setpgid is inside a try / except and falls
back to 0.

Fixes bug 1068051

NOTE: This issue is not affecting production/stable environments (no comments
related to that have been made) but the issue is there and raises under
certain cases.

The backport is being suggested because this is, most likely, happening
under the hoods without users even noticing it.

Change-Id: Ie9ed044e08053d0067396138de0bd124326aa1a5
Cherry-picked: a9f9f137bb44bd5727854f416f8b0c7c3df81867

commit_message:
Call os.kill for each child instead of the process group

The patch sets the process group id to its process id. Note that this
change raises an OSError in Glance's tests because they are run under
Popen and using glance-control, which changes children's session ids and
other parameters. That for, setpgid is inside a try / except and falls
back to 0.

Fixes bug 1068051

NOTE: This issue is not affecting production/stable environments (no comments
related to that have been made) but the issue is there and raises under
certain cases.

The backport is being suggested because this is, most likely, happening
under the hoods without users even noticing it.

Change-Id: Ie9ed044e08053d0067396138de0bd124326aa1a5
Cherry-picked: a9f9f137bb44bd5727854f416f8b0c7c3df81867

commit_message:
Implementation of proxy affinity for requests.

* Configurable parameter region was added in proxy-server
  configuration file.
* New configurable algorithm for iter_nodes function generate nodes
  according to following variants:
    - only local nodes;
    - local nodes and then remote nodes;
    - default behavior.
* Implementation get_local_nodes function for collecting local nodes
  equal by number of replicas.
* Get_nodes was replacement by get_local_nodes with parameter regions
  in some places of code.
* Using configurable iter_nodes for some requests according to proxy
  affinity implementation.
* Add header 'x-auto-create-on-handoff' for PUT and DELETE at handoffs
  nodes.
* Proxy affinity for PUT, GET, HEAD, POST, DELETE requests for
  account-, container-, object- servers for region architecture.

Change-Id: I4067b64e68b3db4a0e5dfa532d81dbec415edb6e
Implements: blueprint proxy-affinity
Implements: blueprint proxy-affinity-writes
Implements: blueprint multi-region

[{'created': '2013-05-06 07:28:27.000000000', 'message': "Don't raise HTTPForbidden on a multitenant environment

When getting public images in a multi-tenant environment, Swift raises
HTTPForbidden for chuncked images.

Based on swift documentation, rlistings directive turns listings on,
which is the desired behavior in this case.

Fixes bug 1170156

NOTE: Swift guys where consulted about this fix.

Change-Id: I149f702d5b3ebae73b04deed4809939ab43c6adc
Cherry-picked: 2d492e04be9e386e402ddde248d9a55c8d04a2bb
"}]
commit_message:
Don't raise HTTPForbidden on a multitenant environment

When getting public images in a multi-tenant environment, Swift raises
HTTPForbidden for chuncked images.

Based on swift documentation, rlistings directive turns listings on,
which is the desired behavior in this case.

Fixes bug 1170156

NOTE: Swift guys where consulted about this fix.

Change-Id: I149f702d5b3ebae73b04deed4809939ab43c6adc
Cherry-picked: 2d492e04be9e386e402ddde248d9a55c8d04a2bb

This patch moves the monkey_patch call into the glance scripts that
needs libs to be monkey_patched. This seems to be a good practice and
has given good results for other projects as well.

This change is needed  to avoid loading / initializing modules
before other libs are patched. For example: logging module.

Fixes bug 1163722

Change-Id: Idee486851606d765fb11598967a4f7d56cf46c97
Cherry-picked: 1c5a4d2bdcc00439b5e351d14f47deebdedcb001
'}]
commit_message:
Call monkey_patch before other modules are loaded

This patch moves the monkey_patch call into the glance scripts that
needs libs to be monkey_patched. This seems to be a good practice and
has given good results for other projects as well.

This change is needed  to avoid loading / initializing modules
before other libs are patched. For example: logging module.

Fixes bug 1163722

Change-Id: Idee486851606d765fb11598967a4f7d56cf46c97
Cherry-picked: 1c5a4d2bdcc00439b5e351d14f47deebdedcb001

subject: Add a separate Template class for the HOT format
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 2834, 'name': 'Steven Dake', 'email': 'steven.dake@gmail.com', 'username': 'sdake'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 4328, 'name': 'Steven Hardy', 'email': 'shardy@redhat.com', 'username': 'shardy'}, {'_account_id': 4715, 'name': 'Angus Salkeld', 'email': 'asalkeld@redhat.com', 'username': 'asalkeld'}, {'_account_id': 7193, 'name': 'Thomas Spatzier', 'email': 'thomas.spatzier@icloud.com', 'username': 'thomasspatzier'}, {'_account_id': 7385, 'name': 'Thomas Herve', 'email': 'therve@redhat.com', 'username': 'therve'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-24 14:04:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-05-24 15:39:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

That in deed looks like a good place to handle the difference between the template format. At least from what I know about the Heat code after the couple of days I've been looking into it.

From my understanding that would give us more flexibility of handling differences other than just naming in the HOT template, e.g. by overriding the method for resolving parameters refs etc. in case HOT does those things differently."}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-05-24 16:12:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

... something that just came to my mind: we might still need a little change in template_format.py for what is currently done in default_for_missing. Like only if neither HeatTemplateFormatVersion nor heat_template_version are present assume a default.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-26 13:05:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

So, this looks good to me, and it's definitely a cleaner and less hacky approach.

But.. we do need to ensure we're OK with baking this change into the engine, as previously we'd discussed a translation-plugin system at the API level, which would be possible with the mangle-template approach in my patch, but much more difficult with this approach.

Provided we're happy to permanently wire in the HOT template parser to the engine (and there are definitely advantages to doing that), then this gets my +2 and I can abandon my patch.

Thanks Zane for posting this, good to get the discussion going so we can figure out the best way to proceed with this. :)"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-27 11:19:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Mailing list discussion: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-May/009551.html'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-05-28 18:22:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2013-05-28 18:48:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think your change makes sense, I would just argue that the inheritance hierarchy is a bit weird (the fact that HOTemplate is-a Template, which is a CFN template). Maybe in the long term we should have a base class with common functionalities instead?

I also don't like using __new__ much, but I suppose it reduces the number of places we have to update instantiations."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-29 06:21:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thomas H - I completely agree, long term Template should be a common base class with CfnTemplate and HOTemplate subclasses, in separate files (maybe even loaded dynamically as plugins).

This is kind of a proof-of-concept to illustrate the idea.'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-05-29 20:11:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-30 10:20:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Ok, approving this so we can iterate over subsequent additions to the new HOT template class.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 10:20:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 4328, 'name': 'Steven Hardy', 'email': 'shardy@redhat.com', 'username': 'shardy'}, {'_account_id': 4571, 'name': 'Steve Baker', 'email': 'sbaker@redhat.com', 'username': 'steve-stevebaker'}, {'_account_id': 4715, 'name': 'Angus Salkeld', 'email': 'asalkeld@redhat.com', 'username': 'asalkeld'}, {'_account_id': 6434, 'name': 'keith-bray', 'email': 'kebray@gmail.com', 'username': 'keith-bray'}, {'_account_id': 6488, 'name': 'Clint Byrum', 'email': 'clint@fewbar.com', 'username': 'clint-fewbar'}, {'_account_id': 7193, 'name': 'Thomas Spatzier', 'email': 'thomas.spatzier@icloud.com', 'username': 'thomasspatzier'}, {'_account_id': 7256, 'name': 'Randall Burt', 'email': 'randall.burt@rackspace.com', 'username': 'randall-burt'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-24 09:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30405/1/check/gate-heat-pep8/3166 : SUCCESS in 1m 25s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30405/1/check/gate-heat-python26/3121 : SUCCESS in 1m 53s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30405/1/check/gate-heat-python27/3120 : SUCCESS in 1m 32s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30405/1/check/dev-heat-coverage/1524 : SUCCESS in 2m 46s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-05-24 10:32:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

This patch looks good to me; I think I can get started with BP hot-hello-world based on that.

I added one inline comment with a question more for educational purposes.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-24 11:06:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-24 12:36:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I'm not against this as a short term hack to allow experimentation, but here is another option:

Currently in the engine a template is represented by a Template object. Mostly we access this object as if it were the template dictionary (i.e. we do tmpl['Resources'] or whatever). It seems to me that, long-term, it would make more sense to support two different template formats by having two different Template classes.

A first-cut implementation would be to just override __getitem__ in the HOTemplate to convert keys to lowercase before grabbing them from the dictionary (i.e. tmpl['Resources'] actually grabs tmpl['resources']). Long term, we could gradually move everything in the engine over to more programmatic ways of accessing the data (i.e. tmpl.resources()) that would give us a lot more flexibility in a less hacky way.

The big change this involves is that the discrimination between the two formats happens only after the template gets to the engine, not in the API. There may be downsides to that, although I can't think of them at the moment."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-24 13:48:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-24 14:13:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Draft of my suggested first cut in the comment above:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30439/'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-05-24 14:14:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

The proposal that Zane made also sounds interesting to me, and could in fact be the better longer term solution. And I mean Steven's patch was really just thought to be a an initial short term hook that would need to evolve. And the good it that it already gave me some good pointers into the code so I can start digging :-)

So options seem to be now: keep this initial patch and do the cleanup (follow Zane's proposal) while working on the hot-hello-world BP - or change the patch right away?"}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-05-24 14:33:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
engine : PoC initial template_format parser for HOT template

Based on the draft templates posted, this is a super-minimal example of
where we can plug in the DSL/HOT translator in a non-intrusive way.
Initially the translation will be from HOT to our internal template
model, and over time, we could potentially use a similar _parse_cfn
function to somewhat de-aws-ify the engine

provides a starting point for blueprint: hot-hello-world

Change-Id: I7ed48dfa8037f7058883afa6a911927ca808f5bb

commit_message:
Fix config drive code logical error.

Image id has changed to uuid, so bool value can't be a image ID
any more, remove unnecessary test code.

fix bug #1181991

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-29 21:48:45.000000000', 'message': "Don't delete sys_meta on instance delete

Unfortunately, we require to access instance_system_metadata to get
data (specifically at least instance_type data) for instances that have
been deleted.

There's 2 cases where this is true:

1) nova-api supports showing deleting instances when you specify a
'changes-since' param.
2) The _usage_audit_log periodic task pulls all instances during the
audit period, which includes instances that have been deleted during
that period.

This reverts commit 17bca438954638d74035d560e826a26a532b3ea3, which was
attempting to fix a bug where we leave instance_system_metadata entries
undeleted from the DB.  There's not an easy way to query for the deleted
sys_meta data in an efficient manner, and leaving the entries undeleted is
the lesser of the 2 evils for now.

Fixes bug 1185190

Change-Id: I898f0546c49126dcc56a4237120082f95dc82304
(cherry picked from commit 4885aa28706a1858f4fc51a0d2c661eec05139c0)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't delete sys_meta on instance delete

Unfortunately, we require to access instance_system_metadata to get
data (specifically at least instance_type data) for instances that have
been deleted.

There's 2 cases where this is true:

1) nova-api supports showing deleting instances when you specify a
'changes-since' param.
2) The _usage_audit_log periodic task pulls all instances during the
audit period, which includes instances that have been deleted during
that period.

This reverts commit 17bca438954638d74035d560e826a26a532b3ea3, which was
attempting to fix a bug where we leave instance_system_metadata entries
undeleted from the DB.  There's not an easy way to query for the deleted
sys_meta data in an efficient manner, and leaving the entries undeleted is
the lesser of the 2 evils for now.

Fixes bug 1185190

Change-Id: I898f0546c49126dcc56a4237120082f95dc82304
(cherry picked from commit 4885aa28706a1858f4fc51a0d2c661eec05139c0)

commit_message:
Remove character causing knife cookbook upload to fail.

This mystery character causes knife cookbook upload to fail with ../ruby-1.9.3-p429/gems/chef-11.4.4/lib/chef/cookbook/metadata.rb:444:in `encode\': "\xE2" on US-ASCII (Encoding::InvalidByteSequenceError). Whatever it is gets rolled up when the metadata.rb imports the README.md in the long_description.

Change-Id: I13cd55bee3a98ac0bb0a50abc4e3fef2d61120ba

commit_message:
Use exec_dirs for rootwrap commands

Avoid depending on platform specific paths for rootwrap
by using exec_dirs in rootwrap. Fixes rootwrap configuration
for SUSE.

Fixes bug #1156044

Change-Id: I54d082c543fd84b40db0caa3571300ac0bb07b57

'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-21 09:33:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Would it be better to have a wsgi package with server.py and serializer.py ?

Also, I'd like to see the Serializer / DeSerializer thing evolve a bit. I personally don't like having to specify both the serializer and deserializer in the configuration file. Would it be possible to create a common "Transformer" class that serializers can inherit from?

  class Transformer(object):

    def serialize(...):
      pass

    def deserialize(..):
      pass

Does that make sense?'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2013-05-21 11:35:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the comment Flavio. I think it definitely makes sense and I'm ok with having common Transformer interface. The only concern I have is about module namings as we don't want to put all (de)serializers into a separate file but only those that should be configurable - body (de)serializers."}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2013-05-21 11:37:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Would be great to see other reviewers opinions on this. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-22 05:08:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Flavio, I do think it would be better if the serializer and deserializer would be in a single class but I don't think it is a must for now. Thank you for bringing up the topic.

I think what's more important is to have projects first adapt oslo.wsgi to prevent further diversion of the wsgi module. After that we can be sure the enhancements we make can be propagated.

So for this patch, the motive was to let quantum use oslo.wsgi by removing wsgi's dependency on the standard xml module. And I think it does that perfectly.

Follow up work should be defining a high level procedure of serializing and deserializing which will be defined by oslo. By then I think we should find out a way to implement the Transformer class.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-29 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-29 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2013-05-29 06:35:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Restored

Waiting for Flavio opinion'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-29 11:11:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Wow, sorry it took me so long! T_T

Well, that's actually something that concerns me. I mean, if we let this land and then decide to change the API that will end up being a backward incompatible change which would make the improvement more complex.

My point is, if it makes sense and we're planning to do it anyway, then why not doing it before people start using the wsgi module? Is this code being used? If not, it seems like the change could be made.

Also, I don't think adding 4 new config variables is the way to go, it would be better to have something that actually is more object oriented and generic enough to fit most projects. Can we think about this a bit more? IRC Discussion? -dev thread?"}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-05-29 12:11:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'd also like to echo the concern about making sure this is the direction we really want to go.  I think having four config variables is too many and I also have concerns about standalone classes for serialization and deserialization.  

Using Quantum as an example there is lots of cruft that is required to make the generic serializers even work properly.  Currently, there is discussion amongst several Quantum devs that a different way of serialization should be proposed for the I-cycle."}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2013-05-29 12:56:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the inputs guys. So Mark do you agree with the approach proposed by Flavio in his first comment (Transformer class) and thus having only two config variables?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-29 13:08:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

We don't want projects using the wsgi module any more, so I don't think we need to keep improving it. New API development should be shifting to Pecan/WSME.

https://etherpad.openstack.org/havana-common-wsgi"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-29 13:12:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

@Doug

good point, I didn't even know there was an etherpad for that"}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2013-05-30 07:22:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

New API development should be shifting to Pecan/WSME'}]

[{'created': '2013-05-29 07:41:46.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up DB migrations when running unit tests

When doing development work, all kinds of issue can result when moving
between versions of the code that have added/removed DB migration scripts
if the compiled .pyc files are left behind. To save the need to do this
manually, remove all of the .pyc files when the unit tests are run.

Change-Id: Ia4bc889edeeed499e5fc2172d5f7c1b4e693a27b
'}]
commit_message:
Clean up DB migrations when running unit tests

When doing development work, all kinds of issue can result when moving
between versions of the code that have added/removed DB migration scripts
if the compiled .pyc files are left behind. To save the need to do this
manually, remove all of the .pyc files when the unit tests are run.

Change-Id: Ia4bc889edeeed499e5fc2172d5f7c1b4e693a27b

All of the horizon client API modules, except for keystone, default to
using the publicURL value from the service catalog when looking up url
values.  There are use cases where the publicURL is not exposed or

to fail.

using the publicURL value from the service catalog when looking up url
values.  There are use cases where the publicURL is not exposed or

commit_message:
horizon should default to internalURL in 'url_for' function

All of the horizon client API modules, except for keystone, default to
using the publicURL value from the service catalog when looking up url
values.  There are use cases where the publicURL is not exposed or
defined, but leaving publicURL undefined causes some critical operations
to fail.

The horizon keystone client defaults to internalURL, which should be
the rule for all horizon intra-service communications.

Fixes Bug:  #1178690

Change-Id: Ia2f2bf0ce93b865dd9a1954fcdd3711089782671

commit_message:
Fix functional tests with keystone

Functional tests fail when keystone is used instead of tempauth.
swift_test_client.py doesn't handle properly utf-8 strings, and
testPUT method is specific to tempauth.

Change-Id: I909741408a539ed25956c3c591dfee3a107424ba
Fixes: bug 1176030

[{'account_id': 4419, 'date': '2013-04-30 12:19:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Just getting feedback at this stage.

Should it be done in cell weights and filters ? or is it better hard coded like this.

What does it mean if a child cell fails to notify the parent ? should builds stop going there ? or should we just be more alert for build failures ..'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2013-04-30 12:28:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

some nits.."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-30 13:01:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

"}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-04-30 14:54:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It feels like we need to get generic cell filters & weights merged first.  Not sure if that work is still blocked.'}, {'account_id': 4419, 'date': '2013-04-30 21:18:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks belliot.

Yeah, cells weights and filters is still blocked by this blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/entrypoints-plugins

That changes the way all (including host scheduler) weights and filters are loaded in nova.

I'd like to see if this can go through without weights and filters. My contention being that it's like an 'always-on' filter.

Unless someone could foresee a situation where you'd still want to send builds to a cell that you haven't heard from and all info we have for it is out of date, I'd like to push this through without waiting for filters."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-04-30 22:42:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

filters and weights are not really blocked.  I theoretically have permission to push it in without entrypoints.  I was working on it yesterday.  I just need to add a couple of tests before I put it up for review.

I definitely think this is better done with filters."}, {'account_id': 4419, 'date': '2013-05-01 04:23:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-01 05:08:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27808/2/check/gate-nova-pep8/25135 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/27808/2/check/gate-nova-python26-centos6/32 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/27808/2/check/gate-nova-python27/20849 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/27808/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/20170 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/27808/2/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/1942 : FAILURE (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/27808/2/check/gate-nova-pylint/10918 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4419, 'date': '2013-05-01 07:11:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

Thanks Boris. I fixed up those inline suggestions.'}, {'account_id': 4419, 'date': '2013-05-01 07:43:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think this is better hard coded than as a filter.

 * Filters are by nature plugins, and therefore optional. I can't foresee a situation where you'd ever want to turn this code off.
 * This code doesn't just filter, but also sends out notifications.
 * With host scheduler there have been performance issues with the amount of filters and weights applied. I don't want to add make it a filter unnecessarily.

I'm happy to go with filters if anyone can foresee a situation where:

 1. Your child cell stops updating the parent with it's capabilities and capacities.
 2. You don't know how much space is in that child cell still.
 3. You still want to send new builds there."}, {'account_id': 5586, 'date': '2013-05-01 12:00:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I agree with Matthew Sherborne. I also think this should be  an 'always-on' filter."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-05-15 17:42:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-16 13:17:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It just seems like a nicer code layout to do this as a filter.  It's also how the host scheduler works."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:30:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I submitted a very similar patch using the new cell weights:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29949/"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:23:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

Prefer Brian's patch that uses the weights.."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-30 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

commit_message:
Monitoring for mute child cells

Adds a config option: child_cell_timeout

If a child cell does not notify its parent about capacities or
capabilities in 'child_cell_timeout' seconds, the parent cell will
publish a notification and stop sending builds to that cell until it
hears from it again.

Adds some extra tests to CellsStateManager.

Fixes bug 1174726

Change-Id: I6fb9b56c52620d2bc73279afd00a7c5f24dfb4b7

messages:

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/30111/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/24417 : FAILURE in 10m 45s
"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-05-30 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi,
This is how Quantum is designed. There may be an external service that provides the DHCP service.
If you want to have the allocation of a port without an IP address then you should not create a subnet.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-05-30 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

since the bug is marked as invalid.'}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-05-30 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the speedy response, i didn't want to create a port without an IP, i just wanted to make sense of what disable-dhcp should mean ? and why nova is lying about VM having an IP ? 

Because as i understood it, no DHCP server will be serving IPs for that sub-network, so if a user choose to launch a VM in the parent network, what make sense IMHO, is for the VM to get an IP only from other child subnets with DHCP enabled, if there is more than one subnet, or to get no IP (like in the bug reported example).

Because right now, from a cloud user perspective, he will see in "nova list" that his newly spawned VM has an IP (but it didn't get an IP), so he may try to ssh to it, ping it ... and it will fail. Confusing right ?

So i am not sure how this can be a design decision: "Allocate IP from subnet even thew **by default** the VM will not get this IP".

And please correct me if i am wrong, thanks.'}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-05-30 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

If i was not mistaken and this is a real bug, i will add tests in the next commit. 

I believe that this patch will probably fail to build by jenkins.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-30 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-30 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-22 01:36:28.000000000', 'message': 'python3: Add compat layer for python2/python3

Add a compatibility module that provides a useful
abstraction layer over the differences between
different python versions.

This is based off of python-webob which has its
own compatibility layer. This removes the need
for openstack projects to depend on python-six
for compatibility.

Change-Id: Ia9a081fc670e27db0b7b2d0c9b50baf409ce7268
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
python3: Add compat layer for python2/python3

Add a compatibility module that provides a useful
abstraction layer over the differences between
different python versions.

This is based off of python-webob which has its
own compatibility layer. This removes the need
for openstack projects to depend on python-six
for compatibility.

Change-Id: Ia9a081fc670e27db0b7b2d0c9b50baf409ce7268
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-14 13:45:54.000000000', 'message': 'Flavor's function show() should not include those deleted flavors.

There is a bug in nova client. Suppose we have two flavors A and B,
where A's name = <name>, B's id = <id> and <name> = <id>, and flavor
A exists while flavor B has been deleted before.

Because the flavor function show() will get B by id, when running
"nova flavor-delete <name>" to delete A, find_resource() in utils.py
will get B, deleting B again will cause an exception.
However, the flavor A is not deleted, which isn't expected.

Change-Id: I73789b336c52e66dd49592b9562f70a86cde6d5b
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Flavor's function show() should not include those deleted flavors.

There is a bug in nova client. Suppose we have two flavors A and B,
where A's name = <name>, B's id = <id> and <name> = <id>, and flavor
A exists while flavor B has been deleted before.

Because the flavor function show() will get B by id, when running
"nova flavor-delete <name>" to delete A, find_resource() in utils.py
will get B, deleting B again will cause an exception.
However, the flavor A is not deleted, which isn't expected.

Change-Id: I73789b336c52e66dd49592b9562f70a86cde6d5b
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Move auth_token middleware from admin user to an RBAC policy

Before this patch auth_token middleware required admin user credentials
stored in assorted config files. With this patch only non-admin user
credentials are needed. The revocation_list and validate_token commands
use an policy.json rule, to only allow these commands if you are in have the
service role.

Rule used:
    "service_role": [["role:service"]],
    "service_or_admin": [["rule:admin_required"], ["rule:service_role"]],

Added the policy wrapper on the validate functions.

Fixes bug 1153789

Change-Id: I43986e26b16aa5213ad2536a0d07d942bf3dbbbb

https://github.com/openshift/openshift-extras/tree/enterprise-1.1/node-manager

commit_message:
Move autoscaling metrics from nodes to broker.

Broker has scripts /etc/heat/notify-scale-up and /etc/heat/notify-scale-down
which will trigger heat autoscaling.

Scaling decisions will be made within the broker itself using its own
platform agnostic scaling scripts:
https://github.com/openshift/openshift-extras/tree/enterprise-1.1/node-manager

This template has successfully scaled up from 1 to 3 nodes, and scaled back
down to 1 by manually executing notify-scale-up and notify-scale-down.

Change-Id: Idb9920438bbe598b610efc8eca5bc158181b74a7

maintenance burden.

commit_message:
Add node as instance attribute for notification

Fix bug 1181900

In havana release, node is not set as instance attribute and node
indicates the hypervisor where the instance reside in, we should
set node as instance attribute for notification.

Change-Id: I872fba626ef3e321d88cf60fc730df6cf4612c86

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-29 13:57:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix colorizier thowing exception when a test fails

This failure in colorizier was hidding the actual error
in the tests. If we ran enough tests it also became difficult
to see which test had actually failed.

Fixes: bug 1183602

Change-Id: I806da8f13040b38258de7f3e0fa7b62700bdcead
'}]
commit_message:
Fix colorizier thowing exception when a test fails

This failure in colorizier was hidding the actual error
in the tests. If we ran enough tests it also became difficult
to see which test had actually failed.

Fixes: bug 1183602

Change-Id: I806da8f13040b38258de7f3e0fa7b62700bdcead

commit_message:
No relevant message when stop a stopped VM

When user tries to stop a stopped VM, there is no need to stop it again,
and We need return it's vm_state.

Fixes bug 1181934

Change-Id: I71772dfcead440cb49b6ccdbb4e1a891475bb75e

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-23 05:21:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: (2 inline comments)

Couple things inline.  Also had a crazy idea when I was driving around tonight (yes, I think about work too much).  What do you think about obj.f.<fieldname> to access object data?  I don't *really* like it.  However, it prevents us from having to worry about namespace problems in the future.

For example, I could see 'load' being a completely reasonable field name... yet we have it as a method... so we'd have to force the field to be named something else.  Same with 'version', although this one is our own attribute, not a method.  I don't know if it would be *that* big of a deal that we can't use those names as fields within the code.. (the DB columns could still use those names, of course)...  But... I thought I'd throw it out there for feedback."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-05-23 06:25:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: (2 inline comments)

Just a few questions, not sure if the novaobject model allows for inheritance to work correctly (due to the fields dict), any thoughts there? Also I am a little confused by the context hiding in the object itself. Why is that needed? I also second chris b's question about attr names, it seems like we can't allow 'load, context, changed_fields, to_primitive, save, what_changed' and a few others to ever be in the fields dictionary to avoid conflicts and/or function/attr collisions/overwriting."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:39:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: (4 inline comments)

Personally, I *really* don't like the foo.f.field namespace thing. I'd much rather make all the inbuilt methods and attributes be prefixed with _ or _obj_ or something like that.

If folks think that's important, then I can spin something."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:04:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:08:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:10:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (2 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-25 00:42:37.000000000', 'message': "Way early hacky PoC of object model silliness

This is entirely un-mergeable as it is, and is just for demonstrating
one way to do this. It's just hacked together enough to barely work.
Be nice :)

This adds nova/object.py (yes, I know we can't call it that), which is
a dumping ground for almost everything in the patch. It adds:

1. A NovaObject thingy which handles (de-)hydration stuff
2. A NovaObjectVersion thingy which is just a dict-to-attribute helper
   that lets me define properties to enforce data types
3. A half implementation of the Migration object for demonstration
4. A couple of decorators that help me avoid basically any changes to
   existing stuff (for transition)
5. A subclass of RpcProxy that handles the magic (de-)serialization of
   NovaObject items over the wire, to avoid touching common bits.
6. Changes to make conductor's migration_get() method use the new scheme.

It doesn't account for any RPC version changes that will need to be done.
Things are all dumped into object.py instead of where they should be.

The actual object version stuff is completely un-thought-out and really
only there to get the syntax down to roughly what I think it should
look like.

Change-Id: Iecd54ca22666f730c41d2278f74b86d922624a4e

commit_message:
Add base object model

This adds the base infrastructure for a unified object model in
Nova. It provides a somewhat-magical metaclass which serves to
automatically register objects that are capable of being remoted.
Magic remoting of methods happens via two decorators, allowing
a given nova service to globally declare that such actions should
happen over RPC to avoid DB accesses.

For more details, see blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: Iecd54ca22666f730c41d2278f74b86d922624a4e

commit_message:
Refactor db_base_plugin_v2 and to remove code duplication

fixes bug 1104379

Introduce CommonDbMixin which includes utility methods
to manipulate model queries.

Change-Id: Ib3602321328cbf945358e0581ecc649e3f69d196

commit_message:
Delegate authentication to quantumclient

Quantumclient can deal with authentication, getting the token and
refreshing it when needed. There should be no need for nova to do
those explicitly. Additionally nova can save some time not having
to recreate the Client object on each request.

Fix a couple of places that relied on the exceptions module being
imported inside quantumv2.

Part of blueprint fewer-networking-token-checks
Fixed bug 1177579

if you do not daemonize the print and error thread, the parent thread will wait and ctrl-C interrupt will never work.
The whole reason of not to use join() and daemonizing the 
print and error threads is to allow ctrl-C to work.
Otherwise, looking at the the patch set #1 which use join and
non-daemonized thread, but unfortunately, that makes ctrl-C not working.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-02-26 19:35:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-04-30 14:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This can stil hang when interrupted with Ctrl-C.  There were four files getting uploaded, zeroes{1,2,3,4}, all 20 MiB.  I instrumented both signal handlers to print stack traces to stderr.  I also had "swift" instrumented for profiling, but that's not relevant here.

  $ time PYTHONPATH=. bin/swift -A http://192.168.22.2:8080/auth/v1.0 -U test:tester -K testing upload --object-threads=2 cont zeroes*
    (profling dumped to /tmp/upload.prof)
  zeroes1
  zeroes2
  ^C  File "bin/swift", line 1339, in <module>
      sleep(0.5)
  Attempting graceful exit. Press Ctrl-C again to exit immediately.

[... time passes ...]

  ^C  File "bin/swift", line 1339, in <module>
      sleep(0.5)
    File "bin/swift", line 110, in attempt_graceful_exit
      signal.pause()
  
  real	0m46.837s
  user	0m0.196s
  sys	0m0.100s

Note that the last Ctrl-C which actually exited had been stuck in that same sleep(0.5)'ing loop.  I haven't isolated the root cause, but can you see if you can reproduce this problem?'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-04-30 14:48:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (1 inline comment)

I think I found the cause:

  signal.pause()

in attempt_graceful_exit()'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-04-30 14:57:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (1 inline comment)

Also, the exit condition for that main while loop seems dubious.  I instrumented the while loop to print its conditions each iteration (which is how I noticed that the graceful-exit signal handler was wedging the main thread with signal.pause()).  I also instrumented the graceful-exit signal handler to inject something into each queue with a normal priority to emulate a queue item getting stuck onto the queue between the graceful exit signal sticking in the thread-stop message and the thread pulling that message off the queue and exiting.  That's theoretically possible, and if it happens, "swift" will hang (see below).

If the printing and error threads are dead, it doesn't matter if the queues are empty, so all queue threads being dead should exit regardless of queue length.

  $ time PYTHONPATH=. bin/swift -A http://192.168.22.2:8080/auth/v1.0 -U test:tester -K testing upload --object-threads=2 cont zeroes*
  (4326899712; _object_job)  starting
   (4331106304; _object_job)  starting
    (profling dumped to /tmp/upload.prof)
  (4335312896; _print)  starting
   (4339519488; _error)  starting
  (140735151628672; main)  len(threading_enumerate()) = 5; error_queue: empty; print_queue: empty
  zeroes2
  zeroes1
  (140735151628672; main)  len(threading_enumerate()) = 5; error_queue: empty; print_queue: empty
  ^C  File "bin/swift", line 1350, in <module>
      sleep(0.5)
  Attempting graceful exit. Press Ctrl-C again to exit immediately.
  (4335312896; _print)  breaking from StopWorkerThreadSignal
  (4339519488; _error)  breaking from StopWorkerThreadSignal
  (140735151628672; main)  len(threading_enumerate()) = 3; error_queue: NOT empty; print_queue: NOT empty
  (140735151628672; main)  len(threading_enumerate()) = 3; error_queue: NOT empty; print_queue: NOT empty
  (140735151628672; main)  len(threading_enumerate()) = 3; error_queue: NOT empty; print_queue: NOT empty
  ...
  (4331106304; _object_job)  breaking from StopWorkerThreadSignal
  (4326899712; _object_job)  breaking from StopWorkerThreadSignal
  (140735151628672; main)  len(threading_enumerate()) = 1; error_queue: NOT empty; print_queue: NOT empty
  (140735151628672; main)  len(threading_enumerate()) = 1; error_queue: NOT empty; print_queue: NOT empty
  (140735151628672; main)  len(threading_enumerate()) = 1; error_queue: NOT empty; print_queue: NOT empty
  ... (forever)
  ^C  File "bin/swift", line 1350, in <module>
      sleep(0.5)
  
  real	0m11.377s
  user	0m0.199s
  sys	0m0.099s'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-04-30 21:08:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Darrell, if we do not use signal.pause(), then it is not
really a graceful exit even if we put the stop signal in the
queue, when the main thread ends, the child threads will end
regardless their status. That makes sending a stop signal
to the queue almost like a fake. This patch does not change
the ctrl-C behavior at all. That is for the first ctrl-C, 
the program will start sending the stop signal to queue
and wait for the second ctrl-C to end, if the user press 
ctrl-c again without wait, then entire program ends. 

If the user waits long enough after first ctrl-c, then all
child threads will finish the job it took and will not
start a new one. In either case, two ctrl-C end the program.

If this is not what you expected behavior, we can talk more.
ctrl-c again.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-04-30 22:59:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

The hanging problem when specifying uploads with a lot of segments illustrates the problem with stopping the threads with a sentinel queue item.

The thread(s) executing _object_job are looping, messing with segments, so if there are more than 10,000 segments to be worked on, the _object_job thread could be left sitting blocked in segment_queue.put() when attempt_graceful_exit comes along and injects StopWorkerThreadSignal() into the object worker thread's queue.

Maybe the graceful exit triggered by the first Ctrl-C feature is misguided?  I think it'd be better for Ctrl-C to abort the whole thing than for a single Ctrl-C to cause the process to hang or for the second Ctrl-C to cause the process to hang.

Or maybe the "swift" command-line needs a significant overhaul in its concurrent execution model so that a feature like "Ctrl-C once allows in-process work to complete followed by program exit while a second Ctrl-C will immediately exit (and not hang)" can actually be implemented...'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-05-01 01:46:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Darrell, I am all for the one ctrl-c to end the whole thing.
The only good thing waiting for the segment to end then exit
before all the segments are finished is not to make the
server waiting, if we already took another patch (I submitted
and abandoned) to fix up the client disconnect error, then
ctrl-c to end the whole thing should not have any bad affect
on the server. So I am all for the ctrl-c to end the whole
thing. Further more, because of this ctrl-c support, we can
not use thread join. that actually makes things a bit
complicated.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-01 15:08:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I'd suggest taking current tip-of-master, rip out the double Ctrl-C thing, and then attack the CPU consumption.  Hopefully without the double Ctrl-C requirement, the CPU reduction implementation will be simpler an "swift" will never hang.

I think you mentioned something about making sure the "swift" client closes its open sockets to Swift on shutdown, and that also sounds like a good idea as well (with some defensive programming to make sure the Ctrl-C shutdown doesn't fail because of socket errors, etc.).

How does that sound?

Sorry for not realizing earlier that the soft-Ctrl-C exit "feature" made this so hard to get right (where I consider "right" as "the swift command-line client never hangs").  :-/'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-05-01 21:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-01 21:30:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Works for me

You don't need any of the priority queue stuff, right?  On the first (and only) Ctrl-C, the process is existing, so there's no need to send "stop" messages into the threads since we're not going to wait on them anyway.

So I think there's more code in your patch you can cut out.

I think anything in the patch not related to actually exiting when Ctrl-C is pressed or reducing CPU consumption when Ctrl-C /isn't/ pressed can be removed.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-05-02 13:51:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-02 13:52:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
remove busy-wait so that swift client won't use up all CPU cycles

The current implementation uses busy-wait and checking flags to
communicate between threads. It wastes a lot of CPU powers. With
python 2.6 is required for Swift, the communication between
threads should now be using queue and signal mechanisms. This
patch removed the busy-wait loops and use queue and queue join
for threads coordination which will not consume CPU cycles if
a thread is blocked.

Change-Id: I648cd637a92a159d5c13baa83f357cee2dfe7937

commit_message:
More doc updates.

Create doc/source/dev/ directory, and add several files that got
accidentaly ignored because they were under doc/source/api/.

Also move some files from doc/source into doc/source/dev to clean up the
base doc dir.

Change-Id: Ief9777216db82ec3be32b7a73e2d268a3a973ef8

commit_message:
Fix config drive code logical error.

Image id has changed to uuid, so bool value can't be a image ID
any more, remove unnecessary test code.

fix bug #1181991

Change-Id: I420e4cdb848401375b347d43e06343efaa7bf5fc

commit_message:
Changes the example files and modifies the README

This patch changes the quantum.pp manifest. It also deletes
the install_sample.sh script as it was out of date. Finally,
it updates the README.md file to something similar to the
other manifests.

Change-Id: Icb8cdf82a97f7a5b7b983d253ac0304123c886fb

commit_message:
Restrict StrOpt to just a few allowed values

Allow the developers to specify allowed parameter with a list
of values. Throw a ValueError when the value specified in
the command line or config file is not in the list of allowed
values

Fixes LP# 1123043

DocImpact

Change-Id: I69f5610dd738f808c7f2734e8abead0e26f8dadf

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-29 22:05:50.000000000', 'message': "Work around heat-cfntools/boto/keystone issue.

Heat-cfntools uses boto to communicate with Heat's Metadata server. In
more recent versions of boto, there is no option to use older AWS
signature methods. Only version 4 is supported. However, keystoneclient,
which keystone uses for validating signatures, only supports this in
trunk. Until that is released, any boto version after 2.5.2 will cause
heat-cfntools to be unable to authenticate with Heat.

By installing heat-cfntools in a virtualenv, we isolate it from the rest
of the system. This way as the boto version advances, we stay with the
one that works with heat-cfntools according to its own requirements.

Fixes bug #1183732

Change-Id: If0d83a29e8a7df59c1dc08f4ceae8fec2882725d
"}]
commit_message:
Work around heat-cfntools/boto/keystone issue.

Heat-cfntools uses boto to communicate with Heat's Metadata server. In
more recent versions of boto, there is no option to use older AWS
signature methods. Only version 4 is supported. However, keystoneclient,
which keystone uses for validating signatures, only supports this in
trunk. Until that is released, any boto version after 2.5.2 will cause
heat-cfntools to be unable to authenticate with Heat.

By installing heat-cfntools in a virtualenv, we isolate it from the rest
of the system. This way as the boto version advances, we stay with the
one that works with heat-cfntools according to its own requirements.

Fixes bug #1183732

Change-Id: If0d83a29e8a7df59c1dc08f4ceae8fec2882725d

Add proper README for how to develop on hacking

Move parts of HACKING to README, along with how to add rules, how to
version. This is the first pass at the README, it's expected to continue
to grow

subject: Set Disable Terminate flag on Instances
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 2835, 'name': 'Brian Elliott', 'email': 'bdelliott@gmail.com', 'username': 'belliott'}, {'_account_id': 6992, 'name': 'Kaushik Chandrashekar', 'email': 'kaushik.chandrashekar@rackspace.com', 'username': 'kaushikc'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6992, 'date': '2013-04-17 10:25:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

there's one test failing in CellsComputeAPITestCase."}, {'account_id': 6992, 'date': '2013-04-17 11:21:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

The test_update_instance_with_disable_terminate is failing in CellsComputeAPITestCase. 

The update is stubbed in CellsComputeAPITestCase.
Looking for a workaround to test cell_api's update call"}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-04-17 19:25:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi, I don't think you can just add flags to existing APIs because we don't version the individual API resources.  There is no way for a client to know if it's interacting with a service that would support the 'disable_terminate' flag.

In the past, I believe changes like this have been modified to get submitted as extensions.  In that case the client can query the server to get the list of supported extensions."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-04-19 16:01:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Yeah, I agree, this is going to have to be an extension.

Also note, there are two ways to mark a patch as work-in-progress; one is to click the "Work In Progress" button in the Gerrit interface.  The other is to submit the patch as a work in progress up front by using the "-D" or "--draft" flags to "git review".'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-04-19 16:44:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree, this has to be an extension.

Take a look at:
nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/extended_status.py

I think -D leaves the review private to only the people you add onto the review. Which at times, may be a good thing."}, {'account_id': 6992, 'date': '2013-04-26 09:11:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'm going to add a separate extension for this. Instead of making it specific for disable_terminate, do I add a generic extended_attributes extension?

Do you think there'll be more attributes like "disable_terminate", that we'd like to set during a create or update?'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-04 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-04 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

instance

commit_message:
Check role delegated uses HEAD not GET

Fix a typo where the doc said to use the GET operation to check
if role is delegated by a trust rather than HEAD.

Change-Id: I6d763cb4569968d849fec2a1963d6434cf3d2ac4

commit_message:
WIP: Add ssh power manager.

Converting nova's virtual_power_manager for use by ironic

Implements: blueprint virtual-power-driver.

Change-Id: Ib9ed8ed099445aef087ec9584d726ddf5616a339
Authored-by: Devananda van der Veen <devananda.vdv@gmail.com>
Authored-by: Chris Krelle <nobodycam@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Support Cinder mount options for NFS/GlusterFS

When connecting to an NFS or GlusterFS volume, use
mount options specified in the "options" field of
the connection_info structure to perform the mount.

This allows the Cinder volume service to specify mount
options rather than only being able to configure them
on the Nova compute node.

Fixes: bug 1185180
blueprint cinder-volume-options

Change-Id: I81a50a2ceb4da4d639f6471b2114a904e5d1a42e

commit_message:
Raise AgentBuildNotFound on updating/destroying deleted object

Methods below should raise an exception when attempting to operate
with deleted AgentBuild objects:

 nova.db.sqlalchemy.api.agent_build_destroy()
 nova.db.sqlalchemy.api.agent_build_update()

Fixes: bug 1181967

Change-Id: If6df202afb7ea41634c35f7a52988e19677f4d65

messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-23 14:53:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27346/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pep8/1472 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/27346/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/1098 : SUCCESS
