- http://logs.openstack.org/27346/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26-rhel6/119 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/27346/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/1432 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-04-23 16:17:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Ok, /tmp/openstack-zmq definitely isn't the right thing here - it's actually a security risk as someone could pre-create this dir with open permissions

I think the discussion at the summit was confused - it's not a temporary directory that's required here

When this code is used by Nova, what we need is a directory that's owned by, private to and writeable by nova

i.e. you probably want $state_path/zmq ... similar to the likes of the keys_path config option

So, you should follow what we did for sql_connection. Set the default to e.g.

  os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '../../../zmq'))

and allow nova to do:

  rpc.set_defaults(rpc_zmq_ipc_dir=paths.state_path_def('zmq'))

Also, use fileutils.ensure_dir()

There's probably a good argument for moving $state_path into olso as a general concept of a directory owned by this service ... but we can address that later"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-04-23 16:28:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Quick note, not judging if $state_path/zmq is better or worse...  it's not a security risk if you generate a random directory under tmp using tempfile.mkstemp."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-04-23 16:31:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I intended to set the permissions of this directory to 770. I missed the parameter to makedirs().

As presently designed, all projects need to access this directory.  The ZmqProxy is global to all the projects, although the binary is seeded into each of them. We could manage permissions via unix groups.

The group management is something that isn't too clear how best to handle.

The problems we're describing here are generally simple to solve, but somewhat complicated by the oslo architecture. In production, we setup secure permissions and create directories during package installation and in the upstart scripts.

The lack of state_path has surely been a thorn."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-04-23 16:35:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If you keep it under /tmp, it should certainly use tempfile.mkdtemp() which is about the only secure way to create directories under /tmp in python :)"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-04-23 18:02:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thierry, I could use mkdtemp() then change the group and directory permissions (+7 for the group).

The group would have to be changed to something all the services are a member of, which is a bit of a challenge since I don't believe there is presently any concept of a common unix group for running the services."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-04-23 22:07:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ok, I think we're being very confused here

Correct me if I'm wrong

This is a directory containing unix sockets - a server process creates a socket in this directory and a client process connects to it

The client process needs to know where to find the socket and it needs to be able to access it

In terms of permissions, AFAICT we assume that the client and server run as the same user - e.g. a process running as the nova user talking to another process running as the nova user

In terms of discovery, we use a directory that is well known to both the client and server - the socket names within that directory are derived in a predictable way from the topic name

So, mkdtemp() isn't appropriate here - it needs to be a well known directory configured in advance for the client and server

Having the server create a predictable directory in /tmp is a security issue - someone else might create the dir before the server

Using the same directory for all projects doesn't make sense as the directory needs to be private to the users which the services are running as

In a devstack type setup, the default $state_path approach used by Nova of creating a dir under the git repo is fine

In a more realistic deployment, you'll want to use e.g. /var/lib/nova/zmq and, while we might lazily create the zmq, we must assume that /var/lib/nova exists ahead of time since we won't have permissions to create it

So ... I think it's appropriate to copy the approach taken for sql_connection

But we might add $state_path to oslo itself in future"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-04-23 22:15:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Mark: we run a single ZmqProxy to handle incoming requests from/to all RPC services, regardless of if this is Nova, Quantum, Cinder, or Ceilometer.

I believe only the ZmqProxy creates sockets in this directory, so it should be okay to make the directory permissions 750, should that all the services and projects be of the same unix group.

The biggest issue is with race conditions.  We could check if the directory exists and is not a symlink, and create it both are false. If the directory exists and the owner/group/perms are okay, we can use it. However, without file locking, we'd have potential races.

There is still then the issue of ensuring all the projects and their services run within a single group that can access the directory."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-04-23 22:22:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Will look more closely tomorrow, but ...

What user does ZmqProxy run as ?

Let's assume for a minute that this isn't a developer setup and we can have packages create the directory with appropriate directory with the appropriate permissions ... what should that directory be and what permissions should it have?

(Once we've figured that out, we can figure out the correct approach for developer setups)"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-04-24 08:44:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

OK, I thought the directory was just used by the server, but since multiple parties need to be aware of it, unpredictable directories (under /tmp) is not the way to go. If we need to go with a static directory I would still prefer if we considered it created by the installer/deployer, rather than grow a dependency on rootwrap just to create it. All projects rely on some directories being created before they can run, and those are not created as root at runtime either.

The issue of group permission needs to be solved in all cases, as this is probably an issue with the current code as well.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-04-24 13:34:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thierry, I agree on those points. At present, at Cloudscaling, we solve this during installation and startup. As such, rootwrap is neither used nor required. We should have something that works by default for developers, and possibly add a DocImpacts to note the security implications/requirements.

Mark: There are two viable practices here...

1) Run ZmqProxy as a dedicated user, make the directory and sockets group-readable. All services of all projects belong to that group.

2) Run ZmqProxy as the project user (nova, quantum, etc). Deploy each project with a different CONF.rpc_zmq_port variable. This is the effective equivalent to a control_exchange for ZeroMQ. Because control_exchange is a string and not a numeral, we can't use that directly. This configuration also causes the same problems for projects like Ceilometer that control_exchange demands, but unlike the AMQP-specific control_exchange, is not on the radar for leaking into the abstraction...

Honestly, I'm increasingly interested in copying the Rabbit/Qpid behavior here of having control_exchanges implemented via a different rpc_zmq_port per project. Assigning those ports to various projects and dealing with that seems a bit messy, however."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-04-25 13:48:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

If the proxy is run as a dedicated user, and the socket names are predictable, then the group only needs execute permission on the directory to use the sockets.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-03 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-03 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-09 10:49:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Another issue uncovered with this stuff: https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo/+bug/1160420/comments/5'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Restored'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:41:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Changed the commit message. Limiting the scope of this change to removing rootwrap. Pushing the problem of groups/permissions/etc. upward, while better handling the errors we might see here.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 15:43:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-23 14:49:07.000000000', 'message': 'Move default ipc dir to /tmp

Removes processutils/rootwrap dependency.
Fixes bug 1160420

NOTE: Systems upgrading will see their sockets moved.
If restarting all services on a machine, this
should not have any adverse effect. Upgrading single
services on a machine, without upgrading or restarting
them all, could cause problems.

Change-Id: I7814320adbfd0b2fe54cc2e523452c18ab2e7687
'}, {'created': '2013-05-23 15:40:12.000000000', 'message': 'Remove rootwrap from IPC directory creation

Removes processutils/rootwrap dependency.
Fixes bug 1160420 and partially fixes 1180631.

The attempt will still be made to create
/var/run/openstack, but will give a reasonable
error when it happens.

If the directory exists, but permissions are denied,
we should also give a reasonable error.

A patch will be submitted to devstack
that will set and create the IPC directory as necessary.
Packagers should do this as well.

Change-Id: I7814320adbfd0b2fe54cc2e523452c18ab2e7687
'}]
commit_message:
Remove rootwrap from IPC directory creation

Removes processutils/rootwrap dependency.
Fixes bug 1160420 and partially fixes 1180631.

The attempt will still be made to create
/var/run/openstack, but will give a reasonable
error when it happens.

If the directory exists, but permissions are denied,
we should also give a reasonable error.

A patch will be submitted to devstack
that will set and create the IPC directory as necessary.
Packagers should do this as well.

Change-Id: I7814320adbfd0b2fe54cc2e523452c18ab2e7687

commit_message:
Use stubout in test_correlation_id

Best to use stubout for stubbing out methods like this. That way they
get properly unstubbed on failure.

Change-Id: I61dc96d01e331e8d811b8f24137e8f738cf09215

[{'created': '2013-05-28 14:32:29.000000000', 'message': 'Improve error messages for invalid --nic / --file.

Implemented by catching the valueerror thrown when unpacking a split to
two variables but the split string is not present.

Change-Id: I9930fe828c932e103fdad1b88c3434f097664f31
'}, {'created': '2013-05-29 09:00:52.000000000', 'message': 'Improve error messages for invalid --nic / --file.

Implemented by catching the valueerror thrown when unpacking a split to
two variables but the split string is not present.

commit_message:
Improve error messages for invalid --nic / --file.

Implemented by catching the valueerror thrown when unpacking a split to
two variables but the split string is not present.

Change-Id: I9930fe828c932e103fdad1b88c3434f097664f31

commit_message:
More doc updates.

- general updates to index.rst
- add api quick-ref section to index.rst
- consolidate contributing/* to contributing.rst & dev-quickstart.rst
- remove broken :term: links in architecture.rst
- rename v1.rst -> api-spec-v1.rst

Change-Id: Ib02fb3f8c8e3c6450e74b3a6831795699b2ddf67

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-29 12:10:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I would prefer to sit on this until we have a documented plan on how to add new tests.  We cannot add new tests without bumping the version property etc.

Also this needs a update to the readme and to the tox file to enable the test.

Also I am fine with false negatives, but it sounds like this can have a false positive.  Which is't acceptable.  Is that the case here?"}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-05-29 13:59:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Yes, this can have a false positive.  I didn't find any cases in OpenStack code where we do

ex = Exception()
raise ex

But if we did, it would be falsely flagged."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-29 14:13:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Do not merge

hacking exists on a fine line of making code review better and pissing of patch authors.  So I don't want any false positives.  If we can show why the so called false positive is a bad coding practice itself we can make a rule for that too


Note: some false positives may exist today, which should be treated as bugs."}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-05-29 19:00:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

Abandoning because of the chance of false positives.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-29 02:09:43.000000000', 'message': "Add hacking_raise_only_instances

It tests that the first argument of a raise statement, if it
has one, contains a '(' character.  This is designed to flag
various deprecated ways of raising exceptions: string
exceptions, raising an exception class, and raising an
exception class then a comma then a string.

It's not foolproof because one can legitimately create an
exception instance on a previous line then raise it later.
But that doesn't happen very often in real code.

Change-Id: Id680fab50c43864ee139072910bb814830ac3fad
"}, {'created': '2013-05-29 02:10:21.000000000', 'message': "Add hacking_raise_only_instances

commit_message:
Add hacking_raise_only_instances

It tests that the first argument of a raise statement, if it
has one, contains a '(' character.  This is designed to flag
various deprecated ways of raising exceptions: string
exceptions, raising an exception class, and raising an
exception class then a comma then a string.

It's not foolproof because one can legitimately create an
exception instance on a previous line then raise it later.
But that doesn't happen very often in real code.

Fixes bug 1185225

Change-Id: Id680fab50c43864ee139072910bb814830ac3fad

[{'created': '2013-05-27 06:03:56.000000000', 'message': "Rename TestCase.flags() to TestCase.config()

The 'flags' thing harks back to when we were using gflags, so rename the
method to config() like most other projects call it. I really should
change this in Nova someday too.

Change-Id: I07bcb6392b47cb78a2b58a5a1d663d544e7a5b63
"}]
commit_message:
Rename TestCase.flags() to TestCase.config()

The 'flags' thing harks back to when we were using gflags, so rename the
method to config() like most other projects call it. I really should
change this in Nova someday too.

Change-Id: I07bcb6392b47cb78a2b58a5a1d663d544e7a5b63

commit_message:
Initial skeleton for an RPC layer.

This patch implements the a framework for RPC between the API service
and the Manager service. It implements only the 'get_node_power_state'
method, and adds a unit test.

Change-Id: I19e4b761ef212de4c8fd0e600e98368e520a44aa

Fix a few things in conf.py

Change-Id: Ieb62caa7d4540ed642265612eb9a04e5a61a7b99

commit_message:
Log configuration values on API startup

It's very helpful for every service to log its configuration values on
startup, so you can e.g. check typos.

Also, change the print statements in the API binary to info logs.

Change-Id: I1b4181ddc7f36149cddb2c24f514d526c403b2e0

[{'created': '2013-05-28 10:35:05.000000000', 'message': "Don't use pecan to configure logging

Fixes bug #1184941

openstack.common.log gives a mechanism to configure logging and, by
default, we will set up a handler on root logger. Using pecan to also
configure a handler on the 'ironic' logger means every log message gets
logged to console twice.

It seems that the pecan logging configuration stuff is redundant with
our existing logging configuration infrastructure.

Change-Id: Iec0630b0e842e3b6a90021bf552d9b857c5a0552
"}]
commit_message:
Don't use pecan to configure logging

Fixes bug #1184941

openstack.common.log gives a mechanism to configure logging and, by
default, we will set up a handler on root logger. Using pecan to also
configure a handler on the 'ironic' logger means every log message gets
logged to console twice.

It seems that the pecan logging configuration stuff is redundant with
our existing logging configuration infrastructure.

Change-Id: Iec0630b0e842e3b6a90021bf552d9b857c5a0552

subject: Update proposed API.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 04:38:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29867/1/check/gate-ironic-pep8/39 : SUCCESS in 1m 44s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29867/1/check/gate-ironic-python26/39 : SUCCESS in 2m 50s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29867/1/check/gate-ironic-python27/39 : SUCCESS in 1m 56s
'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-21 10:57:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 7625, 'date': '2013-05-21 13:15:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The patch looks fine.  However, I do have some comments about the proposed API.

The API should be discoverable from a single entry point.  This is usually '/' or '/<version/'.  This is missing from the description.

Generally plurals of resource names are used when dealing with collections and subordinates of collections.  For example, '/nodes' instead of '/node'.  This does not in anyway go against any REST principle, but is generally the default for REST clients and client generation tools.  It also makes sense from a semantic point of view, since collections are sets of resources.

The JSON resource representation uses '_' for keys and '-' in values.  Could this be consistent.

A more standard format for JSON resource ID's is to use _id or id rather than <resource_type>_id.  Again, doesn't go against any principle but is used usually by default by most client tools.

Nested resources should be referred to using a resource or link to resource rather than id.  At the moment the API uses the ID.  For example in the iface desription:

{
	        "port_id": "fake-port-uuid",
	        "node_id": "fake-node-uuid",
	        "address": "01:23:45:67:89:0A",
}

It would also be useful to add a _type or an equilivilent field that shows the resource type.  For example _type; iface.  This way the resource description is all that is needed to make sense of the resource (rather than inferring this information from the URL).

URL should be the unique identifier of the resource rather than the ID.  The ID could also be unique but it is really an implementation detail.

URLs should also be present in resources.'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-05-21 17:01:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> The API should be discoverable from a single entry point. 

++ to "/" listing versions and "/<version>/" listing capabilities

> Generally plurals of resource names are used when dealing with collections and subordinates of collections. For example, '/nodes' instead of '/node'.

++

> The JSON resource representation uses '_' for keys and '-' in values. Could this be consistent.

To be simplistic, I initially had each API model match the DB schema, which means "_" in the class members, which Pecan in turn uses to generate the JSON resource's keys. I'm fine with either, as long as it's consistent.

As for what separator is used in values, I think this depends on the value in question. I don't see a strong case for normalizing this across all values, but instead to specify that certain values expect one or the other (eg, uuid-like values expect "-", a mac address expects ":", and so on).

> A more standard format for JSON resource ID's is to use _id or id rather than <resource_type>_id. Again, doesn't go against any principle but is used usually by default by most client tools.

If you mean that the identifier for a requested resource, eg the node returned from "GET /nodes/123", should be "_id" instead of "node_id", I can agree with that. If you mean something else, please clarify.

> Nested resources should be referred to using a resource or link to resource rather than id. At the moment the API uses the ID.

Sure. This was a simpler way to represent the internal data. I'm fine with the API presenting this in a more standard fashion.

> It would also be useful to add a _type or an equilivilent field that shows the resource type. For example _type; iface. This way the resource description is all that is needed to make sense of the resource (rather than inferring this information from the URL).

Fair 'nuf. I'd like to see the types consistent between the API and the code: chassis, node, and port.

> URL should be the unique identifier of the resource rather than the ID. The ID could also be unique but it is really an implementation detail.

Yes. The "_id" in the resource and in the URL should be the UUID of the resource, rather than the internal AUTO_INCREMENT INTEGER value. I probably didn't make that clear... :)

> URLs should also be present in resources.

Can you give an example?


Thanks!
-D'}, {'account_id': 7625, 'date': '2013-05-22 10:23:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
>
>> The API should be discoverable from a single entry point.
> ++ to "/" listing versions and "/<version>/" listing capabilities

I think that is a reasonable approach.  To be honest in the past I've simply used different end points for different versions, often only supporting 1 version at a time.

Do you intend or do other OpenStack components regularly support multiple versions of an API in a single release of the code base?
>
>> Generally plurals of resource names are used when dealing with collections and subordinates of collections. For example, '/nodes' instead of '/node'.
> ++
>
>> The JSON resource representation uses '_' for keys and '-' in values. Could this be consistent.
> To be simplistic, I initially had each API model match the DB schema, which means "_" in the class members, which Pecan in turn uses to generate the JSON resource's keys. I'm fine with either, as long as it's consistent.
>
> As for what separator is used in values, I think this depends on the value in question. I don't see a strong case for normalizing this across all values, but instead to specify that certain values expect one or the other (eg, uuid-like values expect "-", a mac address expects ":", and so on).

Actually you are right here.  What I really meant was to keep the replacement of \s consistent.  i.e. not "foo_bar":"foo-bar".  But when I looked again at your example JSON representations I can see you have done this already for everything except the uuid, which makes complete sense.
>
>> A more standard format for JSON resource ID's is to use  id or id rather than <resource_type>_id. Again, doesn't go against any principle but is used usually by default by most client tools.

> If you mean that the identifier for a requested resource, eg the node returned from "GET /nodes/123", should be "_id" instead of "node_id", I can agree with that. If you mean something else, please clarify.
Yes, that is what I meant.
>
>> Nested resources should be referred to using a resource r link to resource rather than id. At the moment the API uses the ID.

> Sure. This was a simpler way to represent the internal data. I'm fine with the API presenting this in a more standard fashion.

Great, this is really here to adhere to the "discoverability" principle.  i.e. You should be a able to move around the API with having an understanding of how the URLs are constructed.
>
>> It would also be useful to add a _type or an equilivilent field that shows the resource type. For example _type; iface. This way the resource description is all that is needed to make sense of the resource (rather than inferring this information from the URL).

> Fair 'nuf. I'd like to see the types consistent between the API and the code: chassis, node, and port.
Sure that makes sense.  

One comment here and for your point later about copying the database schema.  

I have worked with in the past with many people that favour copying the code representation or data base schemas and expose them via the API, this has led to a couple of problems, I've list 2 of the major ones below.

The approach I take when creating an API is to think about the API consumer, and figure out what he/she needs.  This may look similar to the internal object model, but should be filtered from information or resources that are of no value.

Issues I've seen in the past:

  * An extremely complex resource model in the API with things like database foreign keys, resources that have no value or make sense
  * Tight coupling between the code and the API, making it difficult to refactor and/or make significant changes without affecting the API

>
>> URL should be the unique identifier of the resource rather than the ID. The ID could also be unique but it is really an implementation detail.
> Yes. The "_id" in the resource and in the URL should be the UUID of the resource, rather than the internal AUTO_INCREMENT INTEGER value. I probably didn't make that clear...

++ (though tbh we shouldn't actually need the "_id" at all.  Since in the HTTP world the url is the _id.  The _id field in this case is simply an implementation detail).
>
>> URLs should also be present in resources.

Sure, I just meant that when returning the resource, the url should be included in the resource description.  Since this is where the resource lives and it's unique id.  Later tasks like updating the resource can update the description and PUT to the URL.

e.g.

GET http://<ip>:<port>:/v1/chassis/1

{
     '_id': 1
     'url': 'http://<ip>:<port>:/v1/chassis/1'
     '_type': 'chassis'
}

> Can you give an example?
>
>
> Thanks!
> -D
Thanks a lot.  I think we have pretty much agreed on the points above.

I'll go ahead and write up a proposed API with the suggestions.'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-05-23 03:29:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Martyn and I talked briefly on IRC. He is working on merging this discussion into the spec, which will hopefully be the last major change before we start implementing it."}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-05-26 23:24:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I forgot to post this link a few days ago. Ongoing discussion of the API spec is now here:

  https://etherpad.openstack.org/ironic_api'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-05-29 18:53:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Superceded by:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30763/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-21 04:35:10.000000000', 'message': 'Update proposed API.

Make it more resource-oriented.

Rename iface -> port, and add the chassis resource.

Add some JSON examples, and some proper RST formatting.

Change-Id: I1c434e92c1b7b6d9b61f2332ca0e1c425fee14b4
'}]
commit_message:
Update proposed API.

Make it more resource-oriented.

Rename iface -> port, and add the chassis resource.

Add some JSON examples, and some proper RST formatting.

Change-Id: I1c434e92c1b7b6d9b61f2332ca0e1c425fee14b4

commit_message:
100% test coverage for security groups and rules

This patch achieves full test coverage for security_group and
security_group_rules by:

- Fixing the arguments used in test_invalid_parameters_create
- Testing the __str__ and delete methods of SecurityGroupRule
- Adding a test for the ___str__ method of SecurityGroup

Change-Id: I9cfbc68761f158754aa4b339238d29cc587c91e1

commit_message:
Support our own apache access/error log names

It looks like the apache cookbook does not set a default access_log
attribute. Even if it did, it would probably be too generic for anyone
wanting to isolate access logs for openstack-dashboard. Similarly,
So, move this attribute into our own namespace and set the default as
"openstack-dashboard-access.log". As error logs fall into the same
dilemna, maintain consistency by also configuring their naming inside
this cookbook.

Change-Id: Iaa7c4202a14c6e3a963cb1bc5f37239c847264b0

commit_message:
rbd: send ceph monitor addresses with connection info

Previously we relied on a ceph configuration file on the compute host
for this information. Sending the info directly from cinder makes more
complex setups with multiple ceph clusters talking to the same compute
hosts possible.

Refresh the monitor addresses for each initialize_connection() call,
since monitors may be added or removed while cinder-volume is
running.

Fixes: bug 1077817
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

Change-Id: I34a1fa16ce1f4524ba25832faf3129303e755100

commit_message:
Do not configure memcache if no servers found

If a user specified memcache as the session_backend for the dashboard
then make sure we have memcache servers to configure local_settings.py
with. Attempting to configure this Django front-end with memcache on
and no servers found/specified will cause Django to 500. But, that is
not to say that this configuration is an error - this could happen as
the environment is being converged across nodes.

This change adds tests to support this logic.

Change-Id: I72cf5465d09aec34d9a76305819745b0580b19a2

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-20 20:11:44.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that pbr>=0.5.10 is installed

A bug in PBR levels less than 0.5.10 causes the
/usr/lib/python2.X/site-packages/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/migrate.cfg
file to not be properly installed.  This causes 'cinder-manage db sync'
to fail due to the missing file.

This change sets the required PRR level to >=0.5.10,<0.6 to avoid the problem.
In the case that user already has a 0.5.X level of PBR installed that is less
than 0.5.10 it should be updated rather than encountering issues as our
test system did.

Change-Id: I532158277a4acbb2f8cb75d03c91097e6d7e0312
fixes: bug 1182203
"}, {'created': '2013-05-29 15:12:29.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that pbr>=0.5.10 is installed

/usr/lib/python2.X/site-packages/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/migrate.cfg
file to not be properly installed.  This causes 'cinder-manage db sync'
to fail due to the missing file.

This change sets the required PBR level to >=0.5.10,<0.6 to avoid the problem.
In the case that user already has a 0.5.X level of PBR installed that is less
than 0.5.10 it should be updated rather than encountering issues as our
test system did.

Change-Id: I532158277a4acbb2f8cb75d03c91097e6d7e0312
fixes: bug 1182203
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure that pbr>=0.5.10 is installed

A bug in PBR levels less than 0.5.10 causes the
/usr/lib/python2.X/site-packages/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/migrate.cfg
file to not be properly installed.  This causes 'cinder-manage db sync'
to fail due to the missing file.

This change sets the required PBR level to >=0.5.10,<0.6 to avoid the problem.
In the case that user already has a 0.5.X level of PBR installed that is less
than 0.5.10 it should be updated rather than encountering issues as our
test system did.

Change-Id: I532158277a4acbb2f8cb75d03c91097e6d7e0312
fixes: bug 1182203

commit_message:
Brings in Matt's openstack-ops-database work

Just bring in Matt's original work on the ops-database
cookbook.

Corrects what I think was a typo for the database service
role name attribute from openstack::role::database to
openstack::database::server_role

Brings in Berksfile and Gemfile and stubbed specs to pass
gates. Also sets version to 7.0.0 to match semantic versions
of openstack project cookbooks.

Change-Id: Idc02435ff7d3ff4b8a04c2bfc5abbb1e3091cb68

commit_message:
Add tailor to the compute cookbook

Add a tailor style guide check to be incorporated with the standard
run_tests. These checks are the defaults with the exception of the 80
character line limit. As this is being added to the standard set of
tests being executed during CI, this will add an extra step - locally
this was costing me ~20sec per run.

Change-Id: Ie78bc7c969e0c8d3563d76829b25c19b66341292

commit_message:
test_glance.py: Stub out _get_member_model as well.

glanceclient's v2 client needs to also have its _get_member_model()
stubbed out as well, to avoid attempts to reach 'fake_host' during
client instantiation.

Update: Only stub when _get_member_model() when required.

Change-Id: I943cbb017ccdbe4f6c994bc83cbefe8693f4672b
Fixes: bug #1185178.

commit_message:
Pin the versions of pep8/pyflakes here.

This way we don't need expansive blocks copied around everywhere.
hacking is developed against specific versions of libraries - use them.

Change-Id: Ie5b0e30f8067d509d19c082d5a3ebf27d737d2bd
Reviewed-on: https://review.openstack.org/30556
Reviewed-by: Joe Gordon <joe.gordon0@gmail.com>
Reviewed-by: James E. Blair <corvus@inaugust.com>
Approved: Sean Dague <sean@dague.net>
Reviewed-by: Sean Dague <sean@dague.net>
Tested-by: Jenkins

New patch set coming soon. This one will not be marked WIP. All comments to this point have been addressed. The config defaults and config files are cleaned up, and the initial DB migration support has been added.

Several items remain to implement following this merge:

* GreTypeDriver and RPCs for managing tunnel endpoints.
* Calling into MechanismDrivers to determine binding:vif_type value for a port. MechanismDrivers for the agents will use the binding:host_id and the agent_db data to determine the binding:vif_type.
* More unit tests.
* MechanismDriver calls as part of network and port CRUD operations, in order to support SDN controllers, top-of-rack switched, etc..'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Work In Progress

I can confirm the plugin with the devstack patch works fine for me.

- a short README file
- fix of some minor nits like whitespaces

Removal of stub code would be a nice plus.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (18 inline comments)

While I am approaching to run this patch (which I expect to run perfectly fine since it's already been tested), I have a few comments inline.

Most of them are just questions from my curiosity.
Others are nits, or advice to remove code which at the moment appears to be just a stub.

The bits which might need some discussion here or in follow-up patches are:

- conceptually I think that there is no "provider reserve" or "tenant allocation". I would just call this methods allocate and 'reserve'. Whether these are mapped to provider or tenant, this depends on the particular deployment.
- multiple segments. It seems the data model is ready for them, but it is not obvious to me how the plugin currently handles them. It is something which will come in subsequent patches?
- allocation of network segment in flat mode for a tenant is just a 'pass' now. Is that how it's supposed to work? Shouldn't it work in a way similar to the VLAN driver, just without allocating the segment exclusively?

The only thing that I really would like to see addresses in a first patch is a README file. Most of the stuff you put in the commit message is actually more suitable for a README file (people installing packages won't have the git log)'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(9 inline comments)

Some cleanup comments are inline.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hi,
I agree with Salvatore's comments above. It will be great when this is through so that others in the community can also start to contribute and we can move this forwards.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (3 inline comments)

See minor clarifications on commit message in-line.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (29 inline comments)

I'm about to submit a new patch set that resolves most of the comments, and I've responded to all the in-line comments.

Responding to Salvatore's out-of-line comments:

[Salvatore] conceptually I think that there is no "provider reserve" or "tenant allocation". I would just call this methods allocate and 'reserve'. Whether these are mapped to provider or tenant, this depends on the particular deployment.

[response] The interaction between the plugin and the TypeDrivers is very different depending on whether or not provider attributes have been supplied. We could consider renaming the methods at some point, but right now the 'provider' methods apply when provider attributes have been supplied, and the 'tenant' methods apply when they haven't. I feel this is a reasonable division of labor between the plugin and the TypeDrivers, but it can be revisited later if needed.

[Salvatore] multiple segments. It seems the data model is ready for them, but it is not obvious to me how the plugin currently handles them. It is something which will come in subsequent patches?

[response] That's correct. I'm hoping we can extend the provider extension API to support multi-segment networks during havana, but this isn't necessary for parity with the existing openvswitch, linuxbridge, or hyperv plugins. I plan to write a blueprint to cover this.

[Salvatore] allocation of network segment in flat mode for a tenant is just a 'pass' now. Is that how it's supposed to work? Shouldn't it work in a way similar to the VLAN driver, just without allocating the segment exclusively?

[response] Yes, this is how FlatTypeDriver is intended to work. By returning None, it allows subsequent type drivers listed in tenant_network_types to have a chance. I don't think it makes sense to allocate flat networks to tenants from a pool, since there will never be very many of them. We could consider preventing type drivers like FlatTypeDriver that cannot allocate tenant networks from being listed in tenant_network_types as a future enhancement.

[Salvatore] The only thing that I really would like to see addresses in a first patch is a README file. Most of the stuff you put in the commit message is actually more suitable for a README file (people installing packages won't have the git log)

[response] I've added a README file and will edit the commit message.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'message': 'Initial Modular L2 plugin implementation.

The Modular L2 Plugin uses drivers to support extensible sets of
network types and of mechanisms for accessing networks of those
types. Drivers are loaded as python entrypoints using the stevedore
library. Networks can be composed of multiple segments.

This initial patchset manages network types using drivers. It includes
drivers for the local, flat, and vlan network types. Type-related
functionality and code, including provider network validation and
tenant network allocation, is similar to the linuxbridge and
openvswitch plugins. Enhancements include allocation of multiple
tenant network types and the option of allowing flat and vlan provider
networks with physical_network names not listed in configuration.

Support for mechanism drivers is currently skeletal. The interface for
server-side mechanism drivers remains to be defined in a future
patchset. Also, the database schema and driver APIs support
multi-segment networks, but the client API for multi-segment networks
is not yet implemented. Current plans are to support the existing
linuxbridge, openvswitch, and possibly other agents prior to
implementing a modular L2 agent.

Implements: blueprint modular-l2
Change-Id: Ia8cae480180f0990af7d5e5e56f29eaeac205e0e
'}, {'created': '2013-05-29 17:21:05.000000000', 'message': "Initial (WIP) Modular L2 plugin implementation.

The Modular L2 Plugin uses drivers to support separately extensible
sets of network types and of mechanisms for accessing networks of
those types. Unlike with the metaplugin, multiple mechanisms can be
used simultaneously to access different ports of the same
network. Mechanisms can utilize agents via RPC and/or use mechanism
drivers to interact with external devices or controllers. Networks can
be composed of multiple segments. Type and mechanism drivers are
loaded as python entrypoints using the stevedore library.

Network types are managed using drivers. This initial version includes
drivers for the local, flat, and vlan network types. Type-related
functionality and code, including provider network validation and
tenant network allocation, is similar to the linuxbridge and
openvswitch plugins, but is refactored into separate drivers. Minor
functional enhancements include allocation of tenant networks from
multiple pools of different types and the option of allowing flat and
vlan provider networks with physical_network names not listed in
configuration.

RPC callback and notification interfaces support interaction with L2,
DHCP, and L3 agents. This version has been tested with the existing
openvswitch plugin's L2 agent, and may also work with the hyperv L2
agent. Additional work is needed to support the linuxbridge L2 agent,
since its current RPC interfaces differ slightly. A modular agent may
be developed as a follow-on effort.

Support for mechanism drivers is currently skeletal. The interface for
server-side mechanism drivers remains to be defined in a future
version. Mechanism drivers will be called both inside and following DB
transactions for network and port create/update/delete operations.

The database schema and driver APIs support multi-segment networks,
but the client API for multi-segment networks is not yet implemented.

A devstack patch supporting use of the ml2 plugin with the openvswitch
L2 agent for the local, flat and vlan network types is at
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/27576/. Note that the gre network
type and the tunnel-related RPCs are not yet implemented, so use the
vlan network type for multi-node testing.

Implements: blueprint modular-l2
Change-Id: Ia8cae480180f0990af7d5e5e56f29eaeac205e0e

those types. Unlike with the metaplugin, multiple mechanisms can be
used simultaneously to access different ports of the same
network. Mechanisms can utilize agents via RPC and/or use mechanism

openvswitch and linuxbridge plugins' L2 agents, and may also work with

effort.

Support for mechanism drivers is currently skeletal. The interface for
server-side mechanism drivers remains to be defined in a future
version. Mechanism drivers will be called both inside and following DB
transactions for network and port create/update/delete operations.

The database schema and driver APIs support multi-segment networks,
but the client API for multi-segment networks is not yet implemented.

A devstack patch supporting use of the ml2 plugin with either the
openvswitch or linuxbridge L2 agent for the local, flat and vlan
network types is at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/27576/. Note that

implemented, so use the vlan network type for multi-node testing. Also
note that ml2 does not yet work with nova's GenericVIFDriver, so it is

the L2 agent deployed on each compute node.

- Return useful binding:vif_type value for GenericVIFDriver
- Implement GRE tunnel endpoint management RPCs and DB (might defer)

commit_message:
Initial Modular L2 plugin implementation.

The Modular L2 Plugin uses drivers to support separately extensible
sets of network types and of mechanisms for accessing networks of
those types. This is an initial implementation that has been tested
with the openvswitch and linuxbridge agents, and should also work with
the hyperv agent. See quantum/plugins/ml2/README for details.

Implements: blueprint modular-l2
Change-Id: Ia8cae480180f0990af7d5e5e56f29eaeac205e0e

'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-20 13:05:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

__doc__ is a class attribute already so what does changing it's name accomplish, other than reducing readability and maintainability?"}, {'account_id': 7138, 'date': '2013-05-20 14:41:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Dolph:
  Thanks for your comments.
  I have tried to directly wrap __doc__ by _() function,but translated __doc__ string doesn't work,
"return self.__doc__ % kwargs
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for %: 'NoneType' and 'dict'
" exist. If we want add REST API return message in keystone exception module,we need to use class variable "message" to work against translated messages.
  For readability and maintainability,could you explain more about your concern? I'd like to know what cause readability and maintainability reducing. Thank you!'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-20 15:08:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can you elaborate on "tried to directly wrap __doc__ by _() function"? I did this in my patch and it works just fine.'}, {'account_id': 7138, 'date': '2013-05-20 15:42:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Take class Unauthorized as a sample,the way to directly translate __doc__ string is:
"
class Unauthorized(SecurityError):
  _("""The request you have made requires authentication.""")
  code = 401
  title = 'Unauthorized'
"
then extract the __doc__ string into keystone.pot file and translate it.But it can't work.

I'd like to point out that in your patch, __doc__ string can't be extracted into pot file, then they can't be translated.'}, {'account_id': 7138, 'date': '2013-05-21 14:51:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dolph:

  Whether I have answered your question? I'd like invite you to review/validate my patch again, thank you!"}, {'account_id': 7138, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:21:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dolph:
  I hope that I have answered your question.I'm looking forward to your follow up comments."}, {'account_id': 7138, 'date': '2013-05-29 15:31:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-29 15:31:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset."}, {'account_id': 7138, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:08:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7138, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:10:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Abandoned

commit_message:
Implement exception module i18n support

The doc string in exception.py of Keystone
will be returned with __doc__ method, but
cannot realize the internationalization.
Change exception module to enbale i18n
support.

Changes are:
1, use class variable message to replace
   using  __doc__
2, update new REST API return messages
   into keystone.pot
3, modify wsgi.render_exception function to
   support unicode messages

Fixes: bug # 1179425
Change-Id: I2ff873d353cff03d9abc2e0e0a0664f816f593f4
